138217: Unbender Tine.author: Shiizu
138217: Unbender Tine.text_parsed:
A surprisingly flexible and powerful card. It accelerates your mana, fixes your mana, can fix your teammate's mana and accelerate him in Emperor or Two-headed giant. It basically lets you (ab)use all tapping effects twice. I played it in a deck that sported Obelisk of Alara and Merieke Ri Berit. It also had a maze of ith in it.

Really, it's an amazing card that gets extra value out of tap effects, fixes and accelerates mana, and turns one of your creatures into a vigilant one.

144249: Pale Recluse.author: ZursApprentice
144249: Pale Recluse.text_parsed:
You guys are missing the point. You aren't always going to have the green for Rampant Growth and cycling is also done at instant speed. Yes, instant speed may not be relevant all the time, but it is still a plus. A 4/5 reach for 6 is efficient in Limited and Pauper. If it was a 5/5 reach, then you would be approaching constructed territory. Giant Spider was always a decent pick in limited, this is 2/1 bigger for 2 mana more, and can be cycled. A 4/5 reach is often going to be the biggest creature on the battlefield in limited. Add the the fact that it's cycling ability is quite good and this card because an insane common in limited. As for Pauper, Twisted Abomination was always good in that format. This is about the same size, with reach instead of regen, and can find two different types of lands instead of just swamps. Ok, even in Pauper maybe it isn't overpowered, but there is some use for it. Obviously it isn't good enough for standard constructed.

I give it a 4 for being a limited powerhouse.

144249: Pale Recluse.author: The_Jabberwocky
144249: Pale Recluse.text_parsed: I feel this card is under-rated. I use him in my Doran EDH deck. If I draw him early, I cycle him to pull a Bayou, Scrubland or Savannah out of my deck which is always a huge help. If I draw him once my mana is stabilized, I play him as a creature. He also works great because my mostly treefolk Doran deck has no flying creatures and no other creatures with reach. With Doran out, he can swap with Thundermaw Hellkite and other 5/5 flyers. Its his versatility which makes him great. I love the art work also. An easy 4/5 stars for casual and EDH formats.

144276: Igneous Pouncer.author: IncrediSteve
144276: Igneous Pouncer.text_parsed: The Dual landcycling Creatures are supposed to be "bad". Their primary purpose is to fetch a land and fix your mana; but should your mana be fine, or if you draw this late game, it's got the flexibility of being a creature you can cast. Any decent strength hasty creature is a viable play when your opponent taps out and doesn't kill you. Great for limited, worth considering in Casual for the manafixing and emergency creature.

Yeah there are beter creatures to reanimate but they usualy don't put themselves into the graveyrd, and it can always be used to tutor the lands and bump up other creatures that live off creatures in graveyards.  Tutoring lands includes thining out your deck which is always a good thing.  Also as said before, with living end deck its high enough to not be cascaded before living end and bringing out a 5/1 with hase is never bad when they don't have a chance to respond and probably have no blockers (unless they are sacing creatures themselves).  Every card has a use, even defensive stance, even if it is just usualy outclassed by other cards.

144286: Jhessian Zombies.author: snyden
144286: Jhessian Zombies.text_parsed: This is a land cycling card, not a creature. If it wasn't more expensive than it was worth it would be overpowered. Then, say, if you have more than enough lands and you don't need a land cycling card later in the game, it is still somewhat useful as a creature if drawn.  a 2/4 creature with fear, which may be able to act as that one blocker you need to stay alive or sneak in that little bit of damage you needed to snatch a victory from defeat. Dual use cards are pretty nice, and I'm somewhat surprised at the one-sided reviews it is getting.  Any zombie deck in standard should be running four of these as a staple for getting the mana you need to win.

At half a glance, it's CC is rubbish... but it's got Island AND Swamp cycling, AND Fear, AND it's a Zombie.

There are great perks to using this in a U/B Zombie deck. In the company of cards such as Zombify, Death Baron, and Avatar of Woe the advantages FAR outweigh the gripes if you ask me. The 6 CC is way too high to pay straight up,... so, cycle him, then rise him from the grave and get a Death Baron or a Cemetery Reaper in play. Think outside the box.

Also, i LIKE the art a lot! Ordered two of these for xmas.

147530: Retaliator Griffin.author: JaxsonBateman
147530: Retaliator Griffin.text_parsed:
Not a bad card. If you take a hit from a flier that your other fatties can't block, you'll become strong enough to block it next time. It is a target for removal, but even just having 3 colours works really well with Knight of New Alara, pumping it up to a 5/5 immediately.

If your opponent doesn't have any fliers or removal, it can work as a great shield while you establish board dominance aswell. They're probably not going to attack if they'd have to take at least that much back +2 next turn.

Edit: somewhat take it back. It's so hard to get him up to anything significant. You're basically relying on another card to pump it up to be a worthwhile 4 drop. Perhaps the only thing it's good for is stopping your opponent from attacking if he doesn't have removal and can't deal winning damage in one turn.
147530: Retaliator Griffin.text_posted:
Not a bad card. If you take a hit from a flier that your other fatties can't block, you'll become strong enough to block it next time. It is a target for removal, but even just having 3 colours works really well with Knight of New Alara, pumping it up to a 5/5 immediately.

If your opponent doesn't have any fliers or removal, it can work as a great shield while you establish board dominance aswell. They're probably not going to attack if they'd have to take at least that much back +2 next turn.

Edit: somewhat take it back. It's so hard to get him up to anything significant. You're basically relying on another card to pump it up to be a worthwhile 4 drop. Perhaps the only thing it's good for is stopping your opponent from attacking if he doesn't have removal and can't deal winning damage in one turn.

147530: Retaliator Griffin.author: achilleselbow
147530: Retaliator Griffin.text_parsed:
@SoulShatterer: No. Read the card again. He only gets the counters when damage is dealt to YOU.

I agree that while this may seem awesome, it's kind of a lose-lose situation. If you already have a good defense set up, he just becomes a really weak 4-drop. If you don't, then you could have spent that 4 mana casting a Spellbreaker Behemoth or Mycoid Shepherd to block whatever damage was coming your way. Considering how many creatures there are that trigger effects after dealing damage to a player, it's pretty dangerous to let the damage through just to power up a creature that could still get Terminated immediately after. The flying may make it useful in some situations, but overall it just doesn't have very good synergy with a Naya deck.

@Wormfang: I don't think it works like that...

Retaliator Griffin is an awesome card, even though it may seem bad. You should give him lifelink with, say, Scourge of the Nobilis and shroud/hexproof with, say, Swiftfoot Boots.

If you give it lifelink, it combos really well with Phyrexian Unlife. If you're reduced to zero or less, your griffin becomes enormous. Then you swing to regain life before your opponent can poison you to death.

Really, though, it's just a cool card. I like it.

147530: Retaliator Griffin.author: UsagiYojimbo
147530: Retaliator Griffin.text_parsed:
This card is the Polar Opposite of Kavu Predator. Hear me out:

KAVU PREDATOR
1) Efficient Body, Low Colorweight
2) Grows When Opponent's Life Swings Up
3) Easily Blocked, Unchumpable
4) Combos Off of Your Cards
5) White/Black Bane
6) Seems Bad, Turns Out to Be Great
7) Solid in Any Deck that Can Cast It
8) Discourages Defensive Strategies
9) 2 Power and 2 Toughness

RETALIATOR GRIFFIN
1) Ineffecient Body, High Colorweight
2) Grows When Your Life Swings Down
3) Hard to Block, Chumptastic
4) Combos Off of Their Cards
5) Seems Great, Turns Out to be Bad
6) Only Good in Specially Tuned Decks
7) Discourages Offensive Strategies
8) 2 Toughness and 2 Power

Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you the Odd Couple of Magic the Gathering!

Kathari Bomber-Jund/Grixis-Goblin tokens and unearth

Etherium Abomination-Grixis/Esper-Unearth on an artifact creature

Ethercaste Knight-Esper/Bant-Artifact creature with Exalted

Sigiled Behemoth-Bant/Naya-Exalted on a creature with a power of five

Godtracker of Jund-Naya/Jund-"power 5+" ability, and dragons. I feel Gorger Wurm might have been better (Power of 5 and has devour) but Godtracker's flavor text fits the cycle.

161291: Breath of Malfegor.text_parsed: A really fun thing to do is get two of these and two Quest for Pure Flame's in your hand during a multiplayer game.  Play the QfPFs, and then hit of BoM number one.  Assuming enough players, that should put enough tokens on the Quests (and if not just use other minor burns to make up the difference). 161292: Trace of Abundance.author: Oleander
161292: Trace of Abundance.text_parsed: These colors giving shroud is kinda odd, and it's not the only card in the set to do this, as the Naya Hushblade also gets shroud. I think the shroud is more of a white and green function, however, as there have been white and green cards in the past that have done this, such as Ravnica's green and white hybrid, Privileged Position, Time Spiral's green Aspect of Mongoose, and Shadowmoor's white Greater Auramancy. However, in terms of how well this card is, I personally don't care for it. The shroud seems to do more harm than good, as there isn't too much land destruction going around in everyday play, and there also aren't too many things that can actually target lands at all. The few things that do target lands can tap or untap them, and if I happen to be running one of those items in a deck, it makes sense to untap an enchanted land to get more mana. Fertile Ground is, in my opinion, a much better alternative, as it does the same thing, minus the shroud, with a more flexible mana cost, meaning you can use things like Unbender Tine and even Garruk Wildspeaker to untap the land it happens to be attached to.

161292: Trace of Abundance.author: Donovan_Fabian
161292: Trace of Abundance.text_parsed:
I would mix this card with fertile ground. I don't know why everyone mentions shroud, theres some creature with shroud in every color, its not really a flavor oriented ability. The reason for the shroud on the enchantment is because mtg staff mentioned they wanted to fix the tempo you can lose by enchanting something that gets bounced or destroyed because its 1 card for 2. So they started giving enchantments either better benefits, or ways to keep them in play. Personally I like the shroud, as there are several ways to destroy the land or get rid of an enchantment.

Boomerang, creeping mold, thresher beast, and deus of calamity all come to mind.
161292: Trace of Abundance.text_posted:

So they started giving enchantments either better benefits, or ways to keep them in play.  Personally I like the shroud, as there are several ways to destroy the land or get rid of an enchantment.

Boomerang, creeping mold, thresher beast, and deus of calamity all come to mind.

161292: Trace of Abundance.author: PurpGuy
161292: Trace of Abundance.text_parsed:
Arguably as good as Harrow.

T1: Forest, Birds.
T2: Forest, Harrow. Leaves you with 2 available mana, and 4 going in to T3

T2: Forest, Trace of Abundance. Leaves you with 2 available mana, and 4 going in to T3

Harrow thins (and screws you on counterspell), Trace doesn't thin. In a long game, Trace would leave you with more available mana since it's not killing lands.

Harrow if you have a fast aggressive deck, Trace if it's not so fast.

175109: Identity Crisis.author: Chamale
175109: Identity Crisis.text_parsed:
The earlier this is played, the better, at least against most opponents. It's not that hard to get out by turn 3 in the right deck - for example:

Turn 1 Plains
Turn 2 Swamp, Marble Diamond
Turn 3 Swamp, Dark Ritual, Identity Crisis.

Or:

Turn 1 Forest, Search for Tomorrow
Turn 2 Swamp,
Turn 3 Search library for Plains and put it into play, play another Plains, Dark Ritual, Identity Crisis

If you manage to mana-ramp to this quickly enough, it's the end of the game against most decks. However, this is not a card to simply toss into any white-black deck. Be careful.

4/5 because it's only useful in a deck that's quite set up for it.

175109: Identity Crisis.author: Wulfsten
175109: Identity Crisis.text_parsed:
Beautifully balanced card. The effect, while initially seemingly devastating, grows less and less relevant as the game goes on. The casting cost presents a challenge to deckbuilders: how to get this card on the table while the opponent's hand is still fat enough to make this card worth it? By way of comparison, its CMC is twice that of Mind Rot, although this card does exile the graveyard as well.

Still, I wouldn't feel like I got my money's worth unless the opponent discarded at least three cards and was damaged by the loss of his graveyard in some way.

175109: Identity Crisis.author: DarthParallax
175109: Identity Crisis.text_parsed:
This is farily costed. Yes, technically its Magic and everything might as well cost 0 'in the right deck', but 6CMC in Enemy Colors is nothing sneeze at, and more difficult to cheat out, than say, Phyrexian Om Nom Nommer. (Obliterator)

Turn 1-3ing this is just dorky. Please don't, that's mean.
Finding a nice quick way to shave off a mana or two like Everflowing Chalice, and this is a complete bomb on turn 4-5.
If you're Joe Lucky and play with only basic lands, but actually hit Plains, Swamp, Plains, Swamp, Plains, Swamp as your first six land drops, then this is still a completely valid card to play. I wouldn't run more than 3 in a deck though.

It comes down to mana. There isn't a single player who'd say the effect is somehow bad. Its not Cruel Ultimatum, but its very fine indeed. Speaking of Cruel Ultimatum, playing this either before, after, or on the same turn as Cruel Ultimatum...

is a GREAT way to lose a friend forever. works every time xD

175109: Identity Crisis.author: TheGoodDoctor20
175109: Identity Crisis.text_parsed:
So this is made for a card game, right? Such that I and my opponent should be having fun while playing it, right?

When I see this I imagine a deck where my opponent spams Path to Exile and Doomblade culminate into a turn 5 or 6 fatty and this thing. Truly there is nothing for me to do but pray I can out aggro the relentless torrent of instant speed, low cost removal spells before this bomb smacks me in the face.

Similar problems exist with the current standard grixis control meta (Innistrad, first set). Galvanic Blast, Go for the Throat, and the number of counter spells in type hold the line for a Chandra, The Firebrand and Sorrin's Vengeance auto kill turn 7 and a very boring match.

175256: Reborn Hope.author: DacenOctavio
175256: Reborn Hope.text_parsed:
Regrowthing something is very useful. It really depends on what you're regrowing.

Eternal Witness is a powerful tool. The ability to blink it or recur it generates serious card advantage.

Nature's Spiral is ok, but can't get back instants or sorceries. If your deck has a lot of great permanents that are a lightning rod for removal or counterspells, this is still very useful.

Reclaim is cheaper, but you skip a draw step. Noxious Revival is similar, can be cast for free, and can mess up an opponent's draw step.

I just did a Gatherer search, and there are 487 multicolored Modern-Legal cards that are green or white. Progenitus is the only one on the list that can't be used with this card :P

This is the ultimate sideboard card for a deck playing Glittering Wishes, and therefore NOT strictly worse than Regrowth, which is not retrievable with Glittering Wish. All the same, don't let it lull you into a false sense of security. Your graveyard is still vulnerable, and it's still an extra 2 for that second copy, so think twice before only leaving yourself one Qasali Pridemage on that sideboard.

It's so perfect for this one purpose, you'd think it was made with that in mind.
5/5 for this reason alone.

176449: Terminate.author: Grimn777
176449: Terminate.text_parsed: Well, nothing much to say but amazing card. Path to exile, while it does cost less, is horrible early game card. the cost difference means next to nothing in the mid-late game, where path should be used anyway. If you path turn 1 or 2, you are giving the opponent a huge mana acceleration... not wise. Both have built in no-regeneration. Terminate sends to the graveyard, which can be more useful (for haunting echoes etc.) or less useful (if they have unearth/persist) depending. Then again, how can you compare cards in completely different colors? Different play styles, different uses. So although you may think that path to exile is better spot removal, which would you run in a B/R deck? Exactly. 5/5

176449: Terminate.author: achilleselbow
176449: Terminate.text_parsed: I kind of wish they hadn't printed this card back in Planeshift. It is basically the main reason that on the comments page for any creature there are about a hundred idiots going "IT DIES TO REMOVAL". Obviously there was tons of removal before, but it was balanced. In the old days the only spot removal options were black, white, and red burn. Each had its own drawback: black couldn't deal with black creatures, white was either situational like Exile or helped your opponent like Swords to Plowshares, and red of course couldn't deal with huge creatures or regenerators. Creatures would actually stay out for more than one turn and maybe even get an attack or two in. Imagine that. And if you had a black creature with protection from white like Ihsan's Shade, you were basically set. Nowadays nearly every color combination has unconditional or almost unconditional removal, and too many games just turn into a back-and-forth of casting one creature after another only to see it removed the next turn while doing the same to your opponent until one of you runs out of kill spells.

176449: Terminate.author: wstonefi
176449: Terminate.text_parsed:
Every cheap removal spell has a restriction. Doom Blade and Dark Banishing can't hit black creatures, Go for the Throat can't hit artifact creatures, and Terror can't hit either. Terminate can hit any creature... but even it has a restriction, namely the red mana symbol in the cost. Only a handful of decks can run it. This prevents it from going out of control and warping every format ever.

That being said, I still think the card is a bit OP... but what can you do. Wizards printed it, we need to deal with it.

If you're running a red/black deck in any format where Terminate is legal, there is absolutely no reason not to run 4 copies. It's the most efficient spot removal ever printed.

176449: Terminate.author: FlashCaster
176449: Terminate.text_parsed:
Let's get something straight; this isn't the best removal spell ever as some people are saying, it's easily Swords to Plowshares.

Granted they are different in many ways, but comments like "as good as targeted removal gets" and "best removal ever printed ever since ever" are just plain incorrect.

Swords is so good that even if you were playing it in a burn deck the life you give opponent is still worth it considering the versatility of the card.

Take Wurmcoil Engine for example, Terminate will kill it but it is swords that prevents opponent from gaining tokens as a result. Swords just gets it done, especially in really tricky situations where you are staring down a Blightsteel Colossus, etc.

There are so many good creatures like this with "when this creature dies" abilities as well. Swords gets around all of them since it's not actually killing the creature.

Obviously this is true for Path to Exile and other targeted exile as well.

Even considering this I still give Terminate 5/5 since it's way way up there and is an iconic and classic removal spell.

As far as it versus Dreadbore I think in the end the edge goes to Terminate overall. Dreadbore is better Sideboard tech though since it is more versatile.

Granted they are different in many ways, but comments like "as good as targeted removal gets" and "best removal ever printed ever since ever" are just plain incorrect.

Swords is so good that even if you were playing it in a burn deck the life you give opponent is still worth it considering the versatility of the card.

Take [autocard]Wurmcoil Engine[/autocard] for example, Terminate will kill it but it is swords that prevents opponent from gaining tokens as a result. Swords just gets it done, especially in really tricky situations where you are staring down a [autocard]Blightsteel Colossus[/autocard], etc.

There are so many good creatures like this with "when this creature dies" abilities as well. Swords gets around all of them since it's not actually killing the creature.

Obviously this is true for [autocard]Path to Exile[/autocard] and other targeted exile as well.

Even considering this I still give Terminate 5/5 since it's way way up there and is an iconic and classic removal spell. 

As far as it versus [autocard]Dreadbore[/autocard] I think in the end the edge goes to Terminate overall. Dreadbore is better Sideboard tech though since it is more versatile.

177922: Lord of Extinction.author: Gabriel422
177922: Lord of Extinction.text_parsed: It's a creature that's potentially very huge, but it's unreliable in not one way but two; the usual "dies to removal", but also a risk that it will come into play as a 3/3 or smaller. Which can happen often if your deck is slow and you have to cast it turn five or die. This is the explanation I can give as to why I always ended up running Bloodbraid Elves and Broodmate Dragon while this thing got cut. But then, these cards set a high bar, themselves being the best cards in the best deck of the time (Jund).

179406: Blitz Hellion.author: Beastlygreen
179406: Blitz Hellion.text_parsed: A very fun card. A quick 7 damage. I've won a fair share of games when my opponent has either had to waste a spell on this then be unable to answer a better spell, or they thought of stopping the other spell and had this to reckon with.And if they don't waste a spell, they either take a lot of damage and/or lost a creature(s). Either way, you win, not to mention they have the dread of not knowing when it would pop up again! That fear can make them be a bit more conservative, giving you a chance for more aggression. I think it's fun. Imagine it with Mighty Emergence!

179406: Blitz Hellion.author: NoobOfLore
179406: Blitz Hellion.text_parsed:
It's not Ball Lightning, but this one gets past 1/1 first-strikers and lightning bolt, can be reasonably played in a deck that isn't mono-red, and can recur.
Easier cost to pay in multicolor, and your chances of drawing one tend to only increase as the game goes on.

Ball Lightning is more efficient, certainly, but not everyone can be running Ball Lightning, and sometimes you just like your guys huge.

179409: Soulquake.author: Ferlord
179409: Soulquake.text_parsed:
The bouncing from the graveyard can backfire, but that would be the case if you weren't playing this in the proper deck.

Nearly every card has its place. This is a combination of Empty the Catacombs and, more obviously, Evacuation. Add the costs together, and this costs 2 less than playing those two. Not only that, this takes up at least one card slot.

But yes, Liliana's Caress/Megrim + this = pretty ugly business. Throw in Jin-Gitaxias, and the once cooked goose is now a burnt piece of rubble.

It's just about time for some stupid effect like, "this card can't be returned to its players' hand" to pop up. I wouldn't be surprised if one of the new Return to Ravnica guilds' ability is that. Maybe Simic (but let's hope not)

179534: Stormcaller's Boon.author: Oleander
179534: Stormcaller's Boon.text_parsed: I could definitely see this being an instant or sorcery, but as an artifact, probably not. It's all about the flavor of the card, and a boon is like a blessing or a fortune, and such things usually don't come in the tangible, metallic forms of artifice. As for how it is as an enchantment, it's ok, being neither stellar or pitiful. It's definitely got perks because of the cascade, and the fact you can sac it for it's effect at anytime allows you to play it early and get more creatures out that could benefit from it, thus saving you mana as you won't have to play it on a turn where you might need to play a creature or some other spell.

I find it funny that this card is rated a full point lower than Sky Spirit (rounding both ratings quite easily to the nearest tenth of a point, as of 11/9/2011), despite the fact that, were these two creatures to face off without outside influence, this creature would survive while Sky Spirit would find itself in the graveyard. I'll also state that Sky Spirit is preferable to Trooper in various OTHER situations. Neither is 'strictly' better or worse than the other.

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: Apocolypse_Prophet
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_parsed:
From the Alara Reborn FAQ

* Maelstrom Nexus affects the first spell you play each turn, not just the first spell you play on your own turn.

* If the first spell you play in a turn already has cascade, both cascade abilities will trigger separately. Deal with them one at a time: First one cascade ability will resolve, and you'll play the applicable card if you want. That new spell will resolve. Then the other cascade ability will resolve in the same way. Finally, the original spell will resolve.

* This effect takes into account spells that were played earlier in the turn that Maelstrom Nexus came into play, including any spells still on the stack. If you've already played any spells that turn (including Maelstrom Nexus itself), this ability won't give any of your spells cascade that turn.

* A spell's converted mana cost is determined solely by the mana symbols printed in its upper right corner. If its mana cost includes {X}, take the chosen value of X into account. Ignore any alternative costs, additional costs, cost increases, or cost reductions.

Yes a card with cascade already will trigger twice. Malstrom Nexus can't give itself cascade. It has to be in play to grant the ability. The ability triggers "when you play a spell". By the time it gets in to play it is too late to give itself cascade.

This card is crap... even if this isn't obvious at the first glance.

Cascade ruins the 'typical' way to play, because you can't use cards you don't want to be revealed. Usually this means most decks will focus on a few combo cards.

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: The_Somnambulist
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_parsed:
Multiple copies of this card CAN be brutal, I just proxied a couple of these in my deck to see how it'd work.....simply amazing, if cascade can stack onto a spell already with cascade, logically you should be able to stack cascade onto a spell even w/o cascade by using multiple triggers of Maelstrom Nexus.....I think this card can accelerate any deck that can use this card.

@ Uril: I found the rulings for Cascade in the Comprehensive Rules, check this out:
* If you play a spell with cascade and there are no nonland cards in your library with a converted mana cost that's less that that spell's converted mana cost, you'll remove your entire library from the game. Then you'll randomly rearrange those cards and put them back as your library. Although you're essentially shuffling those cards, you're not technically doing so; abilities that trigger whenever you shuffle your library won't trigger.

So it's what I thought, like other cards where multiple things happen with one spell that parts can be ignored, it seems to be true as well with Cascade. The best part is that you won't lose by deck out either.
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_posted:
Multiple copies of this card CAN be brutal, I just proxied a couple of these in my deck to see how it'd work.....simply amazing, if cascade can stack onto a spell already with cascade, logically you should be able to stack cascade onto a spell even w/o cascade by using multiple triggers of Maelstrom Nexus.....I think this card can accelerate any deck that can use this card.

@ Uril: I found the rulings for Cascade in the Comprehensive Rules, check this out:
* If you play a spell with cascade and there are no nonland cards in your library with a converted mana cost that's less that that spell's converted mana cost, you'll remove your entire library from the game. Then you'll randomly rearrange those cards and put them back as your library. Although you're essentially shuffling those cards, you're not technically doing so; abilities that trigger whenever you shuffle your library won't trigger.

So it's what I thought, like other cards where multiple things happen with one spell that parts can be ignored, it seems to be true as well with Cascade. The best part is that you won't lose by deck out either.

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: JaxsonBateman
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_parsed:
As has been mentioned, multiple instances of cascade trigger separately.

Say that the stack is empty, and you cast an Enlisted Worm with a Maelstrom Nexus out, and it's your first spell of the turn. The stack would look like this, with the lowest number (1) representing the bottom, and the highest number representing the top:

1. Enlisted Worm
2. Worm Cascade
3. Maelstrom Cascade

To make it really wonky, lets say Maelstrom cascades into a Bloodbraid, which cascades into a Blightning.

1. Enlisted Worm
2. Worm Cascade
3. Bloodbraid Elf
4. Bloodbraid Elf Cascade => Blightning

Players pass priority, Blightning resolves, pass again, then BBE resolves. Pass again, then we deal with the Worm Cascade.

1. Enlisted Worm
2. Deny Reality
3. Deny Reality Cascade => Esper Charm

Players pass priority, Esper Charm resolves, pass again, Deny Reality resolves. Then upon passing again Enlisted Worm finally resolves.

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: OmegaSerris

@Kablooie
"Each Spell" would have been broken to high heaven. They would have had to make this cost something like to get away with that. You understand, that means each spell you cascade into ALSO gets cascade. You know these chains people are posting? You would automatically get that, EVERYTIME.

Now, "Each Spell cast from your hand" might have been more appropriate. You also have to understand, as it is now, you can also cascade on your opponent's turn with any instant/flash. It also stacks with spells that already have cascade, giving you two triggers. So I think it is pretty good as it is.

@PhyrexianAdvocate
It specifically states in the Comprehensive Rules at 279.25h that "that player chooses one opponent. This opponent then holds the player down while each opponent gets ONE (1) free kick to the balls. No players receive priority during this and this cannot be countered by spells or abilities."

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_parsed:
@Toren_Megoa & Fanaticmogg: I'm not so sure the answer is no.

If you cast a spell with Storm, that spell by itself, if it was the first one you cast this turn, gets Cascade, of course.

Then Storm states: When you cast this spell, copy it for each spell cast before it this turn. You may choose new targets for the copies.

The copies, to my knowledge, are exact copies of the spell with Storm. Since that spell now has the text: "Do something. Storm Cascade", the copies should copy the Cascade ability, even though Maelstrom Nexus did not grant them Cascade (since, yes, they are not cast).
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_posted:

The copies, to my knowledge, are exact copies of the spell with Storm. Since that spell now has the text: "Do something. Storm Cascade", the copies should copy the Cascade ability, even though Maelstrom Nexus did not grant them Cascade (since, yes, they are not cast).

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: Kablooie
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_parsed:
This card really falls short of being awesome. As the typical card that shows of the set's main mechanic, it should have really given the feeling of "cascade". The card would've been better if it was just "Each spell you cast has cascade." It probably still would be too weak and inconsistent to make a splash in competitive magic anyways.

Have you ever played Bituminous Blast and cascaded into Bloodbraid Elf and then into Blightning? Power level issues aside, that sequence really feels like a cascade. Going down just once from a high-casting card does NOT feel like a cascade at all. The word "cascade" should describe multiple little sequential drops.

How cool would it be if you could start with a Maelstrom Nexus and a CMC nine card and work your way all the way down to a 1 drop or zero drop? That would be wicked cool.

Too bad though :/.

Edit:
@OmegaSerris - I realize the implications of that tweak. A 5 color enchantment that still does nothing by itself is broken to high heaven? Giving this card an upgrade that might give you one extra spell wouldn't even make this constructed playable, but it would create a more elegant and awesome card.

179540: Maelstrom Nexus.author: Keiya
179540: Maelstrom Nexus.text_parsed:
With four copies of this card, since multiple copies stack, Maelstrom Wanderer essentially reads:

Cascade, cascade, cascade, cascade, cascade, cascade (When you cast this spell, exile cards from the top of your library until you exile a nonland card that costs less. You may cast it without paying its mana cost. Put the exiled cards on the bottom in a random order. Then do it again. And again. And again. And again. And again.)

Seems like it would be almost impossible to set up, but it would be ridiculously fun and lulzy to do.

179544: Double Negative.author: Grimn777
179544: Double Negative.text_parsed:
"as already mentioned, the functionality isn't too useful"... remember, english is our friend. it allows us to communicate. let's break this one down. "as already mentioned". unless this is followed up with a yoda-style phrase, like "as already mentioned, it was", this is incomprehensible. needing a "was", or reconfiguring. "the functionality isn't too useful". while grammatically correct, rather inane. functionality is not the same as function. functionality is a concept, not unlike happiness, or peace, that is a noun, yet is not an attribute of the card nor is it an object. "the (object) isn't too useful" makes complete sense. however, this fails when the object becomes indefinite. for example, "the happiness isn't too useful". the "the" in the sentence refers to a specific, and the noun is by nature obscure and indefinite. As we can see, incorrect.

Besides those issues, you are basically saying that the function of the card isn't useful. the card only does one thing, and if that one thing isn't useful, you must not be looking for that kind of effect. It would be unfair for me to declare ancestral recall not too useful because I wasn't looking for card drawing. In fact, if you were declaring that the countering of two spells is largely irrelevant, I don't think you quite understand the concept of CASCADE. I admit, Cancel is a mediocre counter spell. However, in the right colors (red blue), playing a cancel that hits 2 spells is ridiculous. very useful card.

And remember, it is always easier to get your point across if you use intelligent english.

I do not believe many of you are realizing the full utility of this card. It's more than justified, as I didn't until more recent times, and I was running them. It's WAY better than just a cancel that hits Cascades. Follow me on an...

ADVENTURE IN DOUBLE NEGATIVES!!!

Setup: Your a red player, right? Sure you are, as to play this your at least playing red blue. So what else you got in there? Lightning Bolt? OF COURSE YOU DO! Searing Flames? Darn tootin'! These are of course, Instants, like so many great red burns. Why does this matter? They go on a stack! In fact, played right, they CREATE A STACK from NOTHING.

Example 1:
Opponent: I play a Hedron Crab.
YOU: In response, I Lightning Bolt you.
Opponent: In response, I Cancel your Lightning Bolt.
YOU: In response, Double Negative, targeting your Hedron Crab and Cancel.

See what happened? We use our Instant in response to an unrelated play to goad a player into burning a reactive card, which we then Double Negative to kill both the unrelated play, and the response to our instant! Let's try again...

Example 2:
Opponent: I play a Wolfbriar Elemental and kick it for 4.
YOU: In response, I Searing Flame that Beast and Garruk Wildspeaker.
Opponent: OK... I Wild Growth the Beast in response.
YOU: In response, a Double Negative the Wild Growth and the Wolfbriar Elemental.

Come and toss your 2 cents in oh Sages of MTG. If I'm wrong, I would love to know. Otherwise, join me fellow Grixis players in the goading of our opponents into losing multiple cards from one Double Negative.

179545: Behemoth Sledge.author: Donovan_Fabian
179545: Behemoth Sledge.text_parsed: Have to look at the good and bad aspects of this card together, not just the omg its awesome posts.  For one thing, it defintley makes one of your creatures big and brawny in a hurry, but it does cost 6 mana or 3 per two turns, either way thats slightly less cost effective especially if its stopping you from playing something from your hand that would have used the mana spent on it.  For example divinity of pride itself only costs 5, and at the full 6 mana you could be playing a flameblast dragon.  The added 2 toughness on this card vs. the loxodon warhammer is a major bonus though, with the new lightning helix and lightning bolt coming back, you need extra toughness on your creatures if you don't want them to die really easily.   The lifelink is also amazing, your doing a lot of damage and getting life back.  The downside is two fold, the first is that with all that mana cost, if the creature you attach it too is removed, the constant moving it to a new creature (if it isn't destroyed by artifact hate) takes up an extra 3 mana a turn.  The second issue is the card is taking the place of something else, and that something else could simply be another creature with lifelink.  Is it better to have an extra creature on the field with lifelink or an equipment that can give lifelink to your other creatures?  That really depends on the deck.

179545: Behemoth Sledge.author: Mister_Tapwater
179545: Behemoth Sledge.text_parsed:
The obvious point of comparison for this card is Armadillo Cloak, since they have the same initial mana cost and the same effect. However, I'd say they are quite different cards both in the way you play them and in terms of which decks they can go into. This is a much worse turn 3 drop for an aggressive deck than the Cloak, since if you play a two drop creature then play cloak on it and attack, they will have to either find a way to deal with your threat or lose. On the other hand, if their turn goes untap, Doom Blade your guy, you're the one on the back foot.

So Cloak has a bigger potential upside, in that it's a full turn faster, but Sledge is repeatable and doesn't risk card disadvantage (although killing the guy you paid three mana to equip is still a significant loss of tempo). On the other hand, this card is probably amazing in long drawn out slogfests, because it turns any creature you draw later into a legitimate threat, and lifelink is one of the best abilities to have if your opponent tries to race.
179545: Behemoth Sledge.text_posted:
The obvious point of comparison for this card is [autocard]Armadillo Cloak[/autocard], since they have the same initial mana cost and the same effect. However, I'd say they are quite different cards both in the way you play them and in terms of which decks they can go into. This is a much worse turn 3 drop for an aggressive deck than the Cloak, since if you play a two drop creature then play cloak on it and attack, they will have to either find a way to deal with your threat or lose. On the other hand, if their turn goes untap, [autocard]Doom Blade[/autocard] your guy, you're the one on the back foot. 

So Cloak has a bigger potential upside, in that it's a full turn faster, but Sledge is repeatable and doesn't risk card disadvantage (although killing the guy you paid three mana to equip is still a significant loss of tempo). On the other hand, this card is probably amazing in long drawn out slogfests, because it turns any creature you draw later into a legitimate threat, and lifelink is one of the best abilities to have if your opponent tries to race.

179547: Meddling Mage.author: BelloAbril
179547: Meddling Mage.text_parsed:
For those who doesn't know, wizards rewarded certain players with their unique card which featured themselves as wizards. From the original four (Meddling Mage, Shadowmage Infiltrator, Sylvan Safekeeper, and Voidmage Prodigy) one didn't get reprinted anymore, 2 got reprinted in timeshift (1 with alternate art, which is fine as stills features the contest winner) and one got reprinted in alara's cycle.

As you can see meddling mage is quite popular and even sees play in eternal format, maybe not as top tier, but sees play. I find unfair that they removed the original art, but well, at least someone uses it and got reprinted, unlike the poor Sylvan safekeeper that didn't even get his tribute in timeshift...

I guess they changed the art because the reprint in TS weren't too popular or something.

179547: Meddling Mage.author: DoctorKenneth
179547: Meddling Mage.text_parsed: Zieg: The effect does not linger, I'm afraid. If you name a card, bounce this, replay it, and name another card, you don't get to negate two cards. Look at a card like Moat. It states, simply, that non-fliers can't attack. When it leaves play, that abilitiy ceases to function- which is good, of course, because otherwise it could shut-down most decks singlehandedly for the entirety of the game. The same holds for cards like Platinum Angel. If it was required to add the qualifier "As long as X remains on the battlefield...", you wouldn't need to protect your angel. As soon as you played it, it would grant you losing immunity, regardless of what happened to it. Now, you're right in that it doesn't end at the end of turn, of course. And bouncing it is useful if, for instance, you shutdown an early removal spell and now you want to defuse an impending bomb in the late game. But only Cloning can two-for-one your card shutdown. Or possibly some other trickery that I'm overlooking.
179547: Meddling Mage.text_posted: Zieg: The effect does not linger, I'm afraid. If you name a card, bounce this, replay it, and name another card, you don't get to negate two cards. 179551: Spellbreaker Behemoth.author: Douchette
179551: Spellbreaker Behemoth.text_parsed: This card is pretty bad. Although the mana cost compared with power/toughness is decent, its effect is absolutely useless. "Uncounterable" doesn't mean "indestructible". In serious pro leagues, no one is going to run more counterspells other than Cryptic Commmands and maybe some Negates. No one is going to waste a Cryptic Command on a creature like this. With no haste, all they have to do is Boomerang, Terror, or Celestial Purge it next turn. The card is meant as a counter against control decks for Naya decks. But 5CC has tons more ways of dealing with creatures like this. Not mentioning Jund or Grixis will take care of this with no trouble. Terminate, Doom blade, Deathmark will suffice. if you are looking for a cheap, big creature for your Naya deck, might as well go for Woolly Thoctar.

179551: Spellbreaker Behemoth.author: Donovan_Fabian
179551: Spellbreaker Behemoth.text_parsed:
Truthfully, I think its the combination of the big power for only 4 mana, and the ability combined that make it worth it. I already have a spearbreaker behemoth, so.. if I play these two together.. hmmm..

Play spellbreaker first to make all my 5+ naya creatures uncounterable, then play spearbreaker a turn or two later for indestructibility to all my 5+ creatures.. woot! I'd play it if for no other reason than the only cards that grant the uncounterable affect are few and far between, and usually sorceries or enchantments like leyline of life force, at least this way I can get a creature out of it too, since green needs creatures on the board to do anything (can't use titanic ultimatum for any good with no creatures to use it on and etc etc).

I'd play it if for no other reason than the only cards that grant the uncounterable affect are few and far between, and usually sorceries or enchantments like leyline of life force, at least this way I can get a creature out of it too, since green needs creatures on the board to do anything (can't use titanic ultimatum for any good with no creatures to use it on and etc etc).

179551: Spellbreaker Behemoth.author: DarthParallax
179551: Spellbreaker Behemoth.text_parsed:
The downside you aren't seeing Keegan is that Green is not in Kaalia's Color Identity. :3 Cavern of Souls only gets you one type, and you probably want to set that type to Human.

Things like this are why the Nephilim Color Identities probably won't ever be on Commanders. It's bad enough that 5-Color Generals exist, but so far those have attracted people trying to build "Omnipotence decks" more that people trying to use just one extra color to get the MOST out of their 'Real' SECRET Commander. Consider a Scion of the Ur-Dragon Deck running Kaalia. Who is the true Commander? 4-Color Commanders are more dangerous to have than 5-Commanders because the only reason you wouldn't bump up to 5 is to be more focused. Rather than eke out every power from the color wheel, a 4-Color Commander probably just wants its 4th Color for a little bit of its deck to massively improve its main 3 colors, where a 5 Color deck wants as much of all the colors as possible :P

But if you just start looking at 2 and 3 color Generals and think to yourself 'what is the fastest, most direct way to break this literally stupidly in half such that it would need to get banned?' the answer is usually to wish for it to have just one extra color. :P

In Kaalia's case, adding either Green or Blue to her deck would be just plain dumb.
In Zur's case, probably Red is more dangerous than Green because you can do lots of spell-cost hacking with his Blue, but the Enchantment synergies between Green and White are scary, too. Oh and Land Ramp of course xP
In Riku's case, if you ever let him get his hands on a Necropotence, you deserve what you get O_O
In Nicol Bolas' case, White would be horrifying for him to have, because that would make him "Kaalia + Blue"

You can play this game with any Gold card- 'what would happen if my favorite Commander could have this card?' and it's a lot like playing the 'what if this cost 1 less mana or had trample?' game. Basically- Because Development Matters xP

Totally worth it.

depends how you look at it, its mill powers are slow and unless you are really digging into milling, he is meh at it
as for a zombie, he still needs work, if you think about it, you will have 3 zombies by turn 4, maybe? so tapping out turn 4 to mill/drain will only be 3 at best and you are unable to play anyone else

all this has been no mana so far btw, now you can use Lich Lord, mill/drain at least 3, more depending on how many you kill with thoctar, and then you can swing with 8/8 thocar, 2/2 death baron and 3/3 lich lord

that is 16 damage total, nice for 4 mana spent over the whole turn, need one more to finish, well should be one more counter on thoctar, pew to the player for win

179555: Lich Lord of Unx.author: totallybast0s
179555: Lich Lord of Unx.text_parsed:
I actually find this card very usefull in my black/blue mill deck. i combine him with the Dire Undercurrents enchantment. those creature tokens are blue/black creatures, so when u tap just 2 mana at the end, or during the opponents turn, they gotta discard a card from their hand and u get to draw a card. result being not only are u milling their deck, you are reducing whatever hand they might be able to play on you.

at the same time, you are pulling out more cards to be able to play on them. its especially funny when your opponent has drained his whole hand, and at the beginning of his turn u tap and pull out a token to make him discard whatever card he JUST drew out.

like was mentioned before, his milling ability is only really great when u use it at the end of the opponent's turn, but think about how great that is of a kicker when u do use it at the end of their turn. combine it with the Unscythe card, and dire undercurrents, its a great card IMO. is it as good at milling as nemesis of reason or drowner initiates? no. but he can provide the damage along with your milling as a backup plan in case your milling just isnt going fast enough. and he also can provide a last minute pinch blocker if you need one and u don't want lich lord to die.

179555: Lich Lord of Unx.author: majinara
179555: Lich Lord of Unx.text_parsed:
Looks like an average to bad card for me.

I mean, at first it's a 2/2 for 3 mana, which by itself is bad (especially since it requires two colors).

Then, you could pay another 4 mana the turn you play him to mill for one, or maybe a bit more. Thats then 7 mana so far for a few cards to mill. Also, of those seven mana, three must be black and three must be blue, which is pretty harsh.

Or you can generate tokens. The first time you generate a token, it took you 5 mana (of which must be two blue and two black) and two turns, to get a 2/2 into play and a 1/1 token, which is bad as well.

So, for him to be actually good, you need tons of mana in exactly the right combination of blue and black (since he hates generic mana), and you need dozens of zombies in play. But if you have dozens of zombies in play, why don't you just attack with them for the win?

The guy is slow, vulnerable and needs tons of mana. He might look good for some, but to me he just looks clunky and overcosted.

179555: Lich Lord of Unx.author: wicked_pick
179555: Lich Lord of Unx.text_parsed:
This guy should not be in an aggro deck.. He would be more useful in a control deck..

He is the only creature card (aside from Fleshbag Marauder) I have on my black/blue zombie control deck..

I just wait for the right moment to cast him, countering spells with Essence Scatter, Negate and other counter spell cards most of the time, if I have 5 mana, I'd go for Mind Funeral, reserving 2 mana for countering spells then Haunting Echoes next turn, or play Lich Lord of Unx right away, reserving 2 mana for countering spells again. As the game progresses the game is in my control and I can finally produce tokens with Lich's, if I have 5 or more tokens its time for loose life and mill.

Just like blue, think before you act, and black, corruption.
- For me he is actually a 4.5 -

179555: Lich Lord of Unx.author: DoctorKenneth
179555: Lich Lord of Unx.text_parsed:
Gatherites seem to be focused on milling. Don't forget you also get life loss in there too. Forget the milling- life loss is what I'm after, here.

Now, zombie tokens aren't produced as quickly and readily as Elves or Saprolings, or even Merfolk. So I can understand why people dislike him- your X value won't usually be high. I think an interesting casual pairing, though, would be with Shepherd of Rot. Gain an early lead in life by letting your foe lose a few to the Lich Lord, then keep firing your Shepherds until he's dead. In the meantime, the Lich holds off aggro a little with his token producing, and coupled with Death Baron, the tokens become all the more dissuasive, with Grave Pact making attacking an even worse idea.

Of course, that's my defence of the card. If you're familiar with my previous comments, vulnerability is not usually a valid point for me. Nor is the argument that a three mana 2/2 is inherently bad (That's on curve for blue and black, friends. Don't let green and white spoil you). I still would not use this card, even with my aforementioned casual pairings. Why? Because blue/black is not a great zombie colour. Options in black/green are much more profitable (Putrid Leech is a wrecking machine alongside the zombie tribal lords), or even black/white (though in this pairing, you'll be leaning on white mostly for some removal and control help). That's not to say this is a bad card. Its just that zombie tribal does not traditionally use blue, and blue support falls short of that found in green and white for our shambling, rotting friends. While I'm sure you could build a decent blue/black zombie deck, you'll find you would be better served in other colours. Value this card for its token production (though Cemetary Reaper may arguably be better, depending on who you ask), value it for its life loss function, but recognize that it's not in a useful colour pairing for a dedicated zombie deck.

179555: Lich Lord of Unx.author: Jannissary
179555: Lich Lord of Unx.text_parsed:
Zombie Wizards, huh?

Not an especially great choice for a milling deck, and a poor leader for a Zombie deck. Generally, if you have enough Zombies that this guy's milling is winning you games, you can afford to just swing with them and avoid putting stuff into their graveyard. If you don't, he's milling 1 for 4 mana.

The definition of a winmore card if I've ever seen one, and one where the community rating truly baffles me.

179556: Qasali Pridemage.author: thaviel
179556: Qasali Pridemage.text_parsed:
Technical Question:
I pay 1 colorless and sacrifice Qasali Pridemage as an activation cost for its ability to destroy a target artifact or enchantment.

Can my opponent prevent the ability from resolving by casting a removal spell on the sacrificed Qasali Pridemage such as, 'Unmake'?

I am thinking no, because my logic is that the Qasali Pridemage's sacrifice resolves immediately and does not go on the stack. In the case that my logic is correct, what happens to the Unmake spell?


ok

so first off costs are paid as soon as you activate your ability. so there is no more pridemage to target with the unmake so it never gets cast.

second if he was still around cuz the card was worded something like "pay 1colorless pridemage destroyes target enchantment then bites it" then yes you could kill it before it goes off because there would be no more pridemage to kill the enchantment .

third if the card said pay 1colorless target enchantment explodes and then they target the pridemage and the pridemage is dead the ability is still on the stack and the enchantment dies anyway.

this has been magic confusion corner with thaviel.

179556: Qasali Pridemage.author: JaxsonBateman
179556: Qasali Pridemage.text_parsed:
@Thaviel:

Thought I'd answer your question/s with some coherence. ^^

First off, sacrificing pridemage is part of the ability's cost, and you can't interrupt costs as they don't use the stack. That's the beauty of instants and abilities that require sacrificing - if they try to destroy it, you can sacrifice it in response and nail an enchantment or artifact. If you try to nail an enchantment or artifact then its already left the field.

Secondly, spells and abilities are independent from their source once they're on the stack. Destroying the source won't prevent the spell or ability, unless it specifically says so. Even an ability like Prodigal Pyromancer (tap, *Prodigal Pyromancer* deals 1 damage to target creature or player) will still work - if the permanent is no longer on the battlefield, its last known information was used (it has no bearing on this, but if it was an ability that did damage equal to Pyromancer's power then it'd use its last power value before it died).

Thirdly, if an ability or spell is multi part (ie. your example of "1: Qasali Pridemage destroys target enchantment or artifact. Sacrifice Qasali Pridemage") and one of those parts can't be completed, the rest still go on as normal. So even if they kill the Pridemage there's nothing to stop the first half of the ability resolving.

Hope this helps.

179556: Qasali Pridemage.author: achilleselbow
179556: Qasali Pridemage.text_parsed: People, stop saying this should be rare or uncommon! It sickens me that people have become so used to the idea that a card's rarity should determine how good it is, or that you can print cards that are strictly and substantially better than other cards with the same cost, with no drawback other than being rare or mythic. Some of the best cards in older sets were commons or uncommons, and rares weren't just strictly better, but situationally better and required more thought to use properly. There is no reason to tie a card's rarity to its quality other than for Wizards to drain more of your money. Cards like Baneslayer Angel and most of the planeswalkers disgust me. Be thankful they're still printing some decent commons - looking at the Zendikar block, I feel like this may soon no longer be the case.

179556: Qasali Pridemage.author: RobotOwl
179556: Qasali Pridemage.text_parsed:
Every time I look at this card I cannot help but think that Wizards originally planned on it being two separate creatures. One with Exalted and the other with the artifact/enchantment destruction. Especially since it is a common.

One cannot ask for more utility in a single creature. Creatures with similar levels of utility usually rely on some other source to make it good. For example, Deathrite Shaman needs the graveyard or it is just a 1/2, and Stoneforge Mystic is only as good as the equipment it gets. Also note that these cards are rares.

Of course I am not saying that Qasali Pridemage is better than these two, but my point is that this card is good by itself. It attacks as Watchwolf and is constantly threatening any of your opponents artifacts or enchantments. It is pretty much required as a 1 or 2 of in any GW deck, especially with Green Sun's Zenith.

5/5 for being an awesome card but still far from broken.

One cannot ask for more utility in a single creature.  Creatures with similar levels of utility usually rely on some other source to make it good.  For example, [autocard]Deathrite Shaman[/autocard] needs the graveyard or it is just a 1/2, and [autocard]Stoneforge Mystic[/autocard] is only as good as the equipment it gets.  Also note that these cards are rares.

Of course I am not saying that [autocard]Qasali Pridemage[/autocard] is better than these two, but my point is that this card is good by itself.  It attacks as [autocard]Watchwolf[/autocard] and is constantly threatening any of your opponents artifacts or enchantments.  It is pretty much required as a 1 or 2 of in any GW deck, especially with [autocard]Green Sun's Zenith[/autocard].

5/5 for being an awesome card but still far from broken.

179560: Sigil Captain.author: ICEFANG13
179560: Sigil Captain.text_parsed:
@ Hokeymon yes it is true what your logic is based off of. I agree when I first read it (and other cards like it) adding a +1/+1 counter would not remove a -1/-1 counter. However in the rules, which I looked up to clear up my confusion, it specifically states that the addition of a +1/+1 counter to a -1/-1 counter will cancel them both out making it a +0/+0 (or in Sigiled Captains case a +1/+1 since it adds two). See rule 120.2 in the rules http://www.wizards.com/magic/comprules/MagicCompRules_20091005.txt

@ hunterewell It won't add any counters Sigil Captain triggered ability checks twice, if a Goblin comes into play with Goblin Chieftain in play the ability sees that the Goblin is a 1/1 and when it tries to resolve the Goblin is constantly a 2/2 so it won't work. It would work if that Goblin was a 0/0 because of Engineered Plague because it enters play as a 1/1.

As far as cards go every time I see this guy I think of Mycoloth. Which has the same cost of a similar color idea, two greens to two whites. While Mycoloth is definitely a green green white card, this guy is really white white green and insanely good in a green white solider tribal deck many soldiers are 1/1's and get extra bonuses. And of course good with 2/2's with persist.

179561: Gorger Wurm.author: IncrediSteve
179561: Gorger Wurm.text_parsed:
At worst, this guy is a 5/5 for cmc5, which as others have stated is not bad under any circumstance. The RG manacost is by no means intensive; if you're up to 5 mana without one of those two colors in a RG or Jund deck you're already losing horribly anyway .

Secondly, Devour 1 isn't anything special, but unlike all the other Devour creatures, this guy doesn't need to devour anything to be big. His big already, with the pleasant option of making him bigger should you have a creature that's been hit with pacifism or a Sprouting Thrinax you need to pop so that the fancier devour creatures have some saprolings to dine on.

Also, props for the brutal artwork. This guy goes into my non-tournament decks without a second thought, and is one of the last cuts when I do take Jund out to the serious grounds.

179567: Mage Slayer.author: The_Somnambulist
179567: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
I am actually thinking about making this and Kresh the Bloodbraided as part of my strategy in a spectrum deck I'm trying to work on. I'm going to maybe work 3 of each and 3 Malfegor and 2 Thraximundar. I'm thinking if you can use Malfegor to boost either Kresh or Thraximundar and give them a Mage Slayer, then you don't have to worry at all about them being chump blocked to deal their dmg.

Kresh can get potentially alot bigger than Thraximundar after using Malfegor, though Kresh doesn't have haste and could get killed by the time summoning sickness wears off, where the other can swing immediately after, so either one could be a great threat. I'll try to run multiple copies of each so that it'd take multiple players or alot of removal from one opponent just to stop the combo from working out. Even if they did stop it, Malfegor had already wiped out most or all of their creatures anyway, clearing the way for other attacks.

179567: Mage Slayer.author: Kenji18
179567: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
The best part about this card is that it lets you deal damage to a player with a fat creature that doesn't have the evasions to land the hit on its own. Awesome creatures like Plated Slagwurm and Gloryscale Viashino just made a new best friend.

It might actually work well with Heartlash Cinder, too. I always thought he was cool, but he isn't big enough early-game when he can actually hit. The Mage Slayer just might make him effective late game, too. Oh, and if someone wants to try out Heartlash Cinder with Impelled Giant, let me know how that turns out.

The Mage Slayer just might make him effective late game, too.  Oh, and if someone wants to try out Heartlash Cinder with [autocard]Impelled Giant[/autocard], let me know how that turns out.

179567: Mage Slayer.author: smb379
179567: Mage Slayer.text_parsed:
So, I have a question, that I can't seem to find the answer to anywhere else. During one of my games, I had a 20/23 (or some such power... it was at least 20) Forgotten Ancient. I had equipped him with Mage Slayer and declared him as an attacker. The opponent I was attacking had 20 life, and responded by using Unsummon on my creature.

The game consisted of multiple players, and I'm 100% positive that he would not have used Unsummon if I had attacked another player. So, since the Unsummon was a response to me attacking, would Mage Slayer's effect have triggered (since the creature was attacking) therefore killing my opponent before Unsummon resolved?

I didn't really think about it at the time, so we just went with the fact that my creature was unsummoned, and therefore did no damage. But when I was reading about how the ability triggers during the declare attackers step, I wondered if I would've taken out that player.

Anyway, thanks for your help and responses. :)

179568: Intimidation Bolt.author: Ragamander
179568: Intimidation Bolt.text_parsed:
This card is surprisingly underplayed at the moment for how good it is. As in, it's a great card, and I have NEVER seen it played. Not only does it potentially kill a creature (say, a pesky Wild Nacatl) but it prevents all of your opponent's other creatures from beating you in the face (a problem considering the rising popularity of Naya decks). If the target does die, your opponent can't attack at all. You can also target your own creature on your opponent's turn to prevent all attacks.

I suspect this will see more play in sideboards as one of the only ways to stop the Annihilator 6 ability (not to mention the 15-power attack) of Emrakul, the Aeons Torn once Rise of the Eldrazi comes out.

179568: Intimidation Bolt.author: SilentOppressor
179568: Intimidation Bolt.text_parsed:
@DoragonShinzui

As we approach the enemy planeswalker, the others seem to hesitate. I do not blame them. Already the 'walker had taken out half of our forces, and I could now see he was poised to strike again. Even I had to take a step back as I realized the mage had already begun casting a spell, causing the clouds above us to grow darker. The fools behind me fled, leaving me as the sole target for the 'walker. In a moment, my entire body shook violently, knocking me to the ground. As I struggled to stand, I heard the others fleeing in panic. None of them would deal with the 'walker today. But I knew. The mage had spent too much energy on the spell, and his frightened face told me he had no further tricks. I had an opening. I might not get another. I charged.

179573: Etherium Abomination.author: DacenOctavio
179573: Etherium Abomination.text_parsed: Best played with Etherium Sculptors to cheapen the cost. In an esper deck, it's not that hard to get this out for only 2 mana, at which point it's not a bad card. Also, although there's better things you could transmute, Master Transmuter can make it essentially cost 0 mana, if you run Spellbook. Ugly on its own, much more attractive with help from its buddies. And after it dies, the unearth cost isn't that bad. Remember, artifacts work best as components of strategies, not as standalone tactics.

179573: Etherium Abomination.author: DaLucaray
179573: Etherium Abomination.text_parsed:
Part of a cycle of two-shard creatures. List cuz I'm cool like that.

Kathari Bomber-Jund/Grixis-Goblin tokens and unearth

Etherium Abomination-Grixis/Esper-Unearth on an artifact creature

Ethercaste Knight-Esper/Bant-Artifact creature with Exalted

Sigiled Behemoth-Bant/Naya-Exalted on a creature with a power of five

Godtracker of Jund-Naya/Jund-"power 5+" ability, and dragons. I feel Gorger Wurm might have been better (Power of 5 and has devour) but Godtracker's flavor text fits the cycle.

179578: Ethersworn Shieldmage.author: Cheza
179578: Ethersworn Shieldmage.text_parsed:
This is like a Forfend or Sivvi's Ruse on sticks.

It's quite well balanced, but I don't like the "new way" of making instants useless by printing creatures with flash and CIP effects instead. A vanilla 2/2 is often just a short-time annoyance... not a real threat nbut a blocker. This is clearly in favor of limited drafts but feels so ugly during the normal constructed play.

Creatures with flash have some serious problems. Usually, you won't have the mana free if you need the effect and if you leave 3 mana unused to be prepared, you might lose a lot of speed. It won't protect your Esper creatures from cards like Firespout, because your deck is already quite slow and you either focus on flash + instants or you should focus on normal creatures instead

For me, it's a waste of a free card-slot I might have.... I wouldn't use it in any deck.
I would have preferred a sacrifice effect instead.

179578: Ethersworn Shieldmage.author: Lestat13
179578: Ethersworn Shieldmage.text_parsed:
Shieldmage punishes aggro decks whist playing Esper Beatdown. It really gets the value out of Sculler, Cannonist if you run it main, or SB, and even Court Homunculus as bears you don't want to march straight into 3/3 haste witherers, and 4/4 pay two life beat sticks - Once played creates a deadly weenie wall that they didn't know was there.

Also because of Sculler you can spot a Volcanic Fallout, or just prepare for one, and make it a one sided sweep instead.

Shieldmage might not be for your deck, or that aggro artifact deck, or SB in Affinity, but it defiantly is a very important spell in Esper Beatdown.

179580: Nulltread Gargantuan.author: TrueBloodWolf
179580: Nulltread Gargantuan.text_parsed:
It's draw back isn't as bad of a draw back as one might think. It s a 5/6 beater on turn 3, and can get back summon trigger cards easily. Something like this could happen on the first few turns.

Turn 1: Islands > Ponder /or/ Halimar Depths
Layout: Do whatever with the other two, make sure THIS card is two or more cards from the top. If you play with Option 2, make sure he is the third card down, underneath a Land card.

Turn 2 Option 1: Forest > Wood Sage
Layout: Tap Island and Forest for , then play Wood Sage. Declare the name "Nulltread Gargantuan" and place him onto the field, return Wood Sage to the top of the deck.

Turn 2: Option 2: Forest > Coiling Oracle
Layout: Tap Island and Forest for , then play Coiling Oracle. Put the Land onto the battlefield (because you chose to put the land there).

Turn 3: Play This card and target Coiling Oracle.


This is a nice trigger refresh ability for GREAT attacking skill.

179584: Mask of Riddles.author: Donovan_Fabian
179584: Mask of Riddles.text_parsed: Its effectivley a curiosity with the unblockable part bult in.  I like this card because I play sphinxes, and well, its built for sphinxes.  Both sharding sphinx and ambassador sphinx love this card, and so does a lorescale coatl.  If you care about nothing but the card draw, might play curiosity instead.  It's defintley an impressive equipment, because it can effectivley replace a divination, and potentially gives more card draw over the course of the game by turning all your creatures into shadowmage infiltrators (or even better if you are using something like a cold eyed selkie or overbeing of myth in the same deck).  The only major downside to the mask is, of course, it has to be attached to something.  It's useless without other creatures in play.

179584: Mask of Riddles.author: Ferlord
179584: Mask of Riddles.text_parsed:
Honestly, I think Fear on an equipment is much better than Intimidate.

Intimidate is always different, depending on what creature you put it on. Sure, it can become pseudo-unblockable if put on an artifact creature, but becomes nearly useless when put on something like... oh, let's say Sharuum (why would I mention a creature from the same block in the same colours as this card? NOT A CLUE. ART DOESN'T SUGGEST ANYTHING EITHER).

But with Fear, it's always "Black and Artifacts can block".

It's an absolute, and Black always deals with absolutes.

179585: Marisi's Twinclaws.author: Donovan_Fabian
179585: Marisi's Twinclaws.text_parsed: Technically, you have to consider both sides of what it is and can do.. for one thing your not likely to be able to play a behemoth sledge on this easily, as it takes 6 mana to put out and attach in one turn, unless your willing to leave it on the field first before attaching it, and that 6 mana could just as easily provide you with another big creature instead.  The twin claws are a 4 cmc creature with a 2/4 double strike, where as a thoctar is a 5/4 for 3 cmc in the same colors, so I'd have to say thoctar wins here.  I'd rather have a thoctar on the field, and enchant it with a runes of the deus, than try to get marisi twin claws in play, keep it alive, then fish out a behemoth sledge and have to play it for 6, after which it's still vulnerable to removal.

179587: Drastic Revelation.author: Hayw00d0909
179587: Drastic Revelation.text_parsed:
I love it. to basically draw FOUR cards and mill yourself for three on turn five. Card advantage with a twist. Getting all three colors by turn five shouldn't be much of a problem as long as you have a good landbase, and by turn five your hand needs refilling so the "Discard your hand" clause seems irrelevant.

As far as the "discard three cards at random" part... why anyone would really fret over three cards going to the graveyard (especially in a grixis deck of all things) is beyond me. Lets face it - if losing three cards totally breaks your strategy, you were probably doomed to begin with.

It goes without saying that this targets casual game tables over professional ones, but its things like this that made me fall in love with magic and the color black. It's always a bit of a gamble, and in the right deck its setback can be benefitted from providing your graveyard doesn't mind being full. Would have been nice if it were "Demon themed" to fit the flavor of it's "all or nothing" mechanic.

Overall, I'd say the pros far outweigh the cons when it comes to getting nice late-game card advantage like this. Getting all hung up on the minor setbacks makes you forget how important that can be. Play like you got a pair, and be rewarded. 5/5 for casual :)

It goes without saying that this targets casual game tables over professional ones, but its things like this that made me fall in love with magic and the color black. Overall, I'd say the pros far outweigh the cons when it comes to getting nice late-game card advantage like this. Getting all hung up on the minor setbacks makes you forget how important that can be. Play like you got a pair, and be rewarded. [b]5/5 for casual :)[/b]

179587: Drastic Revelation.author: Enelysios
179587: Drastic Revelation.text_parsed:
I agree with people saying this is great in casual. I think nemokara hit the nail on the head. Why would anyone care about the random discard? Might as well be "Discard your hand, put the top three cards of your library into your graveyard and draw four cards" This is card advantage. (Unless you for some reason insist on playing this with a full hand) I assume the discard is there because this came in a set where black red and blue played the reanimation game and this could fill your graveyard AND hand.

The only time this would be worse than that would be against megrim or underworld dreams decks, but any card that triggers on draw would make this BETTER. I think this card is maybe even my favorite in the set. It might not be overly powerful, but it's fun and flavorful!

179589: Stun Sniper.author: Internet_decks_lame
179589: Stun Sniper.text_parsed:
Icy & damage... not much to complain about here... I think we got lucky the activation is only 1.

Although if the activation becomes a problem you could run Thundersong Trumpeter which has higher power and may suit a faster paced deck... but with either card you are able to create somewhat of the same effect, whether ur looking to remove a blocker or null an attacker. But tapping the creature can add up to nullify a second blocker. And adding 1 point can pick off key component creatures that accelerate control decks like: Noble Hierarch, Birds of Paradise, Dark Confidant, and plenty of other new 1 body toughness rares that are finding there way into the MtG world.

5/5

179590: Wildfield Borderpost.author: kiseki
179590: Wildfield Borderpost.text_parsed: the Border Posts are pretty bad.  You have to ask yourself why you are using them.  If you are planning on hard casting, then you should use darksteel ingot.  If you are planning on land bounching, then all manner of lands are better.  You should be getting something that doesn't always come into play tapped, or has some other ability.  If you are looking for land bouncing, the ravinaca lands are better.  Those can bounce themselves every turn.  If you are looking for flexibility, congrats, you got the mediocrity that comes with it.

179591: Magefire Wings.author: AngelPhoenix
179591: Magefire Wings.text_parsed:
Holy crap this card is WAAAAAY underrated, I really don't understand. I've won many games on the...wings..of this card. Seriously. Okay maybe in a professional atmosphere there are better things you can play for two mana, but that's overly general.

This combos fantastically with many other similarly colored cards in the set, namely Fire-Field Orge, Kederekt Creeper, Shambling Remains, Vedalken Ghoul, hell I've even stuck one on my Sedraxis Specter to make him beef.

But my favorite combo is with Grixis Grimblade. The power of this combo really takes people by suprise. Turn 2, Grimblade, Turn 3, Magefire, and a 5/2 flying deathtouch creature attaks. Turn 3. It's serious.

This card on it's own is nothing special but like most good cards in magic, it's how well they combo that tells you how good they really are.

179592: Vectis Dominator.author: Bluefenix
179592: Vectis Dominator.text_parsed:
It's a good ability for a common. Say someone has you on the edge and they are at 3-6 life, all you have is this guy, 7 lands, and a hand full of nothing that will help. He attacks you for the game win, and you activate this mofo. You're tapping your only defender with 6 land to spare, unless your pokerface sucks, your opponent will probably fall for the bluff and tap their creature.

It's deciding moments like this that these "choice" cards are made for. They are bluffing cards, essentially.

179596: Illusory Demon.author: Blackworm_Bloodworm
179596: Illusory Demon.text_parsed:
The drawback may look harsh, (and it is) but this guy has single-handedly beaten my opponent on many occasions. Mainly because they didn't have a way to deal with flying; and he does hit hard and fast for a creature.

Just remember to cast/summon as many things as you can before turn 3 when you summon him. I had a Briarberry Cohort swinging alongside him and an Oona's Gatewarden on the defensive.

Also, if you absolutely must cast something, make sure you kill him off in combat (preferably trading w/ an opponent's creature at the most) so that he doesn't go to waste.

179596: Illusory Demon.author: blurrymadness
179596: Illusory Demon.text_parsed:
A- Use him with abilties. Guildmages work well, as do spellshapers. You get to "keep casting" without doing so. These are also often high-value cards because of the inherent card-advantage or tempo advantage they can give.

B- Use him with Ninjitsu. He's big for his cost and he's evasive. You either get card advantage from their blockers or you drop the ninja of your choice on their skull when 4 damage isn't enough or you need to cast some spells.

C- Use him with cycling; especially cycling cards that give you side benefits such as Complicate, Decree of Silence, Death Pulse

D- Stop being a pansy. You played Hell's Thunder and thought it was awesome right? Well this guy gets to stick around if you want. Use him as a slow burn spell that might just attract removal and them off him when you have something worth casting. Don't strangle yourself, just remember that getting 4-8 damage out of a single spell is awesome.


He's really a 4/5 in my book. Easy to work around in a proper deck, powerful for the cost.
