179597: Architects of Will.author: Enchantment_Removal
179597: Architects of Will.text_parsed:
I used to think that Wizards tries to keep some cards from being broken.

No, that is not it. I now admit- they make bad cards. . . and give them good artwork. They should go back to making cards of a more equal power level and letting the players determine which are good and bad. I mean relative to present day, in which it is clear what to play and what not to play (in terms of winning). Only someone who had only been in the game for three days would need to sit and ponder for a little while what cards to use and what not to use.

179599: Mind Funeral.author: Ritius
179599: Mind Funeral.text_parsed: I'm surprised no one has mentioned it... this card was born to be Cascaded into: Kathari Remnant and Deny Reality are your best friends with this card. It seems a little reckless, but having this as the only three to cast card, and Kathari as the only four to cast card, and no other lower CMC cards in your deck than 5 will means you will score this every time you cascade, so 12 chances in your library to get it. And since each one removes 4 lands, totaling to 16, plus the four or five your opponent is likely to have already dropped, you probably win. Supplement with higher CMC control and lands that function as creatures like Spawning Pool, and you've got a competitive deck.

179599: Mind Funeral.author: Guest513736147
179599: Mind Funeral.text_parsed:
I haven't seen any rock-solid math for this card on here yet, so I programmed a simple simulation to see how many cards on average this spell would mill. I used a deck size of 60 cards, casting this spell after the opponent had drawn their starting hand of 7, plus 3 cards, which seems reasonable given that this is a 3-mana spell. I varied the lands between 19 (hyper-aggressive) and 26 (hyper-control) to show the effectiveness spectrum. The simulation was run one million times for each scenario. Here we go:

Average cards milled from deck with 19 land cards: 12.2
Average cards milled from deck with 20 land cards: 11.62
Average cards milled from deck with 21 land cards: 11.09
Average cards milled from deck with 22 land cards: 10.61
Average cards milled from deck with 23 land cards: 10.17
Average cards milled from deck with 24 land cards: 9.76
Average cards milled from deck with 25 land cards: 9.38
Average cards milled from deck with 26 land cards: 9.04

We can conclude from these results that this card is more effective against decks light on lands (obviously), but specifically that this seems to be, on average against the typical deck you would face, strictly worse than Glimpse the Unthinkable. That said, it's a) in standard, b) uncommon, and c) undoubtedly more fun to play than the aforementioned benchmark mill spell. I give it a 4.677/5.

179599: Mind Funeral.author: Baconradar
179599: Mind Funeral.text_parsed:
This is superb, if a little bit overrated. For three mana in the definitive mill colours, you are going to be blasting, realistically, around 10 cards off their library. That makes it like having a second glimpse the unthinkable.

But a lot of mill decks can, and will, bounce stuff to the top of the opponents library. If these aren't lands, you are essentially able to blast through them for free. The pyschological impact of the card shouldn't be overlooked.

I give it 4.5 for power, fun and originality.

179599: Mind Funeral.author: Astronautic_Bullfrog
179599: Mind Funeral.text_parsed: I cringe every time I see somebody commenting that milling 4 lands is in any way disruptive of your opponent's tempo, or "like land destruction." It is in no way the case. Milling cards from the library to the graveyard feels like you are getting rid of those cards, but you are not. It is statistically irrelevant and meaningless. Unless you got rid of their last 4 lands, your opponent will basically be just as likely to draw another land as they are to draw a spell, since what you dumped into the grave will roughly be the same ratio as what is in the library. The same goes for any given spell. The likelihood of card X being on top of your opponent's library is exactly the same as card X being 10 cards down and drawing it after you mill them.
179599: Mind Funeral.text_posted: I cringe every time I see somebody commenting that milling 4 lands is in any way disruptive of your opponent's tempo, or "like land destruction." The same goes for any given spell. The likelihood of card X being on top of your opponent's library is exactly the same as card X being 10 cards down and drawing it after you mill them.

179599: Mind Funeral.author: Ferlord
179599: Mind Funeral.text_parsed:
If you are thinking of creating a Modern Mill/Control deck, this could usually be better than Glimpse.

Look on any of the "Decks of the Week", and you'll see that the Modern finalists consistently play fetchlands (like Verdant Catacombs and Scalding Tarn). That means that although they are thinning their decks down, they will also have fewer lands in their deck, and thus, more cards to mill with Mind Funeral.

Perhaps the most necessary card to play with this (and... well, all mill decks) is Surgical Extraction/Extirpate. Extraction is essentially a free "well, now I see your strategy. I'm going to make it not work", while Extirpate is a "I'm going to screw your deck up. Don't try to stop me".

'sigh' with this as well, it looks like Deathrite Shaman can fit in YET ANOTHER modern deck.

179601: Wall of Denial.author: scumbling1
179601: Wall of Denial.text_parsed:
Extremely overrated.

Rather than playing passive defenders, you could play cards that help actively help you accumulate resources or otherwise further your gameplan. Rather than playing a wall, it's more beneficial to drop a mana stone or tutor for something -- anything to get to the business of winning, rather than not-losing.

EDIT: But my point is that all speed is relative, so why not just make your deck faster? Mana doesn't soak up damage directly, but if you start taking control of the game sooner, it doesn't matter what you're life total is. Mana can be used to cast spells and fuel abilities, while resources sunk into a wall do just one thing. I see defenders like Wall of Denial as very similar to straight life gain, which is a bad thing.

179601: Wall of Denial.author: NoobOfLore
179601: Wall of Denial.text_parsed:
Who would have guessed that a wall would get a rating of 4 1/2 stars?
It's an awesome wall for sure, stopping even the most broken of of Turn 2-3 attackers (where's your Abyssal Persecutor now?

@Scumbling: Buying time is a critical aspect of the game. Nobody said that I was playing walls instead of game-winning spells and abilities. Reliably and repeatedly buying time isn't good on it's own, and filling a deck with only that results in a lot of slow defeats. But if you buy time efficiently and early enough, it gives you more time to ramp mana and drop those finishers, because ramping and playing creatures takes up time, and this has unprecedented delaying power at a relatively manageable cost. On top of all that, a lot of decks burn themselves out quickly, if they can't get through those first few turns. Defenders repeatedly thwart their attempts at getting through, which means that after they've emptied their hand, all they can do is wait for you to draw your finisher.
It's also helpful to remember that a lot of walls have Mana Ramp and card advantage worked into them.

TL;DR
Walls don't win games, they save you an indefinite amount of time, ideally until you can drop the spells that do.

It's not the best strategy, but it counters certain deck types, and can hold its own in some competitive environments.

The reason why Wall of Denial is good is because is gives you time to get out the cards that do win you the game. Not all decks are aggro decks.

Wall of Denial is much better than straight-up lifegain. The former improves your board position, while the latter does not. They are not the same thing. Rest for the Weary won't help much if you have no creatures and your opponent is hitting you with a Pelakka Wurm each turn, but Wall of Denial sure will.

179602: Kathari Bomber.author: Qazior
179602: Kathari Bomber.text_parsed:
@iondragonx
Yes you can sac this to something else and get the tokens but it only works like this:

You attack with this and its not blocked. Then this deals combat damage to player.
Then the triggered ability goes to stack.
Players can now cast instants and activate abilities. This is where you can sacrifice Bomber to something like Lyzolda, the Blood Witch to deal 2 more damage and draw a card.
Then Bomber's ability resolves, you get two goblins and try to sacrifice Bomber but since it's long gone you can't. There is no penalty for it in this case.

And now to the card itself. I'm not really sure if I would play it myself since it has to be sacrificed and the unearth cost is so high. 3/5

179602: Kathari Bomber.author: Ligerman30
179602: Kathari Bomber.text_parsed:
Very underrated card. It is a staple in my BR control-aggro deck. Not the most powerful card, no, but combos well with everything, good replacement for Dragon Fodder. Don't think of this as a creature card. This card gets creatures on the field to defend from attackers with chump blocks AND the fact that it deals 2 damage to the other payer is a little added bonus. Out of chump blockers near the end of the game? Fine, unearth, swing for 2 and you have two chump blockers ready to go.

4/5

Turn 1: Mountain, Ligntning Bolt 17 life
Turn 2: Swamp, Lightning Bolt 14 life
Turn 3: Swamp, Kathari Bomber
Turn 4: Mountain, Kathari Bomber attacks, Undying Evil, 12 life
Turn 5: Swamp, Summon a second Kathari bomber, Kathari bomber 1 Attacks, 9 life
Turn 6:Swamp, Unearth Kathiri Bomber 1, Both Attack, 5 life, cast Unearth on Kathari Bomber 2.
Turn 7: Alpha Strike, Game.

All from 2 kathiri bombers , 2 lightning bolts, an undying evil, an unearth and a couple lands.

This card is no joke.

for example, if they attack, you can play it and then block with it.

179605: Flurry of Wings.author: CrazyLou
179605: Flurry of Wings.text_parsed:
Wow. This card just saved me a game. I was playing against a guy who, with the use of Rampaging Baloths and Primeval Titan, had a field full of 4/4 Beasts. I had this in my hand and a Soulcatcher on the field. When he charged, I played the Flurry, chump-blocked 13 Beasts (and killed his Baloths with the help on an Aven Mimeomancer) and put 14 +1/+1 tokens on my Soulcatcher, letting him swing for the win.

Needless to say, my opponent was flabbergasted. And, so was I honestly.

This card is alright. It'll disrupt your opponent, possibly take away his best card and finally this card will replace itself. It's a solid card. The cost is also okay. Distress is two mana and turning a spell into a cantrip usually costs 2 extra mana.

At 2 mana? There would be no reason not to run this if you have the colors. That's a bad thing.

179607: Brainbite.author: MagnusMtG
179607: Brainbite.text_parsed:
A lot of silly criticism about this card. Yes, it's 4-mana to force a discard, which isn't very aggressive.
It doesn't compare to Distress and it doesn't compare to Duress. Distress has BB in its cost - this doesn't. Distress can't discard lands, and duress can't discard lands or creatures.

This is Coercion (not "coercition" - what?!) with an extra pay U to draw a card. It's fairly costed for a common, but overall, yeah, it's not that great. I still have it as filler in my Megrim+Wistful Thinking deck, though. ;-)

179611: Glory of Warfare.author: Asmodi0000
179611: Glory of Warfare.text_parsed:
An excellent card that works very well with Boros Swiftblade and Hearthfire Hobgoblin, and even manages to fit the curve perfectly. In truth, I rarely end up using the +0/+2 benefit since I don't run a lot of vigilant creatures, but even without the backend boost it would still be an excellent card.

I think I would have preferred just a solid +2/+2 on your turn, but as it is now it's certainly more flavorful. While Balefire Liege is my preferred boost card in R/W decks, Glory is harder to remove and works better on just white or just red creatures.

It works great with goat tokens from Springjack Shepard and Springjack Pasture, as well as the kobold tokens from Kher Keep. There's something awesome about taking six 0/1 creatures and suddenly turning them into a surprise 12 damage.
179611: Glory of Warfare.text_posted:

179612: Putrid Leech.author: GoblinNaysayer93
179612: Putrid Leech.text_parsed: Everyone acts like this card is overwhelming, but I don't see what all the fuss is about.  The "once per turn" restriction prevents this from being broken.  Further, Wizards decided to actually be fair with this card--it's not like the creature's power and toughness exceeds its cmc with no drawback.  Rather, it's a two-colored 2/2 for two mana that allows you to pull off some combat tricks, avoid having your leech burned to death with the notorious Lightning Bolt, and pay 2 life to deal 2 more damage.  It seems perfectly reasonable.

179612: Putrid Leech.author: SAUS3
179612: Putrid Leech.text_parsed:
@GoblinNaysayer93
Have you played against this card?

It's not that it has combat tricks and blah blah blah, it's because at no mana cost, you can beat or trade with creatures all the way until around turn 5. Using removal on a 2-drop is usually not very pleasant.

It's not that his guy kills you by himself, it's that on their turn 3, they are swinging at you with a 4/4 while casting stuff like blightning, maelstrom pulse, lightning bolt, or terminate only to follow it up on turn 4 with a bloodbraid elf, which will likely mean more damage (lightning bolt, blightning, another putrid leach) or removal (lightning bolt, terminate, maelstrom pulse). You get overwhelmed by the fact that their 2-drop will kill you if unanswered.

Saying this isn't overwhelming is like saying tarmogoyf isn't overwhelming. It's not that it will kick your butt alone, but the fact that it is just a 2 mana investment makes it lethal.

179614: Morbid Bloom.author: Donovan_Fabian
179614: Morbid Bloom.text_parsed:
This card is being seriously under rated, unlike fertile imagination or other such card it always works, and you get to choose what to target. Playing black green and have a nightmare in the graveyard? That nightmare can now make you 9 saprolings in one turn. Follow up with garruks over run and the game is in the bag. Can also imagine a lhurgoyf or lord of extinction making this card really insane, and because it says toughness only you can always target a wall that died earlier in the game. One wall of frost becomes 7 saprolings. It also doesn't have to be your graveyard, so using it against creatures with unearth, and dredge, doesn't hurt either. At the very least keeps something out of your opponents graveyard and gives you some creatures to boot. Reminds me a lot of aether mutation.

I'm thinking the idea was to enable people to use black/green golgari colors, with some combination of lord of extinction, necrogenesis, and morbid bloom. Same basic concept, new set.

179621: Crystallization.author: Donovan_Fabian
179621: Crystallization.text_parsed:
This card is actually a far better pacifism, not just a reprint. Why? Because you can pacify the creature and then later kill it with any ability, even a beneficial one. Got a creature that taps to add a counter to another one? Use it on the crystallized creature and it gets exiled. Again thats exiled not simply sent to graveyard, its completely gone. A great way to do that would be find a creature who does something like, x target creatures are dealt damage when this card enters play, and then have a few creatures crystallized, for instant exile. Whether thats better than simply finding a card that exiles them is hard to say, keeping in mind that with kitsune mystic you could move the crystallization from creature to creature. Imo wotc has made removal far to easy to achieve, between lightning bolt, path to exile, and maelstrom pulse.. basically if your creature isn't shrouded and indestructible and black and have more than 3 toughness.. it's dead.

@questions, yes you can disenchant/naturalize only the enchantment because you are not targeting the creature, and you can still devour a creature because devour doesn't use the word "target." Mtg rules are very literal, it either says "target" on the ability or it isn't targeting, for example tapping is not a targeted ability, but prodigial pyromancer does have to target a creature to do 1 damage to it (that could be used to exile a creature with crystallization enchanted on it).
179621: Crystallization.text_posted:
This card is actually a far better pacifism, not just a reprint.  Why?  Because you can pacify the creature and then later kill it with any ability, even a beneficial one.  Got a creature that taps to add a counter to another one?  Use it on the crystallized creature and it gets exiled.  Again thats exiled not simply sent to graveyard, its completely gone.  A great way to do that would be find a creature who does something like, x target creatures are dealt damage when this card enters play, and then have a few creatures crystallized, for instant exile.  Whether thats better than simply finding a card that exiles them is hard to say, keeping in mind that with kitsune mystic you could move the crystallization from creature to creature.  Imo wotc has made removal far to easy to achieve, between lightning bolt, path to exile, and maelstrom pulse.. basically if your creature isn't shrouded and indestructible and black and have more than 3 toughness.. it's dead.

@questions, yes you can disenchant/naturalize only the enchantment because you are not targeting the creature, and you can still devour a creature because devour doesn't use the word "target."  Mtg rules are very literal, it either says "target" on the ability or it isn't targeting, for example tapping is not a targeted ability, but prodigial pyromancer does have to target a creature to do 1 damage to it (that could be used to exile a creature with crystallization enchanted on it).

179621: Crystallization.author: eak1801
179621: Crystallization.text_parsed:
In most decks this is essentially Pacifism with a bonus. But in the right deck it can be abused relatively easily. With cards like Simic Guildmage, Vedalken Mastermind, Reality Acid (more removal), and Icy Manipulator (or it's kin) you can trigger Crystallization's ability by targeting the enchanted creature, then respond by returning/moving Crystallization to your hand/another creature. I bet that would be hard to deal with once it's rolling.

Anyways, fun card. More options is always better than fewer options.

179621: Crystallization.text_parsed:
@ElSinorBlanco
I always thought that the green part was destroying the creature. Green is about the community and protecting the group as a whole over the individual. If a creature is a threat to your community of creatures, or is being too selfish and allowing itself to be targeted by spells, it is punished by being exiled.

179623: Sanity Gnawers.author: Kefko
179623: Sanity Gnawers.text_parsed:
Underrated but performs randomly based on the discard. Often messes up entire hands and comes back later to do it again if they still have cards.

Hypnotic specter while very good if he hits dropping both of them turn 3 he takes an extra turn to swing and can be easily killed and/or blocked preventing discards. This guy ETB's it.

I run 2 in my Jund deck along with Blightnings and a slight devour/reanimate /bounce undertone and I'm never dissapointed when I draw these.

One of the most gruesome art I've seen on a magic cards with a fitting flavortext.

Adding haste and/or a bit more p/t would not have broken this, making it 2cmc probably would have.

3.5 solid if you're planning on messing up your opponents and like a bit of random variation

As with a lot of 2-for-1 cards, it has a lot of potential. Having said that, at least in standard most decks top off at 6 or 7 mana for their win conditions. While this can win the game with the right card in your graveyard and the opponent on low enough health, it's not close to being a win condition on its own.

Having said that, it's multicoloured spot removal that can still hit Great Sable Stag which is a big plus. Use it to get a Bit Blast out of your graveyard and you're looking at a 5 damage burn, 4 damage creature spot removal and 1-2 cascades. It could definitely work, but again, has the big drawback of relying on other cards to become decent.

179628: Vengeful Rebirth.author: blurrymadness
179628: Vengeful Rebirth.text_parsed:
It kind of HAS to cost this much. Think of Draco, Darksteel/Blightsteel Colossus, or loads of other 10+ CMC creatures. It'd be easy in a deck that uses CMCs for damage (via other cards as well of course) to pull 10+ damage, so a CMC of 4ish seems a bit perposterous. 5 CMC maybe, but 6 still doesn't treat it too badly with all that colorless. You could always use on of many many avenues to cast this turn 3-4, like cloudposts, saccing tokens to ashnod's alter, channel, etc.

It's a little more work but colorless mana is easy to come by. A single custodian on turn 2 means casting this turn 3 with a sac outlet of some kind. It's quite easy to make this an abusable card. Further with HUGE colorless monstrosities available in your hand you could opt to instead try to hard cast one as a secondary play.

179630: Sigil of the Nayan Gods.author: Donovan_Fabian
179630: Sigil of the Nayan Gods.text_parsed:
This card is intended for a token deck, where it's not junk at all. The concept here would be you play it on a creature other than the token producer itself, a saproling.. a spectral procession token.. bitterblossom fairy.. and that creature gets incrementally larger for every other creature that comes into play, giving your opponent another threat to deal with that started as a 1/1 seemingly innocuous creature. Another example is in a u/w/g color deck, attach it to pride of the clouds, or an emeria angel, giving the pride 2/2 for every flying creature in play or the emeria angel 1/1 everytime it creatures a token.

It's true however that in a normal deck set up where you aren't trying to play tons of creatures at a time that it wont do as much, in those set ups it might add somewhere around 3/3 like a moldervine cloak, and doesn't have the same amount of power behind it.

Beyond that, the simple fact that you can cycle it is fairly useful, if you top deck it and have no creatures while your opponent still has a threat in play you can cycle it to get your next card.

This + Prime Speaker Zegana + Triumph of Ferocity
This + Ideas Unbound

Wizards couldn't have given me much else cooler than this.

179633: Lorescale Coatl.author: jonrds
179633: Lorescale Coatl.text_parsed:
Just built a Simic deck with this. It fits in so well. Master biomancer into prime speaker zegana gets pretty dumb, especially after a rancor (becomes draw 9 minimum). Add Sage of fables for turning counters into more draws (which also add counters to this guy, how convenient!). Its amazing how many of the good Simic cards are wizards (looking at you, Fathom mage and prophet of kruphix, among the others already stated).

Sometimes it can be hard to turn raw card advantage into a winnable position immediately, but this guy does it. You don't even have to pay any mana after dropping him turn 2. Even if your draw engines can't get moving, he gets a counter every turn just for your normal draw. My only complaint about the deck right now is how confusing it can be to play, stacking counters and draws and whatnot.

180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: Donovan_Fabian
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed:
The problem with karrthus is the obvious.. it only works on dragons. While every set needs cards that only work on certain things, those same cards are also the least playable. For example, even a card that has protection from 1 color is still only useful with that ability 1/5 of the time (or maybe more depending on how much multi color decks you fight). In this case it's even more unlikely.. how many decks are you going to fight that your opponent just happens to have dragons in play and you have a karrthus waiting in your hand?

Shields of velis vel is a cool combo indeed, except that you need 9 mana to use it on one turn, and that's not very likely. At the same time, if your opponent has 9 mana, there's plenty of reversals that can be played, or a quick day of judgment.
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_posted:

Shields of velis vel is a cool combo indeed, except that you need 9 mana to use it on one turn, and that's not very likely.  At the same time, if your opponent has 9 mana, there's plenty of reversals that can be played, or a quick day of judgment.

180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: IronDragon
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed: I was playing a game of EDH today, my friend played Treachery on my Kilnmouth Dragon, and i played Karrthus next turn. Which effect takes precedence? I'm inclined to believe Karrthus would, but the counter argument is equally valid. Was thinking to pick the collective brains of the interwebs on this issue
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_posted: I was playing a game of EDH today, my friend played Treachery on my Kilnmouth Dragon, and i played Karrthus next turn. Which effect takes precedence? 180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: Eved
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed:
@Donovan_Fabian
You shouldn't say there is a problem with a card because it has a (useful) conditional ability.
Because there isn't a problem with a cmc 7/7 flying, haste at all.

180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: Flyheight
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed:
@IronDragon
In short, because your effect resolved after his, your effect overwrites his effect and you control the Kilnmouth. For a more detailed explanation, if you're curious, read rules section 613.

By the same token, if, after you played Karrthus, your opponent played another control spell on either of your two dragons, they would control that dragon because their new effect is now the most recent.

180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: Joseph_Leito
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed:
@Tolarus

Yes, you would. Commanders don't get any special consideration for things like this. The thing is, being a commander, their dragon would deal commander damage. That damage would actually be separate from the damage dealt by your commander--each commander has a completely separate pool of damage they must deal to a player to kill them.
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_posted:
@Tolarus

Yes, you would. Commanders don't get any special consideration for things like this. The thing is, being a commander, their dragon would deal commander damage. 180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: adrian.malacoda
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed: "Karrthus has haste; other dragons you control have haste" isn't "Dragons you control have haste." It's a small difference, but it means something.

180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.author: TheBossHammer
180587: Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund.text_parsed:
Hilariously strong in EDH when yanked into the graveyard by Scion of the Ur-Dragon. Start turn with Rise of the Dark Realms or Twilight's Call, flop this guy into the graveyard after the one you picked resolves, then swing with every dragon in your graveyard. If you can mill your library somehow first, then every dragon in your deck. Yank him out of the graveyard if the game is still going on next turn and it gets even better.

Worst case, assuming you can't set anything else up, 2 mana for immunity to "destroy nonblack creature effects" and haste on a 7/7 body. They are a good combo, even if his middle ability doesn't fire off due to his not really entering play.

Even more fun if, somehow, Sarkhan the Mad is on the field.

180592: Wargate.author: DarthParallax
180592: Wargate.text_parsed:
Basically, it is Demonic Tutor where translates to . Another thing it does which is subtle is filters the cards you are searching for so that they are 'virtually artifacts'-i.e. X doesn't have to be whatever color the permanent you are searching for is. So you could make great use of this and aggressive 1-cost Black Zombies or Red Goblins....if you somehow had a Bant-based deck that wanted to summon those creatures, or a Black or Red deck that could cast a 'Bant' spell reliably- or you could even use it to get other wierd gold combinations (BW, RU, GRB) and 'filter' them all into Bant. This point would have been made a bit stronger if it showed a Dragon next to the Sphinx in the art.

There are really two MAJOR groups of decks this card is excellent for: Lands Matter Decks and Heavy-Gold Decks. Of all the 'CMC=0" cards, I would say that Lands are the cards which is a nice fair price for. Lands Matter Decks would be ones that think of Tutoring up specific utility Lands like Silver Bullets- I'm thinking Mystifying Maze or Academy Ruins or Valakut or other lands where the mana they tap for is not the important thing. If all you want is just to get more lands out to tap for different colored mana though, Cultivate, Harrow, and Kodama's Reach are all better just because they're mono-green, and Fetch-Lands are good options for non-Green decks that want to do the same thing.

Heavy Gold Decks use this with the color you are 'filtering into' when you fetch something. That requires good mana-producing support for at least 4 colors though, since you have to cast this reliably and it would be better if you could cast what you search for without HAVING to draw this, to prevent your 'targets' from being dead draws without this. And it's a short hop, skip, and jump to go from 'this could make a nice 4-color deck' to 'this could make a nice 5-color deck'. Unlike many gold cards, this card compares best to Dramatic Entrance, Gifts Ungiven, or Unburial Rites as 'rather than play this Guild's/Shard's/Commander's theme, let's just cheat stuff out and 'whitewash' our mana to do whatever the heck you feel like doing.

Seaside Citadel is actually the last card I would recommend for the mana base of a Wargate Deck because I'd want to be thinking a bit more outside the box than trying to fit it just with other White/Green/Blue cards. Bant decks do best when they are White-Weenie-ish and keep to low CMC. this is going to be a 4-cost most of the time in a deck like that, and sometimes 5, 6, or 7 cost. Not a good fit for Bant after all.

Actually, I just thought of a third thing you can do: It can be a really bad 'Entomb entwined to Animate Dead' card. I don't think trying to use this on cheap creatures just so that X can be low is really the most effiient use. And while fetching lands is efficient, it doesn't always feel like something I want to be spending a whole card to do (especially if I'm running a goldilocks base already).

If you want to Demonic Tutor and Cast a creature in one go, go big or go home and pick something that will really smash the board if it works. You'll have to pay full mana price plus a bit, so it's not really going to be very fast, but you can at least cheat around having to draw the creatures in question, and since it's green you can shave maybe a turn off of the normal ETA of the creature you're trying to summon if you use a lot Rampant Growth effects. I still don't think this is the best thing to be doing with the card though. It's much much better for lands than creatures.

EDIT: Allies and Slivers are kind of stupid tribes in that this card is a bit bonkers with them. Any other creature type in Magic? I'd rather stick with the Black cards I kept comparing this to and do things directly and cheaper. EDIT2: Although normal 6o card decks have a lot of trouble with this whole card in general just because it does something ALMOST good, but that many other cards do better.....1OO card EDH decks can use this card in every way you might want to use it, and it's never going to let them down.

Summary: Play in EDH. lol, sorry I was basically copying and explaining everything metalevolence and Donovan_Fabian already kind of covered, but I hope that any newer players might find my dissertation enlightening so they can see just exactly why those other guys are right. :p
180592: Wargate.text_posted:
Basically, it is [autocard]Demonic Tutor[/autocard] where [1][B] translates to [G][W][U]. Another thing it does which is subtle is filters the cards you are searching for so that they are 'virtually artifacts'-i.e. X doesn't have to be whatever color the permanent you are searching for is. So you could make great use of this and aggressive 1-cost Black Zombies or Red Goblins....if you somehow had a Bant-based deck that wanted to summon those creatures, or a Black or Red deck that could cast a 'Bant' spell reliably- or you could even use it to get other wierd gold combinations (BW, RU, GRB) and 'filter' them all into Bant. This point would have been made a bit stronger if it showed a Dragon next to the Sphinx in the art.

There are really two MAJOR groups of decks this card is excellent for: Lands Matter Decks and Heavy-Gold Decks. Of all the 'CMC=0" cards, I would say that Lands are the cards which [G][W][U] is a nice fair price for. Lands Matter Decks would be ones that think of Tutoring up specific utility Lands like Silver Bullets- I'm thinking Mystifying Maze or Academy Ruins or Valakut or other lands where the mana they tap for is not the important thing. If all you want is just to get more lands out to tap for different colored mana though, Cultivate, Harrow, and Kodama's Reach are all better just because they're mono-green, and Fetch-Lands are good options for non-Green decks that want to do the same thing.

Heavy Gold Decks use this with the color you are 'filtering into' when you fetch something. That requires good mana-producing support for at least 4 colors though, since you have to cast this reliably and it would be better if you could cast what you search for without HAVING to draw this, to prevent your 'targets' from being dead draws without this. And it's a short hop, skip, and jump to go from 'this could make a nice 4-color deck' to 'this could make a nice 5-color deck'. Unlike many gold cards, this card compares best to Dramatic Entrance, Gifts Ungiven, or Unburial Rites as 'rather than play this Guild's/Shard's/Commander's theme, let's just cheat stuff out and 'whitewash' our mana to do whatever the heck you feel like doing. 

Seaside Citadel is actually the last card I would recommend for the mana base of a Wargate Deck because I'd want to be thinking a bit more outside the box than trying to fit it just with other White/Green/Blue cards. Bant decks do best when they are White-Weenie-ish and keep to low CMC. this is going to be a 4-cost most of the time in a deck like that, and sometimes 5, 6, or 7 cost. Not a good fit for Bant after all.

Actually, I just thought of a third thing you can do: It can be a really bad 'Entomb entwined to Animate Dead' card. I don't think trying to use this on cheap creatures just so that X can be low is really the most effiient use. And while fetching lands is efficient, it doesn't always feel like something I want to be spending a whole card to do (especially if I'm running a goldilocks base already). 

If you want to Demonic Tutor and Cast a creature in one go, go big or go home and pick something that will really smash the board if it works. You'll have to pay full mana price plus a bit, so it's not really going to be very fast, but you can at least cheat around having to draw the creatures in question, and since it's green you can shave maybe a turn off of the normal ETA of the creature you're trying to summon if you use a lot Rampant Growth effects. I still don't think this is the best thing to be doing with the card though. It's much much better for lands than creatures.

EDIT: Allies and Slivers are kind of stupid tribes in that this card is a bit bonkers with them. Any other creature type in Magic? I'd rather stick with the Black cards I kept comparing this to and do things directly and cheaper. EDIT2: Although normal 6o card decks have a lot of trouble with this whole card in general just because it does something ALMOST good, but that many other cards do better.....1OO card EDH decks can use this card in every way you might want to use it, and it's never going to let them down. 

Summary: Play in EDH. lol, sorry I was basically copying and explaining everything metalevolence and Donovan_Fabian already kind of covered, but I hope that any newer players might find my dissertation enlightening so they can see just exactly why those other guys are right. :p

180592: Wargate.author: Ominick
180592: Wargate.text_parsed: I've put this card in two decks, with two very different results. With the first deck I was using it like a Tutor, only to discover (as everyone else has) that the mana cost can be prohibitive depending on what you're looking for. After being so disappointed, I took it out of that deck and put it into a five-color deck where I was already running several Tutors. In this deck it worked significantly better, as now I only used it to get more mana (it also makes it pretty easy to find that one elusive Sol Ring). Basically, use it for mana and low-cost cards only.

180595: Thraximundar.author: Donovan_Fabian
180595: Thraximundar.text_parsed: I don't like this card actually, its still 7 mana, but it has no evasion or shroud or anything.  While I understand that clearly not all creatures can have shroud or flying or something, note that it says when thraximundar attacks.. well all that means is if I have a terminate in hand and he's played I terminate him on the spot before my opponent gets to use him.  More over, I can always sacrifice tokens, or birds of paradise etc., at which point he's a high power haste creature.  Flameblast dragon is also pretty similiar by comparison and one mana less with flying, and the x ability can hit players and planeswalkers.  He's still a good creature, but 7 mana is to late in the game to be making a come back, you're either already ahead when you play him, or your not likely to be able to make a board advantage with just thraximundar, as any pacifism, crystallization, or other removal will take care of it completely.  It's true though, if you play him and your opponent has no removal and doesn't draw any for several turns, then it kills.

180595: Thraximundar.author: scumbling1
180595: Thraximundar.text_parsed:
This guy is a fun general for EDH. He's got a synergistic set of abilities and amazing artwork. NeoSin does a great job articulating the beauty of the illustration. Overall, I really like the card.

My only complaint is his creature type of assassin. An assassin is a selective, covert killer; the assassin chooses a single target and eliminates it with cunning and precision. Thraximundar is an armor-clad warlord, riding a giant fellbeast into battle. When he attacks and forces a sacrifice, it's evocative of the attrition of war, rather than a well-planned attack. Thraximundar just seems like a blunt insturment of destruction, and I don't think he could sneak up on a blind man. I really think he should have been a zombie warrior.

180595: Thraximundar.author: DarthParallax
180595: Thraximundar.text_parsed:
Using some intuitive facility with languages I picked up from studying how Tolkien invented Elvish, I'm going to guess the Grixis-Alaran Standard translation runs something like this:

har= he
arra= to paint *not a Grixis word, as they don't have art
rax= red
i= who
mund= world
dar= name ending (equivalent to 'er' in English or 'eur/euse' en Francais, perhaps)

Thar-arra-rax-i-mund-dar= Harraraximundar, which would have been necessarily shortened to Thraximundar for easier pronunciation. He who paints the Earth red.

That looks likely, but I confess that guessing which element is 'paint' and which is 'red' are significantly harder than suggesting probable answers to the rest of the translation, and my divisions of syllables could be off.


Finding the element corresponding to the verb 'to paint' was particularly difficult, and I settled on a word that sounded unlike the harsher language that would have produced 'thar' and 'rax'. 'Mund' and 'Arra' then, probably come from the same language of origin, which I believe to be Nayan. I realized that Thraximundar couldn't have been named in Grixis. His name was most certainly first made by a recorder of some invasion elsewhere on Alara, especially considering the concept of 'painting' seems alien to Grixis (no art, or only ruins of art from Ancient Times, with no words for it left in the Modern Grixis language). However, a responsible scholar would take care to make sure that the name felt connected to the thing being named, and would probably try to create something that sounds 'Grixis-y' to them, and they might even know some Vithian dialects (Knight of New Alara in particular suggests that what little culture there was on Grixis was diffused to the other planes). I hypothesize the victims were not of Esperan origin, as I don't think they were enlightened enough to concieve of the importance of naming this creature with any more care than whatever the Vedalken word for 'Abomination' might be. Therefore that leaves Jund, Naya, and Bant as possible origins for the namer of Thraximundar. I discard the probability of a Jundian name, as they wouldn't care much what the name of the thing they're killing is.
He was probably named by some survivors of an attack on Naya or Bant, since they are the only Alaran culture that would have paint that might also have a similar language structure to Grixis (having human cultures themselves. the Vithian humans might even be distantly related to Elves of Naya). Also, the pattern of naming definitely suggest one of the Red-aligned, more primitive Planes. Since we have ruled out Jund and Grixis as being unlikely to be able to produce the name on their own, then either it was a Nayan, or possibly a well-travelled Bantian or Jundian who created the name.

180595: Thraximundar.author: longwinded
180595: Thraximundar.text_parsed:
@DarthParallax

You can't be afraid to shy away from the literal when translating. When you think about words in English such as "sufferer" or "doer" you don't tend to think of them as meaning "one who suffers" or "one who does". You don't have to, because -or and -er let you encapsulate the notion of "one who verbs" quite easily. Similarly the "he who" portion of thraximundar could come from simply casting a verb into a noun/operator form. The -ar suffix is used in the infinitive form of some romance language verbs, and it is also permitted to use the infitive as a noun, so it's not hard to see "Thraximundar" as a verb without straying too far from the pseudo-Latin that spawned it.

Mundi is world or more loosely earth, and some portion of the word should clearly mean "red", but there's no reason to get too literal with "paint". To paint something a color is not really any different than to make something a color, and to paint red is no different from to made red or redden. How would you translate "redden" into a language that didn't have it as a verb? Probably as make/paint red. Similarly, how would you translate the verb to red into a language where red is only an adjective or noun, but never a verb? Probably as redden if available, or paint red if not.

If thraxi some how meant some form of "red", then thraximundi could easily mean "red earth" and thraximundar, "earth redden-er". Now, why thraxi should translate somehow into "red(den)" is a question worth asking, since mundi is very obvious to people with even a passing familiarity with Latin. The only thing I can think of is that "Thrax" was the Latin form of Thracian, and the people of Thrace were widely believed (were?) red-headed. That's stretching it, but perhaps there's more mythology that I'm missing somewhere. (Or perhaps Creative similarly stretched a word because it sounded exotic with the "x" in it.)

I'd say the flavor of a red assassin, while unusual, is implemented perfectly here. The victim sees him coming a mile away, but he's so fast that he still makes the kill. Unfortunately, he moves so quickly that it's a toss-up as to whether he killed the right target.

180595: Thraximundar.author: MechaKraken
180595: Thraximundar.text_parsed:
In many ways, Thraximundar is still stronger then Grimgrin, Corpse-born. Thrax can come out and swing in the same turn due to haste, and his saccing ability can get around your opponents creatures who have shroud/hexproof. We'll compare to Grimgrin.

Grimgrin is only two colors, so he can come out more easily, and he is cheaper too. Grimgrins saccing ability also has a nice little combo, where you can pump him up indefinitely if you have Rooftop Storm and Gravecrawler out. Running both Grimgrin and Thrax is a definite option though!

Anyway, something to remember is that Thrax can and probably will be chumpblocked. This is where you pump him up to give him trample/unblockabilty. There are many ways to do this, here are a few - Distortion Strike, Artful Dodge, Fury Charm.

180595: Thraximundar.author: Manite
180595: Thraximundar.text_parsed:
Something I just realized: Every Shard except Grixis got a Legendary tricolor iconic creature (Jenara, Asura of War, Sharuum the Hegemon, Karrthus, Tyrant of Jund, and Uril, the Miststalker). Grixis lacks a legendary tricolor Demon. Thraximundar is big and forces players to sacrifice creatures. Now what are two properties common to Demons? I'm starting to suspect Thrax here wasn't designed as a Zombie Assassin. And quite frankly that makes me feel his current typing is redundant with Sedris around.

I think Thrax should have traded places with Malfegor, who if I recall was the closest thing Grixis had to a ruler before his demise, meaning Mal should have been while Thrax would have worked fine as a . Another "could have been" scenario brought to you by Grixis' former demon-dragon overlord.

180596: Thought Hemorrhage.author: Mobenator
180596: Thought Hemorrhage.text_parsed:
Thought Hemorrhage is an exact copy of Cranial Extraction with two slight differences.

1. It costs one red instead of a colourless mana.
2. It can deal 3 damage for each card you name in their hand.

Thought Hemorrhage is similar to Lobotomy because it has the 'extraction' like effect although both Thought Hemorrhage and Cranial Extraction require the caster to name a card rather than choosing one from the target players hand.

In response to Cenelder, firstly Thought Hemorrhage causes you to look in a players hand, if it didn't your opponent could easily lie. Secondly as you name a card on the resolution of the spell you can 'miss a target' in your opponents hand unlike Lobotomy where the card you name must be in your opponents hand.

I rate this card alot lower than Cranial Extraction because of the addition coloured mana it costs to cast, it also requires two different types of mana which makes it hard to splash unlike Cranial Extraction.

180596: Thought Hemorrhage.author: Paolino
180596: Thought Hemorrhage.text_parsed:
The three damage for each named card in hand are not important. This is a powerful card against combo decks.
Comparing it with Lobotomy is natural, but making the comparison is not so simple IMHO. Mana cost and color weight is exactly the same. Both are sorceries. Both exile all the copies of a given card of your choice from graveyard, hand and library. And these are the common aspects. Let's look at the differences.
1) Lobotomy makes you look at opponent's hand. This avoids using other cards to be sure to remove an imminent threat.
2) With Lobotomy you can only remove a card which is actually into opponent's hand, and this is a nontrivial restriction when stopping a combo deck.
3) Lobotomy doesn't deal eventual damage for cards in hand. I don't think this is very important...
4) Lobotomy allows you to remove nonbasic lands. This is a strong feature which Thought Hemorrhage doesn't have: things such as Wasteland, Ancient Tomb, Blinkmoth Nexus or the dual lands are not neglectable; it is also true that normally these lands are played as soon as they are drawn, and so it is difficult that one has come of them in hand to be chosen with Lobotomy...
In the end... Thought Hemorrhage wins also thanks to the artwork! :D

180597: Enigma Sphinx.author: JaxsonBateman
180597: Enigma Sphinx.text_parsed:
Whilst I have only been playing casually myself, I do have one in my artifact deck that I rarely ever lose with. His cost gets drastically reduced if you have multiple Etherium Sculptors out, reaching a minimum of 3 mana to play if you manage to get 4 out (not to mention that on that alone it's possible to play it by turn 4). And of course, even if you get the reduced mana cost cascade is still based off its converted mana cost of 7.

Admittedly, it isn't as useful as a lot of other artifacts in the deck, and it will never be the first one I search for with a Sphinx Summoner, Fabricate or Tezzeret, but it's not entirely bad. Its big cascade lets you put more artifacts into play and increase your utility and power, and it's still a flier which makes it a decent thopter producer if you get a Sharding Sphinx out.

All in all, I'd say the 3.6 rating is about where it's at, but don't underestimate his cascade power when you combine him with those sculptors!

180597: Enigma Sphinx.author: Donovan_Fabian
180597: Enigma Sphinx.text_parsed:
Not sure why it is you can't use master transmuter on it, or at least elvish piper, since you are still playing the spell even if your doing it with help from a creature, but anyways it doesn't really matter. Even with the slightly prohibitive mana cost there isn't anything else about it that makes you want to try to get it out super early, a 5/4 is equivalent to a 3 mana thoctar except that it has flying. The only really interesting thing about this card is the cascade, the only issue being it's not easy to mass a deck of things that it can cascade into, in the sense that it's completely random. Anything under 7 mana is almost everything in the game. It could be completely awesome when that happens, or it could get you a strix, hard to say. The sphinx of the steel wind is probably a better finisher simply for it's consistency.

Also, unless I'm very mistaken, grab the reigns does not put it in the persons graveyard who took control of it with the spell, when it dies it goes back to the original controller and then back into their library. I've never actually played with grab the reigns, but as a patron of mind control I know it works that way with that card.

Can potentially combo with where ancients tread, since when it dies it always comes back into play not long after, and can be used to cascade into removal cards like fiery fall, bituminous blast, and mind control, that you can set to the top of your deck by using cards like sage owl, and magus of the future. The deck has to be set up around it to operate properly however, or half the time you will cascade into something with an x cost, or a 1/1 creature.

180597: Enigma Sphinx.author: Selez
180597: Enigma Sphinx.text_parsed:
This, along with the other cascade cards, is a MAJOR reason that they brought the "cast" terminology back in M10, as well as created the "battlefield." People confuse "play" (the equivalent of cast) with "put into play," which trigger at different times. "Play" denoted an ability that went on the STACK with the spell, like cascade, storm, or replicate. In contrast, "comes into play" will trigger no matter how the card got to the battlefield, be it casting or transmuting or reanimating or search-your-library-and-plop-on-the-battlefield effects.
Also, another reason exile effects are becoming more common. How are you supposed to beat this in draft without a Path to Exile or Celestial Purge?
And hey, why is it an enigma??? That makes so little sense.

"Play" denoted an ability that went on the STACK with the spell, like cascade, storm, or replicate. In contrast, "comes into play" will trigger no matter how the card got to the battlefield, be it casting or transmuting or reanimating or search-your-library-and-plop-on-the-battlefield effects.

180597: Enigma Sphinx.author: A3Kitsune
180597: Enigma Sphinx.text_parsed: The Sphinx's ability triggers when she goes into a graveyard (as far as I can tell, this Sphinx is female). Like all cards, she goes into her owner's graveyard. <u>Then</u> the ability triggers. Since it triggers <u>after</u> the Sphinx goes into the graveyard, who "your" refers to is determined by who's graveyard she's in, which would be her owner's graveyard. Then, she is put into that "your"'s, ie: her owner's, library, third from the top.
180597: Enigma Sphinx.text_posted: The Sphinx's ability triggers when she goes into a graveyard (as far as I can tell, this Sphinx is female). Like all cards, she goes into her owner's graveyard. 180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.author: Archangelion
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_parsed: Hey, adrianxmaturu, if you were thinking of attaching Shield of the Oversoul to Emperial Archangel then your going to have a problem, seeing as she has shroud, and can't be targeted by spells or abilities, which means your Shield of the Overwsoul would fizzle when it trys to attach to the Emperial Archangel. Therefore, in order to make you pretty little angel indestructable, you will have to be more cunning. Use Mycosynth Lattus and Darksteel Forge. The Lattus makes all permanents artifacts, and the Forge makes all YOUR artifacts indestructable, thus makeing your pariahish angel an indestructable game winner, if your opponent doesn't mill you to death, or play a card that sais that they win the game, or if they play a wrath card that exiles all creatures/artifacts. Or if they target you with a spell such as evacuation. lol

It doesn't matter if your opponent is playing removal, since you're getting the aura for free.

On another note, pay no attention to the lack of flying - I believe the way that the current deck works is that you attack with a Birds of Paradise and throw the Eldrazi aura on them on the same turn that you cast these guys, which thanks to Lotus Cobras and such can be as early as turn 3 or 4.

180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.author: d-101
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_parsed:
Sovereigns is a wonderful exalted card that works in both an aura/buff deck and exalted (of course, a mixture works quite well). The lack of flying isn't a main concern, since you'll either be swinging with other creatures or be able to put whatever aura you want that has flying on Sovereigns itself.
Devastating with Eldrazi Con***ion, a combo which comes out on turn five if no mana ramp is used (though exalted decks with green have easy mana ramping capabilities).
5/5

180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.author: TexTiger
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_parsed: Does Geist of St. Traft benefit from exalted since the Angel comes along with it when it attacks?
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_posted: Does Geist of St. Traft benefit from exalted since the Angel comes along with it when it attacks?

180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.author: tenkaze
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_parsed:
@TexTiger: Yes, Saint Traft gets the aura. You declare him as your sole attacker, then three things happen:
1. Exalted trigger from Sovereigns
2. Aura tutor trigger from Sovereigns
3. Angel trigger from Saint Traft
Since Sovereigns only checks if a creature is attacking alone as of the end of the declare attackers step, it won't see the Angel in time and it'll let you search up an aura.
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_posted:
@TexTiger: Yes, Saint Traft gets the aura. You declare him as your sole attacker, then three things happen:
1. Exalted trigger from Sovereigns
2. Aura tutor trigger from Sovereigns
3. Angel trigger from Saint Traft
Since Sovereigns only checks if a creature is attacking alone as of the end of the declare attackers step, it won't see the Angel in time and it'll let you search up an aura.

180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.author: KoreanRevenant
180600: Sovereigns of Lost Alara.text_parsed:
Ex. of a perfect u/w spirit lifegain (modern) turn:
You have this, Boon Reflection, Cradle of Vitality, Drogskol Captain, Wall of Reverence, and some random spirit (assuming you are playing a u/w spirit lifegain, as intended) with unblockable (ex. Latch Seeker) who is at, for the sake of this mock turn, a 7/5 from a little help from cradle and the captain on the battlefield, and you are at 20 life:

-Start by attacking with the 7/5, exalted triggers from this, making it an 8/6.
-Search your library for Celestial Mantle and attach it to the 8/6 (now at 11/9).
~With hexproof and unblockable, there is a very low chance your target will be able to stop the hit.
-Celestial Mantle triggers, also triggering Boon Reflection, so thats 20 x 4, totaling to 80 life with an increase of 60.
- Pay 2 for cradle, and put 60 +1/+1 counters on that 11/9. you now have a 71/69 spirit that is unblockable with hexproof.
-If this doesn't make your opponent scoop, remind them that its your endstep, Wall of Reverence triggers, also triggering boon, for a grand total of (71x2) 142 more life.
-pay 2 for cradle, put 142 +1/+1 counters on your 71/69.
-In one turn, you went from 20 life with a 7/5, to 222 life and a 212/210 (213/211 next time it attacks) who is unblockable and hexproof for 4 mana. If your opponent hasn't scooped by end of turn, they're braindead.

180601: Sages of the Anima.author: Kenji18
180601: Sages of the Anima.text_parsed:
Mode: Where is your Johnny blood?

Try using this guy with Library of Leng and then Esper Sojourners. When you cycle the sojourners, you can choose to put it on top of your library instead of your graveyard using the Library of Leng. The Sages will let you reveal the top 3 cards, one of which is the creature that you just put on top of your library. The Sojourners let you tap or untap a permanent when you cycle him, so if you have a land with Dawn's Reflection or a Bloom Tender with 3 colors of permanents in play, then you will be able to get your 3 mana back, allowing you to repeat the combo.

You get to pull all of the creature cards from your library for free, but if you are playing with Bloom tender, you have the potential to get infinite mana if you have more than 3 colors of permanents in play.

I'll let you figure out your own win condition.

180601: Sages of the Anima.author: Salient
180601: Sages of the Anima.text_parsed:
Ultimate Johnny Insanity: this + Aluren + Glimpse of Nature.

I play it with Armored Skaab, Snapcaster Mage, and a Laboratory Maniac somewhere in your library.

This is probably the sickest card in my Momir Vig deck. Plays well with Sylvan Library and very well with Abundance. (You choose which of the three replacement effects to use: do you want a land card, a nonland card, or up to three creatures?)

If you don't run this with Abundance or sacrifice outlets, remember to stock plenty of landfetch creatures (Sakura-Tribe Elder, Fertilid, Coiling Oracle, etc). Otherwise you'll stall out at five lands.

180601: Sages of the Anima.author: underluc
180601: Sages of the Anima.text_parsed:
this card makes me sad. I run a simic elf edh deck with edric or momir as my general. this card just has sooo much potential. the 2 simple changes that would make this card playable would be, saying "If you would draw a card, instead you MAY reveal... otherwise draw your card" and the second things is, i honestly think this should be a 4 or 5 card filter reveal. even in a 60 card deck, assuming you are running from 30%-40% mana (18-24 land cards). And assuming that of the remaining 36-42 cards, you are running primarly creature cards, it still seems as though the chance of hitting a land or one of ur few non creature cards isnt worth the restraint of only 3 cards filter. let alone in an commander deck....

in summation, someday, i hope to see a 4-6 cmc u/g elf with a reworded version of this cards ability. its a great concept, the sages just dont deliver.

also, the artwork is soooo awesome, it makes how lack-luster the card is all that much more painful...

180602: Predatory Advantage.author: majinara
180602: Predatory Advantage.text_parsed:
The card sucks by default. However, there are ways to make it more playale.
- play it in a discard deck (opponents without cards on hand can't play creatures)
- play it in a land destruction deck (opponents without mana can't play creatures)
- play it in a multiplayer deck (the more opponents, the more chances to get creatures)

And of course: play it in a deck, where the tokens have a purpose (to be sacrificed for something or whatever). Then it's a good card. But just putting it in a random 1vs1 deck: then it's horrible.

180602: Predatory Advantage.author: kiseki
180602: Predatory Advantage.text_parsed:
This can't stand on its own, even in multiplayer. Creatures are so important in multiplayer due to their efficiency that you end up with a couple of very expensive suspended lizards. I've seen this go whole rounds without getting a token. And yet, there is an irrational fear of the card?! If I play this, I won't get the benefit, but opponents will team up on me for having it.
I'm going to try it in my Jokulhaups deck, and also in my red/green control (weird but effective) deck that encourages people to hold back their creatures.
A disappointing card that I really want to be good.

180602: Predatory Advantage.author: Justice1337
180602: Predatory Advantage.text_parsed:
OK, I don't understand the low ratings. First, this is obviously meant for EDH, so stop downrating it because it isn't as good as Tarmogoyf. But now if you've played EDH or any multiplayer FFA, how can you say that this isn't an auto-include for every deck of these colors? Take worst case scenario. By turn 5, your opponents have either done nothing but played land, played a bunch of draw spells, or they're sitting with 3 or 4 cards. Of those, the typical deck usually has at least one creature. So, everyone plays a creature, you get no tokens, waste - right? Not so fast. How long can the least-creature heavy opponent play a creature spell every single turn? Probably not a turn longer, so next turn you have an automatic activated Mobilization, with a 2/2. Next turn after that, you probably have multiple triggers. Down the stretch, you might be triggering it 3 times an orbit. You'll outpace Bitterblossom by the end of the game, no questions asked.

That's if you're just dumb and throw this in there. What about if you build around it? Luring creatures out of your opponents is something that a lot of controllish decks would want to do. Decks playing Jokulhaups and clones probably rank this as one of the top cards they want to hit before playing that card, if not the very top card. This is just so awesome aside mass LD that it's rightly judged as one of the more threatening things to be on the board, perfectly fitting at a 5 cmc.

180602: Predatory Advantage.author: Sweater
180602: Predatory Advantage.text_parsed:
I find it a solid card in practice. Not only does it get you loads of freebies in multiplayer, but forces your opponents to play their creatures when they don't want to. Either bringing out a flash guy on their own turn, or bringing out some specialized fatty too early. Also people sometimes limit themselves to one creature a turn, when normally they would play several.

I like that you just throw it out there and then forget about it, putting all the pressure (albeit minimal at times) on the opponents.

180604: Cerodon Yearling.author: Aaron_Forsythe
180604: Cerodon Yearling.text_parsed:
Aarons Random Card Comment of the Day #73, 4/6/11

Although I was the lead designer on Alara Reborn, I didnt have anything to do with making this card. I believe we handed off something much more complicated in this slot (my first thought is that Intimidation Bolt was at common, although I cant access Multiverse from home right now to check). I believe Matt Place and his development team added this little guy in.

If you dont know, Cerodon Yearling is a throwback to the card Bull Cerodon from two sets earlier. The Bull was an uncommon 5/5 for , but otherwise the cards are the same. One surefire way to make a simple, attractive gold card is to put a keyword from each color onto a creature.

Im not sure this card was the best use of the slot in Alara Reborn. Hes very aggressive, and wants to be cast as soon as possible, but R/W wasnt a deck in that limited format. He would probably have been better used as a more late-game card for Naya decks or for other multi-colored decks to splash for. The only other enemy-colored two-drop common in the set, Putrid Leech, was pushed for constructed, but I dont see any sensible way to have done that for the Cerodon. But then again, reading the other comments on the card, he appears to be lovable, which in the end is whats most important.

180604: Cerodon Yearling.author: Cheza
180604: Cerodon Yearling.text_parsed:
@ Cerodon Yearling:

Adding white seems needless, since both abilities are red flavored. Therefore it would have been just a fine red knight at uncommon rarity.

@ Naya Shards:

Although I don't like tri-color decks, no matter if it's a wedge or a shard-like combination, I like the concept of forming distinct guilds, groups or "worlds" within a set. This defines a structure, forms keywords and makes it easy to build a theme-based deck around an idea.

I wonder who was responsible for the shards, since they seem to have random concepts, so I never got in touch with any shard but Esper. Since Aaron has mentioned Naya, I see the connection between green fatties and the "power 5+" theme, However, it felt strange to see how both main weenie colors (white and red) are "forced" into this theme. So per se, this card fits quite well into a R/W deck, but maybe the true problem comes from somewhere else... maybe a more color-pie specific problem.

As I've discussed it in the MTG forum, I believe that green is a mix of aggressive creatures, but also include the calm, tranquil and creepingly slow color aspects. White also combines the cold, defensive and thoughtful aspects of a pure white and the active, offensive nature of yellow. And it's this dualism within these two colors that causes so much overlap and color-bleed. Likewise any focus one half of the color-aspects leaves the other half unrecognized. So for me, that's why this card fails within the Naya shard, although it's not a bad card in any other enviroment. (Since a typical RW deck feels fine with just the yellow part within white).

Anyhow, Jenara often drops turn two due to Birds of Paradise or Noble Hierarch, and while most can handle her, the thing is you have to handle her. She can't just be ignored. And that means less removal for later, and less pressure on the Bant player right now. Certainly a good card.

180607: Sen Triplets.author: Enchantment_Removal
180607: Sen Triplets.text_parsed:
ATTENTION DEULISTS!:
The text on Sen Triplets is one huge triggered ability. It even targets. At the beginning of your upkeep, you put this ability on the stack with a target. That opponent will get to respond. In a duel, that doesn't matter as much since there is only one potential target.

I have a penchant for stealing other people's stuff. Just because someone else has it, doesn't mean it's worth stealing. There are enough people with cards in their hand that would be better than they actually are if that card's ability was to "force target opponent to jump through hoops to steal this card". If you have your opponent pinned in a corner where you can play their good stuff out of their hand and they can't do anything, perhaps you currently possess more advantageous cards than he/she does and so therefore maybe you would be better off playing your cards, which are evidently more advantageous (or perhaps, it is more advantageous to not play anything at all).

I fear that these strategies being discussed (or Sen Triplets all in all) are not effective against good opponents and only work against an inferior one. When you have the advantage against an inferior opponent, you should not prolong the game and torture them. You go ahead and win.

This card is alright; especially good against certain decks. Most of the time, you force your opponent to kill it (which is alright). Most other time, it is only a 3/3. You only wish that you reach 15 mana before your opponent and get to play their Emrakul out of their hand.

Not a good EDH general. Usually, you would only be allowed to produce White, Blue, or Black mana, so you could miss some players. Also, players who overestimate the power of this card (like yourselves) may preemptively mess with it/you.

Please don't build a deck around this card (unless you can beat good decks/good players). This card is good in certain decks, but if you build a deck around this you will only be able to annoy new/inexperienced players with inferior decks.

180607: Sen Triplets.author: achilleselbow
180607: Sen Triplets.text_parsed:
Sleetfox, Iona doesn't let your opponent cast spells (of that color) AT ALL. This only prevents them from casting spells during your turn. Any deck other than blue counter is barely going to be affected by that restriction. Iona is also a 7/7 flier which will go on to kill the opponent who now has no way of removing her and probably no creatures that can deal with her. These girls won't even put a dent in whatever defenses your opponent has managed to get out before you played them.

That's not to say it's not a good card, but you do have to build around it, while all you have to do with Iona is get her on the field.

180607: Sen Triplets.author: adrian.malacoda
180607: Sen Triplets.text_parsed:
@shb

The effect of this card states "You may play cards from that player's hand this turn". "Cards" includes spell cards (instant, sorcery, enchantment, artifact, planeswalker, or creature) and land cards. You can play any card from their hand.

If it only included spell cards it would say "cast nonland cards". If it only included noncreature spells (creatures are spells too) it would specify "noncreature, nonland cards".

180607: Sen Triplets.text_parsed:
I need to be enlightened a bit concerning this card and having the proper mana to play an opponent's spells. The way I understand EDH rules you can only generate mana in a color of your general's colors. So if you are playing against a red/green deck and take either their land or have exotic orchard they would still only produce colorless mana for you since they do not match the Triplets' colors. Or do stolen lands still produce their normal color even if they don't match your general?

I found the ruling. With Sen Triplets as your general an Exotic Orchard cannot produce G or R mana even if the opponent has a land that can do so.

180607: Sen Triplets.author: Aggro_Red
180607: Sen Triplets.text_parsed:
Why do people think you can use her as a General and cast other player's cards if you lack the proper mana? In Commander, you can never produce mana outside your General's color identity. If you do, the mana automatically becomes colorless. Ex. In my Mono Red Urabrask deck, if I use a Darksteel Ingot to make any color other than red, it becomes colorless. So with the triplets, you can only cast white, black, or blue spells or any combo of those colors, provided they do not require an alt color that is outside your color grid. (multicolor spells) Even if you use their land from their hand as a land drop, that land will only provide legal colors for your deck identity. (Ex. A land that produces a White or a Red would essentially provide a White or a Colorless)

She is an awesome EDH commander, but she isn't THAT broken.
180607: Sen Triplets.text_posted:

(multicolor spells) Even if you use their land from their hand as a land drop, that land will only provide legal colors for your deck identity. (Ex. 180607: Sen Triplets.author: LordRandomness
180607: Sen Triplets.text_parsed:
Your options for EDH use:

- Mycosynth Lattice
- Celestial Dawn
- False Dawn (temporarily)
- Sunglasses of Urza (red only, not green)
- North Star (terrible, but having a copy and some way to dispose of it is important in case your other three permanent options are answered)

Pretty sure they're the only ones that let you spend mana as though it were something else, rather than adding coloured mana to your pool (where it proceeds to turn colourless).

Related: Please run friendly cards such as Shieldmage Advocate that allow you to bolster opposing hands. Not only does it stop a lot of the hate traditionally aimed at Sen Triplets decks, it lets you put the cards you want to cast in their hand!

180608: Aven Mimeomancer.author: Shiizu
180608: Aven Mimeomancer.text_parsed:
Such a fun card! And surprisingly good, too. 3 damage in the air for 3 mana is quite above the curve. Sure, he's bad as a blocker as he'll pretty much always trade, but that's not what you want him to do.
His 3/1 counters on creatures works amazing with the new ally mechanic. 4/2 kazandu blademaster with flying on top of his vigilance and first strike? Yes please!
Of course, turning the mighty baneslayer in a 3/1 is also pretty fun.

His main drawback is that he's a one toughness guy, which is kinda bad. Luckily this only matters when there's a pinger like Tim or his red brother in play.

180609: Finest Hour.author: TheLastKawika
180609: Finest Hour.text_parsed: This card is insane!! Most people don't even realize how powerful this card really is. For example, just imagine this card and Rafiq of the Many in play. (Or should I say on the Battlefield? Bleh...) Rafiq swings as a 5/5 double striker due to his ability and exalted stacking. Which deals 10 damage. Now "Finest Hour" kicks in and untaps Rafiq. KEEP IN MIND, Rafiq is still a 5/5 until end of turn. Now he is allowed to swing again as a 7/7 double striker, dealing 14 damage. So in total, you can have Rafiq deal a WHOOPING 24 damage!

180609: Finest Hour.author: psyklone
180609: Finest Hour.text_parsed:
I would think that 2 of these DO create 2 extra combat phases.
It says "additional" combat phases. The only requirement is that these phases are directly after the current one (ie no mainphase inbetween).
Think of it this way: if you get another main phase you don't say "But I already have 2 this turn!" do you? The number you have doesn't matter.

Also, with 2 out its key to note that if your creature can tap to do something, once the first one resolves your creature is now untapped and you have priority. You can tap it to put its ability on the stack before the second one resolves. And then again after the second one (altho you will have to attack with different creatures in your other attack phases).

And finally, while exalted will stack the 2nd time around, don't let that distract you from the fact that attacking with all your creatures may be better. Especially if you don't have rafiq out, or your opponent has a lot of 1/1 token blockers.

180609: Finest Hour.author: sonorhC
180609: Finest Hour.text_parsed:
@LiXinjian: Multiples don't stack infinitely, but they do stack. If you have four of these out, and make your first attack, all four will trigger and you'll get four more attack phases. You won't trigger any more from one of the later attacks, but five attacks (with the exalted bonus getting bigger in each one) should be plenty.

Though you will need to find a new creature to attack with in the third and following attacks, I suppose, unless you have vigilance.

180609: Finest Hour.author: EvilDarkVoid
180609: Finest Hour.text_parsed:
This and Rafiq is all that is needed to make even a Glistener Elf or Blighted Agent lethal in one turn. Yikes.

Something people don't seem to be noticing: Exalted lasts until the end of the turn and triggers every time a creature attacks alone. If you trigger exalted on this then swing with the same creature in the second combat phase, it gets all of the exalted triggers on your board again, doubling the bonus on the second swing. The above scenario doesn't even need this, though.
180609: Finest Hour.text_posted:
This and [autocard]Rafiq[/autocard] is all that is needed to make even a [autocard]Glistener Elf[/autocard] or [autocard]Blighted Agent[/autocard] lethal in one turn. Yikes.

Something people don't seem to be noticing: Exalted lasts until the end of the turn and triggers every time a creature attacks alone. If you trigger exalted on this then swing with the same creature in the second combat phase, it gets all of the exalted triggers on your board [i]again[/i], doubling the bonus on the second swing. The above scenario doesn't even need this, though.

180611: Spellbound Dragon.author: Agent1103
180611: Spellbound Dragon.text_parsed:
THE combo with this card is Magma Phoenix. Along with Darksteel Colossus, Spellbound Dragon has some massive damage potential. There are several other cards in current Standard with unearth that allows Spellbound Dragon to be used to maximum potential while maintaining the utility of the cards discarded. For example, Scourge Devil has a high casting cost, giving Spellbound Dragon +5P, but a lower unearth cost and a nice come into play ability, giving all creatures +1/+0 until end of turn. After all is said and done, b*tch slap your opponent with Soul's Fire for the coup de grâce.

Edit: Celfaria, I never said anything about Magma Phoenix's ability triggering, I was referring to the ability to bring it back from the grave. You discard it, and you don't have to lose card advantage.

180612: Lavalanche.author: solmalka
180612: Lavalanche.text_parsed:
This card ruins games in Limited. If your opponent plays it, you almost certainly lose. It's totally one-sided and there is almost no way to play around it. It doesn't require much creativity to use it effectively, either. At least symmetric Wrath or Pyroclasm effects require you to sandbag your own creatures, possibly tipping off your opponent that something's coming. With Lavalanche, you just play out your dudes normally and then blow out your opponent.

Martial Coup is much the same. If you play it for 7 or more mana, you just win.

Plague Wind was fine since 9 mana is almost prohibitive, even in Limited. Lavalanche can be a blowout at as little as 5 or 6 mana. That's just not fair.

Please stop making cards like this.

- Sol
180612: Lavalanche.text_posted:
This card ruins games in Limited.  If your opponent plays it, you almost certainly lose.  It's totally one-sided and there is almost no way to play around it. At least symmetric Wrath or Pyroclasm effects require you to sandbag your own creatures, possibly tipping off your opponent that something's coming.  With Lavalanche, you just play out your dudes normally and then blow out your opponent.  

Martial Coup is much the same.  If you play it for 7 or more mana, you just win.  

Plague Wind was fine since 9 mana is almost prohibitive, even in Limited.  Lavalanche can be a blowout at as little as 5 or 6 mana.  That's just not fair.

- Sol
