180612: Lavalanche.author: Kenji18
180612: Lavalanche.text_parsed:
I am unsure why people are not giving this card higher marks. I run it in my domain deck. Spend the early turns mana fixing with cards like Exploding Borders that also soften the opponent, then wipe their side of the board for 5 or 6. Try it with Cloven Casting. Pay 1 less for the X cost, then copy it. It's fun to blast someone for 7 late game, copy it, then walk in with a 16/16 Apocolypse Hydra that needed a couple of chumpers to get out of the way.

For those that still want to complain that it costs too much, then I'm sure that you haven't had your board wiped yet.

180612: Lavalanche.author: EvilCleavage
180612: Lavalanche.text_parsed: I was at my buddies house out of town with my younger brother last week, and I had convinced my brother to play Magic for the first time (he always made fun of me for it by the way), and we were all playing and I think he felt left out, so he said he'd play. So I let him play my Jund deck. Half way through the game he shows me this card and asks me what he should do with it. I'm a fair player so I told him how it worked and that he could kill 4 of my creatures or all of my buddies. Instantly he said he wanted to use it on my buddy so he could wipe out all of his creatures and knock him for a bunch of life. I swear ever since that moment he was hooked. We've played every day since then and now I finally have someone to play with! YES!

180612: Lavalanche.author: DarkonCrack
180612: Lavalanche.text_parsed:
@All of you saying this is a bomb card and don't understand its low rating

Yes, this card is a POWERHOUSE. See Bonfire of the Damned as a good example of this card's potential. The problem with it though is actually it's colors. Because it's in Jund, you are auto including Bloodbraid Elf into your deck in 4. There is NOTHING worse to cascade into than an X spell because X has to be 0. So with the elf, you get nothing if you cascade into this and you just lost one of your most powerful spells. Things like Blightning were just so much better for that deck because it ensured that your opponent wouldn't have the spells to play and would take direct damage.

So if you're asking yourself why this card isn't more popular, put all the blame on Bloodbraid Elf. As an Esper player, that's what I do... that card is too OP.

180612: Lavalanche.author: SAUS3
180612: Lavalanche.text_parsed:
I have a not-so-casual casual tooth and nail deck (it was my first deck and it was full of timmy, but after years of playing and growing up, it is now just an excessively mean casual deck lol) which runs 2 of these. I use cloudpost + glimmerpost to power out big colourless mana.

I think the most I've done with this was 16.

For the record, my deck has no infinites, and the targets for tooth and nail are really budget. I use terastodon + kederekt leviathan (destroy 3 lands, then all non-land permanents get bounced leaving my opponent with an empty field and -3 lands) or tyrant of discord + realm razer (all lands disappear, then all your permanents get sacrificed in a random order). It's a funny deck :P

180613: Maelstrom Pulse.author: asmallcat
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_parsed:
Considering you can't target wall of denial (it has shroud), it's not important. Now, assuming the wall of denial lost shroud somehow and other walls of denial in play didn't. then yes, they would all die becuase the 2nd part of maelstrom pulse does not target. A better way to think about this would be to think of there being 10 goblin tokens in play, one of which is enchanted with something giving it shroud. What does shard do? It prevents the permanent from being targeted by any spells or abilities. If you target any one of the other 9 goblins, is anything malestrom pulse's 2nd ability does targeting the goblin with shroud? No, it's simply looking for a characteristic of a card, in this case, it's name. Shroud does nothing against pulse's 2nd effect.

Just think if name as being just like any other characteristic. It you played a card that said "destroy all 1/1 creatures," would shroud on the goblin token save it? No, it wouldn't because there is no targeting going on. Same thing here.

180613: Maelstrom Pulse.author: Cathaldus
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_parsed:
Is this card extremely powerful? Obviously.

Is it over-powered, though? I don't think so.

Putrefy was an instant, this is a sorcery. Putrefy killed regenerators for good, this gives them the option to regenerate. This hits more kinds of things, and potentially more things (but at the same time, killing an opponent's permanent could mean killing off your own as well). It's a fair alternative to Putrefy (and definitely fair as a rare). The added power of the card in some ways is fairly tempered by its added drawbacks in others.
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_posted:

180613: Maelstrom Pulse.author: Donovan_Fabian
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_parsed:
Since there are already ways to deal with token decks, I like how this card can target just about anything, sort of a catch all. In the same way however, I wouldn't include more than a few in a deck because the times where it acts as more than a doomblade are situational. Unless you get one of these in a booster they are also very expensive to buy as singles, vs. a jund charm for token removal. I run a number of singletons as I don't need a specific creature for my win condition, so to my decks maelstrom pulse exchanges 1 card per 1 card, its the board sweepers that I care more about.

A fun trick, mirrorweave + maelstrom pulse, destroy all creatures in play.

180613: Maelstrom Pulse.author: JasonC2
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_parsed:
Question was asked - "If your opponent has a beast made by garruk and a beast made by rampaging baloths, does this kill both of them?" Answer, yes it does. They are named "beast" and it doesn't care where they came from or how big they started, or any counters added to them later. They all go. One of the reasons this is a powerful card.

In Worldwake, they came out with a new green sorcery that makes one 1/1 snake, one 2/2 wolf, and one 3/3 elephant, that neatly avoids the usual problem tokens of all kinds have with this card.
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_posted:

180613: Maelstrom Pulse.author: mdakw576
180613: Maelstrom Pulse.text_parsed:
This card is ridiculous. It should've costed 1 more mana. Or make it 2 more mana and make it an instant.

I mean, compared to putrefy... being a sorcery instead of an instant is a bad thing, but in most cases removal can be done on your turn (usually to kill a blocker or something). Unless the creature you want to nuke has haste, it's not really a HUGE deal.

Regenerating isn't a big problem either since most cards now lack it anyway.

However, this can kill enchantments/planeswalkers while putrefy can't, and if your opponent has tokens, or just more than one copy of something in play, this easily gives you huge card advantage.

180614: Dauntless Escort.author: humor_love
180614: Dauntless Escort.text_parsed:
My experience of this guy is nearly the opposite of bowlofgumbo's ("He seems good on paper, he really does. In reality this guy isn't that sick. Cool? Sure. Useful? A little. Game changing? Not really, no. 3.5"). Basically, this creature is a sitting 'soak', or counter spell, for destruction magic.

When I first looked at the card, I thought it could be nice and occasionally helpful, but would generally turn out to be not all that great. I've now played a number of games with a deck in which I have 4 Escorts, along with a number of other excellent and effective creatures. My experience is that, so long as you have a bunch of other creatures in play of the type an opponent would want to destroy or remove as quickly as possible, alongside the Escort, Escort is by far worth much more than the three measly mana paid for it. It's a buffer for all of your other creatures for one turn; not one card - one turn. If you have more than one in play, the opponent just has to sit there and sigh, knowing that she or he must expend a number of destruction spells (even mass spells like Wrath of God and Plague Wind) equal to the number of Escorts in play before beginning to have an effect on creatures other than Dauntless Escort. If those destruction spells have mass effects (like Wrath), they must be expended on separate turns, taking more time and allowing more damage from the creatures being escorted. So, so powerful.

The only way to get around it is to use mass bounce like Evacuation - then maybe counter it as it heads back out, since you're running Blue at that point. Otherwise, you've just gotta use your spells one-for-one on Escort (unless you've got some kind of awesome, repeatable ability on a permanent - maybe Temporal Adept, Royal Assassin, Flameblast Dragon) before getting to the other creatures in play - the ones you're really after.

I see a 5/5 rating as indicating perfection in a card. I'm not sure that any card printed after '94 deserves a 5 rating (examples would be Mox Sapphire and Black Lotus), though several cards do warrant a 4.5 - such as Counterspell. I give Dauntless Escort a 4.5 of 5 rating. I feel that it's one of the very best creatures that a creature-driven deck could have in play. Having more than one in play at one time creates a nearly hopeless situation for a one-on-one opponent - at least, it's basically hopeless for a number of destruction spells played (and separate turns to play them) equal to the number of Escorts in play - or for a number of turns equal to the number of Escorts in play, if Wrath-like spells are the destruction at hand.

Is there a card that 'exiles', say, target creature and all other creatures that share a color or name with target creature? That would really be the best way to deal with multiple Dauntless Escort cards in play - even better than the mass bounce like Evacuation. Clearly, though, such a mass effect would have to be exile or forced sacrifice or something - "destroy" is negated at the sacrifice of a single Escort.

Also, the ability to simply willfully sacrifice is another element making the Escort so incredibly powerful. It's instantaneous and doesn't require even as an additional cost. Just use the sac as a response to something - even if the Escort is already tapped, blocking, or blocked. Also, I don't think you can respond to Escort's sacrifice with any effect that's going to prevent Escort's effect, because Escort would not be in play to be affected; that is, sacrificing Escort is the activation to its ability. Therefore, once you sacrifice Escort, the ability is on the stack, and Escort is no longer in play to be affected. (Say I sacrifice Escort to activate his ability. My opponent wishes to respond by Bolting Escort. Escort is no longer there to be Bolted, and the Bolt either must be cast targeting a different creature, or must not be cast at all. Alternatively, say I sac the Escort to activate its ability. My opponent responds by casting Rout as an instant. In this case, Rout's effect would actually resolve before Escort's ability takes effect. Hm. I hadn't thought of that, before. Pretty cool. Still, casting Rout as an instant requires what, 7 mana? That ain't easy, and isn't too likely to happen in the game of one-on-one Magic.)

Just an amazing creature - and card.
180614: Dauntless Escort.text_posted:
My experience of this guy is nearly the opposite of bowlofgumbo's ("He seems good on paper, he really does. In reality this guy isn't that sick. Cool? Sure. Useful? A little. Game changing? Not really, no. 3.5"). Basically, this creature is a sitting 'soak', or counter spell, for destruction magic.

When I first looked at the card, I thought it could be nice and occasionally helpful, but would generally turn out to be not all that great. I've now played a number of games with a deck in which I have 4 Escorts, along with a number of other excellent and effective creatures. My experience is that, [b]so long as you have a bunch of other creatures in play of the type an opponent would want to destroy or remove as quickly as possible, alongside the Escort, Escort is by far worth much more than the three measly mana paid for it[/b]. It's a buffer for all of your other creatures for one turn; not one card - one turn. If you have more than one in play, the opponent just has to sit there and sigh, knowing that she or he must expend a number of destruction spells (even mass spells like [autocard]Wrath of God[/autocard] and [autocard]Plague Wind[/autocard]) equal to the number of Escorts in play [b]before[/b] beginning to have an effect on creatures other than Dauntless Escort. If those destruction spells have mass effects (like Wrath), they must be expended on separate turns, taking more time and allowing more damage from the creatures being escorted. So, so powerful.

The only way to get around it is to use mass bounce like [autocard]Evacuation[/autocard] - then maybe counter it as it heads back out, since you're running Blue at that point. 180616: Dragon Appeasement.author: gSe7eN
180616: Dragon Appeasement.text_parsed:
I absolutely love this card. I run one in my Jund deck. If you have a three colour Jund deck, this card is brilliant. Don't cast until you have Filigree Fracture in your hand if you're that worried about it. Once this card is in play, the fun begins. Having a Mycoloth in your hand or in play helps. If half of your creatures are Devour cards and the other half (or even less) are Saproling generators, then you're set if all goes as planned. I would not use this card for anything but a Jund deck, however, and not outside of Standard right now. People are commenting on its cost, which I agree is a bit high. I'd like to see it 2BRG. As far as three colours, well, Shards of Alara has six themes, five of which are based on tri-colour decks, one theme based on 5-colour decks. It makes sense that a card falling into a tri-colour theme would be in fact three colours.

This card works very well in today's standard.

180616: Dragon Appeasement.author: JARYISM
180616: Dragon Appeasement.text_parsed:
Why would anyone use this overcosted crap? Yes, you could play stuff like Goblin Bombardment... but why? Enduring Renewal is infinitely better (no pun intended).

You could run stuff like Bloodghast/Blossom with Diamond Valley and/or Recurring Nightmare with this card out to draw cards, but that's so not worth it. When I read half of these ridiculously janky ideas ppl have, you have to ensure:
1) You're drawing at least 3+ cards a turn to make it more worthwhile than simply running Phyrexian Arena, Bob, etc.
2) It's practical, cheap and matches the color scheme
3) Like the Goblin Bombardment idea, there's not a more pragmatic alternative that already works better

Unfortunately this card is so ridiculously overcosted that if you don't simply win the turn it comes into play, it's just not worth it and the risk that comes with it >.>

180617: Lightning Reaver.author: Donovan_Fabian
180617: Lightning Reaver.text_parsed: I'm not really understanding what's so great about this card, it's only 3/3 for 5 mana, in a range where we also have the spirit avatars, and several other huge beat down creatures like lord of extinction and ethersworn adjudicator.  It's ability is only relevant in the case that you can get through to an opponents life points, and that's going to be difficult with so much multi color including a lot of black splash creatures.  If it's removed it's charge counters also become pointless.  The only time it seems like a really good card is a g/b/r beat down deck, that uses colossal might.  If you have 7 to spend on it when it hits play you can attack with a 7/5 trampler that will defintley get that charge counter through.  Otherwise there are several better alternatives, goblin razerunners being one, you don't actually have to sacrifice a land to put counters on it by simply using jund charm or mayael's aria, and obsidian fireheart, that still does damage even when it leaves play.

180617: Lightning Reaver.author: blurrymadness
180617: Lightning Reaver.text_parsed:
If going for an "all-in" strategy; this guy can work pretty well with Reanimate; especially if you pump him at all or toss in double strike. It's also comboable.

Primal forcemage and green in general work well with him. The ramp gets him out earlier, the mana fix ensures you can cast him, the pump ensures he hits like a ton of bricks. T3 this guy with a T2 Primal forcemage

How T2 and T3? Veteran Explorer + any black 1-mana sac outlet. Cabal Therapy is preferred since you'll nail the removal from their hand and secure your advantage. If building around haste in general, strangleroot and vengevine go well in the same deck

You could instead use BoP and utopia sprawl; or several other weird combinations, like crop rotation and flagstones

180619: Vedalken Heretic.author: DoctorKenneth
180619: Vedalken Heretic.text_parsed:
Gomorrah: Whispersilk Cloak can't really be wasted. You can switch equipment to other creatures- so, this to draw you cards in the early game and then equip it to bigger creatures for face smashing in the late game. Not that you would ACTUALLY do that, becuase this isn't that great of a card, but you COULD. In theory.

So, anyway, this is blue/green. It gets card drawing from blue and green gives it....personality? Getting a toughness boost from mama green -to the tune of making it a 1/2- sounds better, so that when you swing on turn three, there won't be a chuckle from your opponent as they consistently eat it with their much bigger two/three drop. But I guess if you get a card off of this, it's already become a Elvish Visionary, so what more could you ask for? Well, that's IF you get a card off this. Which you often can't. I wouldn't take the gamble.

Giving it evasion at this cost would be absurd. Unblockable 1/1 at two is already balanced, you don't need to tack on a cantrip. An extra draw a turn is worth more than that, just ask Phyrexian Arena and it's kin. More conditional evasion....well, that's probably a little more fair, but then it would just BE the bloody Selkie. No, stay in Ravnica and Shadowmoor for your enemy coloured needs, comrades.

180619: Vedalken Heretic.author: JaxsonBateman
180619: Vedalken Heretic.text_parsed:
In theory, it's an excellent card drawing engine if you can give it evasion. In reality, it's difficult to give it evasion, and the second you try to protect it or give it said evasion it'll just get lightning bolted, or shocked, or terminated, or any other 1 damage burn the opponent has.

Should absolutely have been a 2/2, and possibly given exalted. Heck, look at Qasali Pridemage - 2/2, exalted, AND the very useful ability of destroying an enchantment or artifact. That's how they should've designed this card.

180619: Vedalken Heretic.author: Enchantment_Removal
180619: Vedalken Heretic.text_parsed:
This guy is good tempo. If you give him support, he gets you a card. It's not like you need to hit the opponent several turns in a row. He's technically good after two successful combat phases.

So about the mana cost: This being two colors means next to nothing. It simply costs 2 mana. Two mana is that reasonable cost that can be played in the same turn as other stuff. He can be blocked, but still, he needs to be blocked (if you built your deck with useful cards and love). Forcing your opponent to do something for two mana..... is good.

This guy is not tournament quality, but I've managed to use him to the extent that he (barely) earned his rare status.

180619: Vedalken Heretic.author: DarthParallax
180619: Vedalken Heretic.text_parsed:
It's a two mana half-green creature. That's fairly aggressively costed.

Also, they printed Lorescale Coatl in this same set, very very deliberately for synergy.

This is rare because one of these cards had to be rare for Limited. Put them both at uncommon, and it's too much goodness. This guy has two advantages over Ophidian: Deals Damage. And Costs 2.

Making it just an uncommon, for all that, seems like it would be too much. On the other hand, you want more for your rares right?

One last point- this was the early days of the Mythic Rarity. Mythic Rares weren't quite as good back then, and Rares had to be less good than Mythics. Alara Mythics are somewhere between current Rares and Mythics in power, and Alara Rares are somewhere between current uncommons and rares in power, and actually do not look too shabby compared to a wealth of the less sleekly costed cards that came before.

Magic is constantly evolving. The best way to give a card a fair evaluation is to compare it to its predecessors, not to its descendants. This also makes Alpha look much much cooler and less imbalanced, because HEY! Magic! Cool game! :D

180619: Vedalken Heretic.author: DoragonShinzui
180619: Vedalken Heretic.text_parsed:
My problem with this guy is that I can't find a single ounce of flavor in him. Blue and Green both deal with card drawing, yes, but green tends to have either bigger creatures or creatures with great utility, and blue tends to have evasive creatures. Being a 1/1 with no evasion and very limited utility in those colors is kinda...bad. In addition, why is he a rogue? Is it just because he's given up his etherium? Does he conduct guerrilla raids? Looks too much like a monk to me.

I'm not sure how I would've gone about making a vedalken heretic, but I know this isn't it. Especially because of the flavor the other cards have, like Lorescale Coatl, Nulltread Gargantuan, and Jhessian Infiltrator, I'm really underwhelmed and confused by this card.

Also, rarity should never be an excuse for more raw power. Rarity should denote complexity, and relative power, but simply saying "Well he'd be too powerful if he'd be uncommon" is a sign of lazy, lazy, lazy development. I imagine a world where Magic has no rarity system, and all cards have to actually be balanced, and I see a bright and wonderful place.

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: Sorxores
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
This card can be usefull since if you can scare you opponent enought is might force him to use a ring of oblivion or a maelstrom pulse on it. and it will force him to react

But other wise it would give you a bonus at around turn 6 at the earliest in a realistic scenario.

Let say you have a deck build around using Mayael as soon as possible.

Turn 1 : Forest + Bird of paradise
Turn 2 : Plain + Wooly Thoctar but if your opponent is smart he will terminte, path to exile, ring of oblivion, flame javelin, 2 shock... ect your woolly thoctar. And considering that wooly thoctar is a 5/4 on turn 2 they will probably kill him a away or an other.
Turn 3 : Mountain + Mayael's Aria

So yeah if your lucky then maybe you could benefit at turn 4. but let's be realistic you'll need to come out with a new creature because no player a ready to fight a wooly thoctar before turn 5 so they will path to exile or terminate him or block with a 1/1 then agony warp him... and if your opponent let your woolly thoctar survive you have a freaking 5/4 ready to attack on turn 3 you don't need Mayaeal to win just attack and swarm him Knight of new alara would be better then Mayael's Aria since the knight will be targeted by path to exile before the wooly thoctar so he will save your woolly thoctar life.
so let be realistic here :

So on turn 3 (with 4 mana) you'll need to drop a new creature personnaly I like the Steward of Valeron (2/2 vigilance that if you tap give G mana to your mana pool) and Bant sureblade (3/2 first strike)
Turn 4 (with 5 mana) you could drop Uril the miststalker at less he's immune to the spell your opponent control, just wish your opponent do not use wrath of god or Scourglass

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: Donovan_Fabian
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
Unfortunately the other post is right, its on upkeep, an until end of turn power boosts wont trigger it. That having been said, there are several very very easy ways to make that happen, but the easiest one is apocalypse hydra, as long as its counters you add are more than 5 it doubles to 10, but it doesn't stop at 10 either. If you can pay at least enough to get 10, you can cast soul's might on it either immediately or during the next turn for a 20/20 creature. Feral hydra will also do, it can increase its own counters. On top of that, doubling season can signifigantly ramp up any creature to 20/20 in no time, your feral hydra would gain 2/2 per 3 mana, your mighty emergence would gain 4/4 instead of 2/2, and your apocalypse hydra would come into play as a 20/20.

Mayael's aria, doubling season, apocalypse hydra played with 7 mana = game win on next upkeep.

I think its a nice benefit to naya since a lot of "spikes" out there will do anything to win and this can short cut there plan, vs those of us that play for fun, I like to play with big naya creatures but blue/black decks still drive me nuts with all the countering and doom blades. I'm more of a "johnny" type player myself.

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: JaxsonBateman
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
A very, very, very good card for a predominantly green Naya deck when playing as the emperor in an Emperor game.

Turn 1: Birds of Paradise + Forest
Turn 2: Mayael's Aria + Plains/Mountain
Turn 3: Master of the Wild Hunt + land
Turn 4: Mycoloth (devouring Birds and wolf token) + land

After that, it's more or less elementary. A wolf every turn, 4 saprolings, all of them getting 1/1 counters and soon enough 10 health a turn - not to mention you get an extra saproling for each aria counter you get.

Having said that, one Day of Judgement/Wrath of God and your hard work is undone, so I find Eldrazi in the deck is a good idea even though you won't actually get much use out of it until one of your generals die. On the plus side, because you have just so many of them you can guilt-free send saprolings to your generals and hopefully let them live long enough for Aria's win condition to kick in.



In normal play, if you can have one of these out with a Kalonian Behemoth it works pretty well. The first upkeep after the Behemoth comes out it gets boosted to 10 power, and as such you start getting 10 health a turn. Not too shabby.

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: klaff
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
Until the end of turn boosters will affect this enchantment, you just need to know when to cast them. If you give your creature '+20/+20 until end of turn' during your opponents end step, it does not fade until your end step, and is thus around for your upkeep, giving you the win.

So if you have this out, its a good time to tap creatures with a power of ten or greater to feed your Mossbridge Troll and win.

EDIT: Nvm, since mossbridge trolls effect is until the end of turn not 'to the beginning of the next end step' i think I'm wrong about that.
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_posted:
Until the end of turn boosters will affect this enchantment, you just need to know when to cast them. If you give your creature '+20/+20 until end of turn' during your opponents end step, it does not fade until your end step, and is thus around for your upkeep, giving you the win. 

So if you have this out, its a good time to tap creatures with a power of ten or greater to feed your [autocard]Mossbridge Troll[/autocard] and win.

EDIT: Nvm, since mossbridge trolls effect is until the end of turn not 'to the beginning of the next end step' i think I'm wrong about that.

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: exterion
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
@klaff: That doesn't matter, as you can activate the boosting ability in response to mayael's aria's ability. The troll's ability will then resolve, giving it +20/+20, and then mayel's aria will check if you have a creature with blah blah power, and give you the bonuses accordingly, and since the troll is over 20 power, you win the game.
In short: The game doesn't check for the creature's power until mayael's ability resolves, thus any temporary boosts cast during your uppkeep will count toward it's ability.

-Lay down a Hamletback Goliath and watch a couple creatures come in

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: InternetNinjacy
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
Most people miss the best thing about this card. It's not the potential for combo, it's not the alt-win condition, it's synergy with the other Naya cards in the block.

The true value of this card is the same as Teneb, the Harvester, the same as Marit Leige as obtained from Dark Depths. It's not about winning or losing. It's about doing it SPECTACULARLY. Yes, I'm hitting you in the face with a 24/24 Teneb. It's cool that you locked me down, I win in three turns with Mayael. 20/20 turn three, problem?

180620: Mayael's Aria.author: LNExtraordinaire
180620: Mayael's Aria.text_parsed:
Anyone know how this card interacts with Primordial Hydra? Because I just played a game (against myself--sigh) that went a little something like this...And yes, this was an absurdly lucky hand for commander.

Turn 1: forest, Llanowar Elves
Turn 2: forest, Abundant Growth
Turn 3: mountain, Mayael's Aria + Harvest Druid
Turn 4: forest, Primordial Hydra as a 3/3
Turn 5: Primordial Hydra is 6/6 (assumed that it doubled in size after Aria would've decided to put a counter on it--is that right?--so no counter from the Aria), play Doubling Season
Opponent's turn 5: play Hunger of the Howlpack after blocking and eating a soldier, Hydra is 12/12
Turn 6: Hydra gains 2 tokens from Aria x Doubling Season (14/14) and then quadruples in size from its own ability x Doubling Season (56/56)--which may or may not be the right order of operations (if it went quadruple, add instead, I'd have a piddly 50/50). But in either case, I win by the time the third part of the Aria rolls around, without dealing any damage to my opponent (myself). Woo.

The problem is that both the Aria and the Hydra's ability happen "at the beginning of your upkeep." So...?

180622: Deathbringer Thoctar.author: Iwaaan
180622: Deathbringer Thoctar.text_parsed:
People ripping on this card aren't really thinking about what it can do once combined with the right cards. In a zombie deck, this card has unlimited potential.

If you can create a combo with bouncing things to and from the graveyard, Deathbringer Thoctar becomes a freaking beast with infinite power and toughness that can deal an infinite number of damage. Him being a zombie only makes him that much better......definitely an under rated card and without question one that should be a part of any zombie or COMBO deck (seriously, the combo ability on this is amazing).

Also, some of you are dead set that because it needs 6 mana to play, it won't come out until late in the game. Really???? Mana resource cards aren't hard to come by, and having them in your deck makes deathbringer thoctar that much easier to play early in the game.

180622: Deathbringer Thoctar.author: BobbySinclair
180622: Deathbringer Thoctar.text_parsed: My opponent had amassed an army of several dozen 1/1 goblins thanks to Krenko, Mob Boss during one of our EDH games. I had one, maybe two blockers. Even with a decent amount of life remaining, it was clear I was dead next turn. I had a turn to do something... anything! What did I draw? This. This guy munches on 1/1's like they're M&M's. I was running a graveyard shenanigans deck, so I was able to sacrifice one of my creatures. And that one, precious, beautiful +1/1 counter on Deathbringer Thoctar is what allowed me to simply destroy his goblin army, one squealing POP at a time. So many opponents underestimate this guy, but when played correctly, and if the stars align, he may just win you the game.

180625: Madrush Cyclops.author: Donovan_Fabian
180625: Madrush Cyclops.text_parsed: Ok, I can't believe everyones giving this card bad stats.  Lets take a quick look at it, unlike fires of yavimaya you get a creature out of it who can also attack the turn it comes into play with haste.  His being black colored means no doom blade or terror, and his 4 toughness means no single lightning bolt or lightning helix will remove it.  Even better, one of its colors is in green, the mana accel color.  You can easily drop this card on turn 3 with green acceleration.  We also have the new vines of the vastwood to protect it and make it bigger, and in red green colossal might on a 3/4 haste is a 7/6 trampler, use both and its a 11/10 shroud and trample until end of turn when you bring it into play or the turn after.  Plus for pure flavor.. its a huge cyclops with a cool flavor text, "death comes in the blink of an eye," the timmy in me loves it.

I dont see the Madrush being any good in anything but casual because of the cost...especially being three colors.

180625: Madrush Cyclops.author: DarthParallax
180625: Madrush Cyclops.text_parsed:
OK, anyone who says Power Creep doesn't exist, here's Fervor. Woooow....

Now I'm not saying it's 'strictly' better, being just an enchantment, not a 3 power, 4 assed creature--

But really, that 4 ass is probably hugely less relevant than Being Black for it's survivability- and recently Black has had a bunch of things to get around that...so- Cyclops is more killable by a considerable margin, but IS a spell stapled to a creature, so that's value.

Still- a mono-colored 3cmc Rare vs. a Shard-colored 4cmc Rare...I think most people would pick Fervor.

NOTE that this isn't *egregious* powercreeping, since in a Goblin Deck Chieftain is about 4x better than Fervor. But Fervor is good for non-Goblin decks and can be splashed into RUG, BRG, and RGW decks with equal ease- neither the Goblin nor the Cyclops can claim that.

At the same time, the really cool thing about haste is that even aggressively costing it, it doesn't feel like too much Spike Power- its only relevant for one turn of a creature's life. Whereas Cleaver Riot I just couldn't see as an enchantment unless it was over-costed to be helpful or Gold like our friend Mr. One-Eye here. RW, and more than 4cmc probably. But less than 8 mana, because apparently Gisela exists o.O

183007: Offering to Asha.author: Narim
183007: Offering to Asha.text_parsed:
Coyotemoon... you can't really compare this to Countersquall. Both spells are counter magic, but they serve different purpose and both are designed to be in different types of decks.
Countersquall is hard counter, it's much more efficient, but it's not so flexible in terms of use. With Offering, you can face creature heavy decks without having almost dead card in your hand. Countersquall is somewhat aggressive, Offering is with it's lifegain part defensive card. I agree it should be hard counter as well with 4 CMC, but soft counters are not so bad. Most of your plays, your opponent will cast spells without having 4 mana available (and it serves it's purpose of a counter magic), and if he will, he is probable to cast some combo, which is screwed if he pays the additional 4 mana or not, and you still gain 4 life, which is not breathtaking on it's own, but can you buy you turn or two, which can be really, really important.
Offering is not bad card, it just need the right conditions. I consider making a control deck based on restricting my opponent, forcing him to pay additional costs for literary everything... it's going to be WU, so Countersquall have no place in this deck... but Offering to Asha may prove usefull... need to test it to be sure.

183007: Offering to Asha.author: Thornhillforge
183007: Offering to Asha.text_parsed:
Before you judge this card too harshly, remember that hard counters almost always cost at least two blue mana- this one requires only one. In a white-leaning WU deck or a Bant deck, this is much less likely to sit pointlessly in your hand. Plus, people usually cast their bigger spells as soon as they get the mana, so they probably won't have 4 sitting around to pay the extra cost.
In addition, the flavor and art of this card are epic.

183010: Vedalken Ghoul.author: Zeofar
183010: Vedalken Ghoul.text_parsed:
See, the thing about this card is that you don't force them to block it(Lure); you force them to block it. What you do with this is equip it with Quietus Spike. The decision for your opponent is obvious; 4 life and a creature is better that half their life. Enchant it with Lightning Talons and the choice is more difficult. Unscythe, Killer of Kings is overkill, but still a great idea. Of course, removal, yadda yadda, but this shouldn't be your sole strategy.

If you want to go the other route (fake unblockability), then you'll probably want some instant speed pumps. The Ninjas work well with this, too (Inkfathom Infiltrator is better, if we're going into Extended). Although, be warned; the surprise will be lost after the first time.

183010: Vedalken Ghoul.author: NuclearMECCA
183010: Vedalken Ghoul.text_parsed:
Most people seem to love or hate this guy. I happen to love it. Most opponents won't bother to block him, so nothing wrong with one damage every turn. Boost it with a zombie lord and opponents will want to block it. That's when you throw in Agony Warp for laughs. Also autoinclude in any deck running Lich Lord of Unx.

Best way to look at it as a card that compliments others while not being the main focus. In other words, don't bother with Lure or even winning with this guy or worrying about burn. If he's burned, then one less burn spell for your other creatures. This guy will not win the game, just make your opponents worried early game while they have to deal with this guy and your winning strategy like mill for example.

183010: Vedalken Ghoul.author: Baconradar
183010: Vedalken Ghoul.text_parsed:
As others have pointed out, this isn't really a good card. It's essentially a worse than unblockable 1/1 for two different coloured mana, which is a bad deal however you look at it.

Trying to combo or synergise with this guy is pretty pointless in my opinion, because he really is just the above. Giving your opponent a choice is always a bad thing. He belongs simply in the slot where you would put, say, a dimir infiltrator, recognising that he is worse. I have one in an aggressive B/U ninja deck and he's ok there, though often I think something like a zephyr sprite or an aggressively costed black creature would actually be better.

If you must build around him, he should go in a 'pick your poison' deck which gives the opponent the maximum number of choices at all times, in order to grief them.

183010: Vedalken Ghoul.author: Mode
183010: Vedalken Ghoul.text_parsed:
sadly the life loss can't trigger more than once (e.g. by using Lure) since the ability only triggers once for the creature's state of going from "unblocked" to "blocked".
(i think otherwise it would have to read something like "Whenever a creature blocks ~, defending player loses 4 life.")
i like that card, though.
since it's a zombie, it can easily be pumped up by zombie lords (like Death Baron or Undead Warchief) in a tribal deck without directly having to aim for a specific combo. it will be able to hit hard either way. since there aren't that many particularly powerful 2cc zombies, this dude might sometimes find a use to fix the mana curve.
and he also works nicely with really Undead Alchemist.

183011: Necromancer's Covenant.author: HalcyonDays
183011: Necromancer's Covenant.text_parsed:
The problem with playing this card in regular Blue-Black-Red Grixis is obvious: It's splashing white. The hardest part about using this card in that kind of deck isn't as much getting the card, or the white. It's getting both of them at the same time. When I was modifying my Grixis to run this card, I really just gave up on trying to splash it in as the only white-taking card in the deck. That parameter is just too conditional. Better to also throw in some other cheap White-Blue stuff, to mix it up, and go from there. Sure, you're adding a whole new color in, but at the same time you can always keep a side-board of straight Grixis to slip in if things look like they're going to hell..

Or the other way around. Not many people have the forsight to expect a little touch of white in a Grixis deck, and sometimes that's all you need to finish something off.

183011: Necromancer's Covenant.author: Ballynock
183011: Necromancer's Covenant.text_parsed:
The thing I notice people saying a lot is, Zombies are in Blue/Black/Red. I only know two or three zombies needing red, and even Thraximundar isn't that good. Most Zombies are Black/Blue. Some are Black/White. So... Black/Blue/White zombie deck, anyone? :D
If you REALLY want some of the red zombie things like Unscythe, which is awesome in it's own right, use the black red filter lands. Doing that even lets you toss in some other red spells, Banefire wins, Cruel Ultimatum wins, Thraximundar if you really like him...
All works for me.

183011: Necromancer's Covenant.author: Karkain
183011: Necromancer's Covenant.text_parsed: A most excellent card, dudes! But anywho, this card can totally be broken if you run a Zombie deck with mostly Lords or use Deathbringer Thoctar (with at least 1 +1/+1 counter) and Death Baron; the Lords pump all your creatures up and can swing for massive damage, or the Thoctar (and counter) with Baron can wipe an  opponent's field clean while gaining life all the while (use Deathbringer's effect to remove a counter and peck a creature for 1 damage and  kill it (Death Baron grants Deathtouch, thus killing it), regain the counter from the creature going from play to graveyard, and repeat until your opponent is out of non-token creatures). One of the few things that makes me feel better than what this card does for me is using Zombie Apocalypse on a Human deck.

183014: Marrow Chomper.author: infernox10
183014: Marrow Chomper.text_parsed:
@spoonish

Doubling Season doubles any amount of counters placed on a permanent you control.
This guy devouring 1 guy without it gets him +2/+2, and 2 life.
With Season out, he gets +4/+4, and 2 life.
I've always called Doubling Season a "calculator card".
Eventually things get rediculous.

As far as rating the card in general, I agree with most of the previous posters.
This guy can be a big deal if your Creakwood Liege has been out for a while,
Or your token production is maxed.
Or if it's just being a B.A. in general.

Here's how you can gain 1 life and put a Thopter token onto the battlefield for each you pay:
1. Cast Thopter Foundry for .
2. Cast Sword of the Meek for .
3. Pay and sacrifice Sword of the Meek to get a token and return Sword equipped to it.
4. Repeat step 3 until you can't or don't want to spend any more mana.

You can also use this combo with Time Sieve to take as many turns as you like as long as you can afford to spend at least per turn.

183017: Thopter Foundry.author: BladeAce
183017: Thopter Foundry.text_parsed: You have Thopter Foundry and Sword of the Meek on the battlefield. You tap four mana and cast a Krark-Clan Ironworks. You sacrifice any two Ornithopter/Mishra's Bauble/Bone Saw/Spidersilk Net for four colorless mana. You use one mana to sacrifice the Sword of the Meek and make a 1/1 Thopter. The Sword of the Meek comes back onto the battlefield. You spend one of the three floating mana to sacrifice it again and make a new 1/1 Thopter and bring the Sword back again. Then you sacrifice the first 1/1 Thopter to the Krark-Clan Ironworks and get another two mana. You then repeat this until you have enough to cast a Whetwheel. Once you have enough mana to pump throgh the Whetwheel you can Mill there entire deck by this turn. You net 2 life, one mana, and one 1/1 Thopter every time you go through the motions.

Kathari Bomber-Jund/Grixis-Goblin tokens and unearth

185045: Deny Reality.author: Atrues
185045: Deny Reality.text_parsed: to those who rated this low, let me explain something to you, You play this card and bounce one, then you play the next non-land card in your deck for FREE!, if it costs 4 or less... and if that card has cascade, you do it again. the trick to cascade is to run a non-reactive deck, things that don't need the opponent to do something to play (i.e. counterspells). put in the right deck I could see some horrific combos with the cascade mechanic.

185045: Deny Reality.author: herbomatic
185045: Deny Reality.text_parsed:
Cadenblade, since the castable card is also exiled ("... until you exile a nonland card that costs less"), it's indeed - as mtmills has written - treated like all other exiled cards, and randomly put back on the bottom of the library.

And yes, there's no mana burn anymore, anyhow.

185045: Deny Reality.author: mtmills
185045: Deny Reality.text_parsed:
At Elysiume: Cascade doesn't force you to play the revealed spell. You can throw the dark ritual on the bottom of your library with the rest of the revealed cards.

At cadenblade: You CANNOT put the dark ritual on top of your deck if you choose not to play it. The rulings text makes it pretty clear that the last card is also exiled: "When the Cascade ability resolves, you must exile cards. The only optional part of the ability is whether or not your cast the last card exiled."

185051: Monstrous Carabid.author: DarthParallax
185051: Monstrous Carabid.text_parsed:
"Most of the time you cycle this card; the price is very reasonable. But if you draw it late enough that you can pay for it and need the creature, you can play it. Flexibility. That is why you play this card. Now, it's still not fantastic, but people are looking at it way wrong. I give it a 3/5."

I challenge this. It's NOT that the statement is OBVIOUSLY wrong. In fact, it's the ''conventional wisdom'' to explain/defend most good cycling creatures. I challenge that it's correct to apply ''the conventional wisdom'' to EVERY card with a 'conventional' excuse though. Cycling is a FANTASTIC mechanic, PERIOD. But there ARE cards with cycling we shouldn't play. Which ones are they, and why?
Well, they all have mana costs, and they all have cycling costs- how could the statement NOT be true about all of them?

A quick Gatherer Search shows 54 total "Creatures with Cycling" in MAGIC.
Let's see if there's a way to break them down more easily.

There are 18 Non-Landcycling Creatures with Cycling that are Modern Legal. Landcycling is good enough to always be excused. plain Cycling is not. plainscycling is. Errr...

Of them, they are mostly from Alara and Time Spiral blocks. Here is something I notice:


Some of the cyclers have effects when they cycle.
Some of the cyclers cycle for only one color and have other effects.
Some of the cyclers have ETB which is of course great, almost-but-not as good as Landcycling?
And...some of them either don't do anything, do very little, or have a drawback:

Jungle Weaver- a large spider? for {5}{G}{G} it's not worth it. fact is Deadly Recluse is the perfect Reach card and is relatively Overpowered compared to the rest of the Spider Tribe. A Spider deck is makeable but if you just want a Cycler, Green's got better.
Ridge Rannet- a 6/4 Beast with no abilities for {5}{R}{R}? The CYCLING is good, and Red might have needed way more stuff like cycling before, but Red's new card draw and fake looting undermines the need for Cycling, and this is not much better than a giant Spider. At Least Jungle Weaver can block flying bombs.
Yoked Plowbeast- a 5/5 for the SAME CMC. {5}{W}{W}? It's a little bit ridiculous, no!?

7 just -isn't- acceptable for a vanilla creature with medium fat. Not when Green is now getting Fusion Elemental-rates for Power/Toughness/Mana in mono-colored. Vorstclaw.

Why IS Monstrous Carabid more playable than the rest? Because it's Creature Cast setting is mere FIVE MANA! It's a 4/4 for five! and even with the drawback on that mode (must attack). This waayy beats out the CMC 7 of the other 'vanilla' Cyclers, and tells us that 5 mana is what we should want the top-right corner to say if we're SERIOUSLY considering an actually Vanilla Cycling Creature. Six needs at LEAST a single good keyword.

7-cost cyclers are pretty much all Limited Fodder. I am speaking about Constructed because unless you specify which, people will assume you mean Constructed, and people talk about Cycling way too generally.
185051: Monstrous Carabid.text_posted:
[i]"Most of the time you cycle this card; the price is very reasonable. But if you draw it late enough that you can pay for it and need the creature, you can play it. Flexibility. That is why you play this card. Now, it's still not fantastic, but people are looking at it way wrong. I give it a 3/5." [/i]

I challenge this. It's NOT that the statement is OBVIOUSLY wrong. In fact, it's the ''conventional wisdom'' to explain/defend most good cycling creatures. I challenge that it's correct to apply ''the conventional wisdom'' to EVERY card with a 'conventional' excuse though. Cycling is a FANTASTIC mechanic, PERIOD. But there ARE cards with cycling we shouldn't play. Which ones are they, and why?
Well, they all have mana costs, and they all have cycling costs- how could the statement NOT be true about all of them? 

A quick Gatherer Search shows 54 total "Creatures with Cycling" in MAGIC.
Let's see if there's a way to break them down more easily.

There are 18 Non-Landcycling Creatures with Cycling that are Modern Legal. Landcycling is good enough to always be excused. plain Cycling is not. plainscycling is. Errr...

Of them, they are mostly from Alara and Time Spiral blocks. Here is something I notice: 


Some of the cyclers have effects when they cycle. 
Some of the cyclers cycle for only one color and have other effects.
Some of the cyclers have ETB which is of course great, almost-but-not as good as Landcycling?
And...some of them either don't do anything, do very little, or have a drawback:

[autocard]Jungle Weaver[/autocard]- a large spider? for {5}{G}{G} it's not worth it. fact is [autocard]Deadly Recluse[/autocard] is the perfect Reach card and is relatively Overpowered compared to the rest of the Spider Tribe. A Spider deck is makeable but if you just want a Cycler, Green's got better. 
[autocard]Ridge Rannet[/autocard]- a 6/4 Beast with no abilities for {5}{R}{R}? The CYCLING is good, and Red might have needed way more stuff like cycling before, but Red's new card draw and fake looting undermines the need for Cycling, and this is not much better than a giant Spider. At Least Jungle Weaver can block flying bombs. 
[autocard]Yoked Plowbeast[/autocard]- a 5/5 for the SAME CMC. {5}{W}{W}? It's a little bit ridiculous, no!?

7 just -isn't- acceptable for a vanilla creature with medium fat. Not when Green is now getting [autocard]Fusion Elemental[/autocard]-rates for Power/Toughness/Mana in mono-colored. [autocard]Vorstclaw[/autocard].

Why IS Monstrous Carabid more playable than the rest? Because it's Creature Cast setting is mere FIVE MANA! It's a 4/4 for five! and even with the drawback on that mode (must attack). This waayy beats out the CMC 7 of the other 'vanilla' Cyclers, and tells us that 5 mana is what we should want the top-right corner to say if we're SERIOUSLY considering an actually Vanilla Cycling Creature. Six needs at LEAST a single good keyword.

7-cost cyclers are pretty much all Limited Fodder. I am speaking about Constructed because unless you specify which, people will assume you mean Constructed, and people talk about Cycling way too generally.

185053: Bloodbraid Elf.author: Wulfsten
185053: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
This card is stupid. It ruined Standard when it was around. I don't see where all the love for it is coming from. It's clearly designed to be a game-breaking, format dominating card, and that's not a good thing. It makes matches more boring, predictable, and similar.

If you're running red and green, you NEED to run Bloodbraid. If you run Bloodbraid, you NEED to run Blightning and Sprouting Thrinax. If you're splashing black for those two cards, you might as well add Putrid Leech and Maelstrom Pulse. Since you know what colours you're running already, and you're using Cascade, you'll probably run a couple of Bituminous Blasts, or Broodmate Dragons, if you're feeling like more creatures. Common sense will make you throw a couple of Lightning Bolts and Terminates in, and you're done.

The deck builds itself, and requires no thought or imagination. That goes completely against the grain of what makes magic fun.

This card has made Magic worse, not better. And it's not by ignorance. The developers knew exactly the effect it would have.

Common sense will make you throw a couple of[autocard] Lightning Bolt[/autocard]s and [autocard]Terminate[/autocard]s in, and you're done. 

The deck builds itself, and requires no thought or imagination. That goes completely against the grain of what makes magic fun.

This card has made Magic worse, not better. And it's not by ignorance. The developers knew exactly the effect it would have.

185053: Bloodbraid Elf.author: Kryptnyt
185053: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
@Wulfsten
Bloodbraid is great, but not broken. It was only insane at the standard of that day because the mana was so good, with Tri-lands, fetches, dual lands, dual manlands, vivid lands, need I go on? Three color decks are rediculously mana fragile unless they get that kind of boost, and if bloodbraid was only a 2-color deck deal, then it would have not completely dominated the format like it did.

Bloodbraid elf is just good value for an aggressive deck. It can also be used to do silly and fun things, like cascade into Boom//Bust to get a free Armageddon, or hit a removal spell and be a control-resistant Flametongue Kavu. BBE is a creature that beats control decks senseless, but that doesn't make it broken!

185053: Bloodbraid Elf.author: CorkBulb
185053: Bloodbraid Elf.text_parsed:
I run this in my red/green speed aggro deck (duh) and I usually cascade into a Colossal Might or a lightning bolt, which just makes my opponents cry. All the cards except this one are 3 or less to cast, and all the creatures have haste, so I'm gonna get something extra to smash with. Then if I'm lucky enough to play another one next turn, it's usually GG. This usually winds up being my finisher along with the other creatures. The haste just makes it all the better, since you can attack if you cascade into a buff spell playing it on her if you don't have any other creatures.

My only complaint is the P/T is a bit low, but for the abilities vs the CMC it's above the curve.

4.5/5 great card

185054: Ardent Plea.author: lolbrolol
185054: Ardent Plea.text_parsed: 2.5 stars. I really enjoy cascade, but putting it on subpar cards is making cascade much less appealing. Having exalted is decent in places like limited, but this card doesn't do much of anything in constructed. The cascade effect is really good but at the cost of having a card in your deck that is really subpar for the mana cost. And past turn 3, why would you want to topdeck this card? By then, you are usually going to want to attack with more than one creature, and the cascade benefit will be minimal. Cascade should be stuck on cards that do more, in my opinion.

185054: Ardent Plea.author: swords_to_exile
185054: Ardent Plea.text_parsed:
People who underestimate this card, here is why it's good.

Exalted decks thrived of sending in small creatures early before the opponent had board position, and if you got an exalted creature out turn 1 with Hierarch, you could hit this turn 2. That means that turn 3, the absolute lowest you're swinging for is 2, but likely 5, since you could hit a Qasali Pridemage with this.
Once the exalted deck dropped a Rhox War Monk, the lifegain coupled with the exalted put them too far ahead to be caught in a race. Lifelink also stacked at that point in time, so if they dropped a Battlegrace Angel, things got crazy quickly, not to mention Rafiq.

The deck wasn't quite as strong in standard due to the stupid power of jund, but it was very threatening in limited or in semi-competitive.

That means that turn 3, the absolute lowest you're swinging for is 2, but likely 5, since you could hit a Qasali Pridemage with this.  
Once the exalted deck dropped a Rhox War Monk, the lifegain coupled with the exalted put them too far ahead to be caught in a race.  Lifelink also stacked at that point in time, so if they dropped a Battlegrace Angel, things got crazy quickly, not to mention Rafiq.

The deck wasn't quite as strong in standard due to the stupid power of jund, but it was very threatening in limited or in semi-competitive.

185057: Bituminous Blast.author: VrtraTheory
185057: Bituminous Blast.text_parsed:
@Vinifera7

Cascade does trigger (and resolve) before the original spell resolves, so you could target your own Bituminous Blast and copy it if you happened to cascade into Wild Ricochet. However, you can't get a "re-cascade" off of the copied Blast -- Wild Ricochet does not PLAY the copied spell, it just creates a new copy on the stack, so no Cascade will trigger.
185057: Bituminous Blast.text_posted:
@Vinifera7

Cascade does trigger (and resolve) before the original spell resolves, so you could target your own Bituminous Blast and copy it if you happened to cascade into [autocard]Wild Ricochet[/autocard].  However, you can't get a "re-cascade" off of the copied Blast -- Wild Ricochet does not PLAY the copied spell, it just creates a new copy on the stack, so no Cascade will trigger.

185057: Bituminous Blast.author: Vinifera7
185057: Bituminous Blast.text_parsed:
@Significant-Backlash:
If I understand the Cascade mechanic correctly, the spell with Cascade doesn't have to resolve in order for Cascade to trigger, it triggers as soon as the spell with Cascade goes on the stack.

So I'm fairly certain that cascading Bituminous Blast into Wild Ricochet would allow you to choose a new target for the damage, then copy Bituminous Blast, allowing you to deal another 4 damage to another target, then cascading again!

Edit: VrtraTheory has corrected me. Cascade works when you cast a spell, but not when a copy of a spell is put on the stack. You will get a copy of Bituminous Blast, but it will only deal 4 damage; it will not Cascade.
185057: Bituminous Blast.text_posted:
@Significant-Backlash:
If I understand the Cascade mechanic correctly, the spell with Cascade doesn't have to resolve in order for Cascade to trigger, it triggers as soon as the spell with Cascade goes on the stack.

So I'm fairly certain that cascading Bituminous Blast into [autocard]Wild Ricochet[/autocard] would allow you to choose a new target for the damage, then copy Bituminous Blast, allowing you to deal another 4 damage to another target, then cascading again!

[u]Edit:[/u] VrtraTheory has corrected me. Cascade works when you [i]cast[/i] a spell, but not when a copy of a spell is put on the stack. You will get a copy of Bituminous Blast, but it will only deal 4 damage; it will not Cascade.

185060: Kathari Remnant.author: Agent1103
185060: Kathari Remnant.text_parsed:
I think that this card is very underrated, as are most of the Cascade cards. People don't seem to get how the mechanics work for cascade. You build a deck in a manner that benefits cascade, you don't just put stuff in the deck that has a possibility of being useless with cascade. This particular card fits well into an Esper cascade control deck - Enigma Sphinx, Deny Reality, Kathari Remnant, and a lot of discard spells.

Speaking of just Kathari Remnant for a moment, he can act as a flying, regenerating wall. And for his price, you get him and something for free (well kinda for free). So, he is a flying, regenerating wall that forces your opponent to discard 2 cards via Esper Charm or Mind Rot, or Blightning (if you manage to fit those colors).

Think outside the box people. He gets 3 stars for the cascade mechanic alone.

185060: Kathari Remnant.author: Ritius
185060: Kathari Remnant.text_parsed:
Like Cadenblade said, this card is (in my mind) tunnel-visioned on Mind Funeral. Between this and Deny Reality, you can structure a deck so that twelve different cards get you the Mind Funeral effect, and with some clever filler, be it (land)cycling, or functional lands like Spawning Pit, you can make a pretty potent deck. Not to mention, the cascade function clears out of the way all the cards you don't need to win, so it's got more than meets the eye going on. Add some Glimpse the Unthinkables to fill the gap.

I've always thought of this as being a pretty much pre-made deck, like the Bloodbraid Elf, Demonic Dread and Jund Hackblade and whatever that other cascade one was deck.

185063: Shield of the Righteous.author: dgregory
185063: Shield of the Righteous.text_parsed:
I've never really looked at this card closely before, but now that I do I realize that the flavor behind it is FANTASTIC.

Traditionally, Bant sigled-caste armor had no rear protection. In the strictly regimented world of Bant exalted combat, no one would be cowardly enough to strike their opponent from behind so there was no need for it. Now that Bant knights are coming into contact with foes from the other 4 shards that don't always play nice, strapping a big-freaking shield to your back is an extremely good idea.

185064: Captured Sunlight.author: AlphaNumerical
185064: Captured Sunlight.text_parsed: They printed Bloodbraid Elves as a 3/2 Haste Cascade yet they couldn't print this as an instant? That is some shit. My Bituminous Blasts frequently Cascade into Grixis Charms/Terminates/Maelstrom Pulses, and that is an easy two for one instant, so I don't see the problem here. Weak, dedicated lifelink is paltry. Having cascade is nice but worthless if it isn't an instant. Don't let anyone say that lifegain in positive forms such as lifelink sucks, as it can totally hose the win-con's of many otherwise potent decks in a slow war of attrition, but this just shows the worst side of lifegain and why it gets all the hate from 'pro' players. Instant or get the hell out.

188962: Nemesis of Reason.author: OmniMarconi67
188962: Nemesis of Reason.text_parsed: Nemesis of Reason, much like Grimoire Thief, is one of those cards that forces your opponent to deal with it.  If he can't, it's game over, which makes this a great mid-to-end game card.  Grimoire Thief is slightly better because of its early playability and the absolute necessity for your opponent to take attention and waste a turn dealing with it which can give you a huge leg up in turn advantage.  That aside, Nemesis of Reason has the raw power to be a great finisher, which should give it consideration to anyone playing U/B, not just the mill crowd.

188962: Nemesis of Reason.author: Ulfhund
188962: Nemesis of Reason.text_parsed: Defending player is the person being attacked and has nothing to do with whether they actively defended themselves. If this card is legally declared as an attacker and tapped, it's ability will trigger, regardless of whether it's blocked, unblocked or even survives to the actual combat.
188962: Nemesis of Reason.text_posted: Defending player is the person being attacked and has nothing to do with whether they actively defended themselves.  If this card is legally declared as an attacker and tapped, it's ability [i]will[/i] trigger, regardless of whether it's blocked, unblocked or even survives to the actual combat.

188962: Nemesis of Reason.author: blurrymadness
188962: Nemesis of Reason.text_parsed:
@the-unbeliever
Actually, to be totally fair, hand-to-graveyard is only discarding IF it says "discard". If a spell said "target player puts all the cards from his hand into the graveyard" I believe unless errata'd it would not be "discarding".

This is similar to library-to-hand is not always a draw. Some cards PUT cards into your hand, but you don't actually "draw" them, such as a Demonic Tutor. The same distinction, though less compelling, would be between "playing a creature" and "putting a creature into play".


All that said, neato creature, though I feel that's it's likely a 0-10 mill without some really good protection for it.


Oh and this one time a friend cast Nemesis of..
The end.
188962: Nemesis of Reason.text_posted:

Actually, to be totally fair, hand-to-graveyard is only discarding IF it says "discard". If a spell said "target player puts all the cards from his hand into the graveyard" I believe unless errata'd it would not be "discarding".

188962: Nemesis of Reason.author: ICEFANG13
188962: Nemesis of Reason.text_parsed:
I find it quite interesting, that this card (not at all entirely, but overall) is outclassed by Jace, Memory Adept. While Jace is easier to just attack and remove, but he is guaranteed to mill 10 each turn (unless you want to do other things), and is harder to use removal on.

I would think that, for the purpose of milling 10, Jace is in the overall better area (once again, not entirely) but I find it funny that Jace seems to get a lot of hate/dislike, while the comments on this card are full of love!

Perhaps magic changes quicker than I expected.

188965: Filigree Angel.author: Bauble
188965: Filigree Angel.text_parsed:
@ Ellwynd
You don't need the Esperzoa to put Filigree Angel back into your hand for Master Transmuter to work. You can just bounce Filigree with the transmuters over and over.

@ Studoku
Sure, Inkwell Leviathan would make a better defender/attacker, but you don't have to choose between the two. You could just get Inkwell out for {U}, then get Filigree out and keep bouncing her every turn. The end effect: You have a 7/11 shrouded creature to attack/defend with, and are gaining at least 9 life every turn. Good trade for {U} every turn if you ask me!

-

This card has amazing potential with a pair of Master Transmuters and Tezzeret The Seeker on the battlefield (And a few other artifacts, maybe with low CMC's, like Etherium Sculptor, Court Homunculus or Ethercaste Knight). I can't count the amount of times I've ended a game with over a hundred life.

Needless to say, the high CMC IS a pain in the butt, but with Master Transmuter, you can get her out for a measly {U}. But as Crenel has pointed out, she IS an Angel, and Angels usually have higher CMCs. Take the much idolized Serra Angel for example. The artwork is stunning, but 5 mana cost for a 4/4 flying creature with vigilance just isn't a worthy trade in my opinion. Also, it would have given it that much more kick if Filigree were 5/5 and not 4/4. But then again, with the endless life gaining from the bouncing of Filigree, I hardly ever attack with her, and 4 toughness is rather sturdy. Cards like Lightning Bolt can't kill Filigree, so I'm happy.

I love the artwork as well. 4.5/5.

188965: Filigree Angel.author: ArKive
188965: Filigree Angel.text_parsed:
There is no need for an Esperzoa, all u need is a Master Transmuter, as Master Transmuter can target the Filigree Angel, bouncing it to your hand and back to the field again. Having a couple Master Transmuters, a Tezzeret the Seeker, and a Filigree Angel in hand can become quite rude. This is what i managed to do in 1 turn.

Having 2 Fieldmist Borderpost, an Obelisk of Esper a Kaleidostone, a Etherium Sculptor and 2 Master Transmuters on the field.
Play Tezzeret for 5.
Master Transmute my Kaleidostone to my hand playing a Filigree Angel (that's 21 life from 7 artifacts)
Master Transmute it once more (another 21)
Tez uses his first ability, untapping my Transmuters.
MasterTransmutex2 on Filigree Angel (42)
Play Kaleidostone for 1.

in 1 turn, i played a Tez for 5, spent 4 on Transmutes, and 1 to summon a Kaleidostone. 10 mana for a planeswalker, 84 life, 1 draw card, and a 4/4 flying angel.
Not too shabby if you ask me.

188965: Filigree Angel.author: CuriousThing
188965: Filigree Angel.text_parsed:
Easy to compare to Platinum Angel and Emperion. Both Angels are 4/4 fliers, but Platinum costs less in addition to being colorless while Filigree's effect is recurring. Both Emperion and Filigree are 8 CMCs, but Emperion is an 8/8 and colorless while (again) Filigree's effect is recurring and it flies.

So what does it come down to? I don't feel dirty when I play Filigree Angel. When I jump from 1 life to 25 it feels like I'm actually coming back from the brink and that I earned the privilege to do so. When I plop down either of the Platinums at 1 life, it just feels like I'm cheating death.

188966: Jund Sojourners.author: JFM2796
188966: Jund Sojourners.text_parsed: @liory This is in Esper. Each of the Sojourners are "Sojurning" to an enemy Shard, hence the name. Bant Sojourners are in Jund, Naya Sojourners in Grixis, Esper Sojourners in Naya, and Grixis Sojourners in Bant. I find the art on this cycle to be interesting, as each Shard had its own artists, and the art for each Sojourner is done by an artist for the Sojourners native plane. I would assume they did it this way and not the other way around to show more how the Sojourners are perceiving the plane.
188966: Jund Sojourners.text_posted: @liory This is in Esper. Each of the [autocard]Sojourners[/autocard] are "Sojurning" to an enemy Shard, hence the name. 188969: Naya Hushblade.author: Donovan_Fabian
188969: Naya Hushblade.text_parsed:
These may be seriously some of the most under rated cards in the game right now, along with grixis grim blade that has death touch. For one thing, the getting a multi colored permanent into play is extremely easy when we are talking shards of alara, and in the case of naya in particular, one trace of abundance on any land gives all your naya hushblades shroud. Now, at first, a lot of people point out.. hey, its shroud from any spell and ability not just opponents. There are several cards that can boost across the board even with that drawback. Have a thoctar, one naya hushblade, and mayael's aria on the field? You get a bigger shroud creature every turn. Ajani goldmane also fantastic for buffing them. If nothing else any of the lorwyn 2 color enchantments in the right colors, for example a shield of the oversoul makes naya hushblade a 5/4 indestructible, flying, shroud, on turn 3. Any card that can turn into that sort of powerhouse on turn 3 deserves a higher rating, 5/5.

A great comparison is that its a 3/2 shroud watchwolf, another green white thats 3/3 for w/g, but this can also have shroud. You could play them together in the same deck and your watchwolf would give your naya hushblade shroud.

188969: Naya Hushblade.author: SleetFox
188969: Naya Hushblade.text_parsed: If this is your first multicolored permanent you could give it a multicolored demigod enchant, which would not only keep it from having shroud just long enough to get the enchant on, it'll also make it a 5/4, putting it over the Naya 5 power threshold, protect itself from being destroyed/exiled/unsummoned, and gives it trample/double strike, indestructible/flying, or lifelink/firebreathing. Not a game-winning combo, nor is it reliable, but all the cards involved work fine without each other, and it's fairly cheap to pull off (the exception being using Runes of the Deus; it's not cheap and it is pretty close to game-winning. A creature with shroud and trample attacking for 10 or more each turn is not easy to deal with.)
188969: Naya Hushblade.text_posted: If this is your first multicolored permanent you could give it a multicolored demigod enchant, which would not only keep it from having shroud just long enough to get the enchant on, it'll also make it a 5/4, putting it over the Naya 5 power threshold, protect itself from being destroyed/exiled/unsummoned, and gives it trample/double strike, indestructible/flying, or lifelink/firebreathing. 188969: Naya Hushblade.author: Vishlord
188969: Naya Hushblade.text_parsed:
Shroud is a static ability of players or permanents. A player or permanent with shroud cannot be the target of spells or abilities (EVEN HIS OR HER OWN).

So as asmallcat has pointed out... she can only be boosted by non-targeted spells and effects

188969: Naya Hushblade.author: kiseki
188969: Naya Hushblade.text_parsed:
@Cheza and Rikiaz
As far as I can tell you guys are being schizophrenic.
You are happy with Esper being flying, which bakes sense for Blue, but not for hybrid White/Black
You want Bant to have shroud, which makes sense for hybrid Green/Blue but not for White
You want Naya to have first strike which makes sense for hybrid Red/White, but not for Green
For Jund, one of you wants haste for the Red, and one of you wants Deathtouch for the hybrid Green/Black
For Grixis, one of you wants deathtouch for the Black and one of you wants haste for...hybrid Blue/Red?!
Rikiaz: you are at 3 for base, 2 for hybrid
Cheza: you are at 1 for base, 3 for hybrid, and 1 non-sequitur
The designers decided they wanted the base ability to matter, and thus gave each of these cards the a base color ability, which makes sense, since they have the shard in their name, and the shards are really about celebrating the base colors, and tolerating the supporting colors.

188969: Naya Hushblade.author: mdakw576
188969: Naya Hushblade.text_parsed:
probably the worst of the cycle, aside from maybe jund hackblade, though I suppose that's not saying much since it's still decent.

Shroud is only really useful for big fatties/high mana bombs so they're protected from removal, which is more or less the only way to deal with them. In most cases your opponent isn't going to waste a removal on this guy, since a 3/2, while good, dies to most any creature anyway.

Scourge of the nobilis

188969: Naya Hushblade.text_parsed:
704. State-Based Actions

"704.5n If an Aura is attached to an illegal object or player, or is not attached to an object or player, that Aura is put into its owner's graveyard."

So you play Naya Hushblade. Next turn, you put Shield of the Oversoul on it. The next time state-based actions are checked, Shield of the Oversoul would go to your graveyard because Naya Hushblade is now an illegal object.

amirite?

brb downvoting all these comments

P.S. "illegal object" made me think she must only be like 15

So no you are not "rite," and are downvoting helpful comments that should be in top comments because they are informative.

188971: Slave of Bolas.author: PhageRules1
188971: Slave of Bolas.text_parsed: I wish that this name had been given to a creature, but I still love the card. Name, art, mechanic, and flavor text are all awesome and converge beautifully. The mechanic is a perfect idea; the combination of two fairly-oft-used mechanics (temporary theft and temporary putting a creature into play) combine to form something that also incorporates removal. Very elegant. And to top it off, it's an excellent use of gold hybrid.

188971: Slave of Bolas.author: Zoah
188971: Slave of Bolas.text_parsed:
I don't know why you are all so exited about this card. In my opinion it falls short. Personally, after seeing the art on a separate occasion I was quite disappointed by the card itself.

Mind control is just so much better, it takes the creature and lets you keep it for the same price as this one. Also, this one requires you to use a two colored deck at least, mind control can be used in a pure blue deck. Overall, Mind control is just better. Also, if you just want something dead, there are much cheaper ways to kill something.

I do admit that I like the elegance of the idea: take the creature, and kill it when your done. If only it were a little cheaper than it might look much better.

base rating: ***

Elegance of design: +*
Comparative failure: -*
Cost: -*/2

Final: ** */2

188971: Slave of Bolas.author: Donovan_Fabian
188971: Slave of Bolas.text_parsed:
I think some people criminally under rate this card primarily because they don't understand how big of a utility it really is that the creature is sacrificed at the end. There are no other targeted sacrifices in the game (that I can think of off the top of my head), all others are like cruel edict or barter in blood. This mean it just devastates indestructibles, and doesn't care about the creatures size or color. It's not good against shroud, persist, or protection from color x (although if your playing red you can use banefire for that), but it just tackles everything else you can think of. I think many people forget that how powerful the card is also scales with the creature in play, and is one of the best ways to follow up an austere command or a damnation; clearing the board of any follow up creature they might have to try to regain a lead.

For example, its distinctly more powerful on (and these are examples of creatures I've actually used this on):

Magus of the disk (wrath field by auto untapping it with the spell)
Mangara of corondor (exile itself and other target creature for a 2 for 1)
Rampaging baloths (steal the creature then drop your own land to keep a token)
Admonition angel (same as above)
Baneslayer (get a 5 point life gain and deal 5)

to name a few, and even more so that you can remove their biggest threat and hit them with it. It's hybrid mana cost allows you to play it in blue black or red black as well, so its playable in merfolk or grixis or esper or jund. For jund colors you can use rise from the grave on the creature you just killed or even follow up with a vengeful rebirth, take creature and hit them with it, burn another creature with the vengeful rebirth for 5 while bringing back the slave of bolas, and then use it again. How many other removals give you that kind of card advantage? Other removals rather are efficient low cost removal, but only get rid of one creature at a time or give trade offs (like fiery justice and path to exile), barring cards like lavalanche.

188971: Slave of Bolas.author: mdakw576
188971: Slave of Bolas.text_parsed:
I don't know why you are all so exited about this card. In my opinion it falls short. Personally, after seeing the art on a separate occasion I was quite disappointed by the card itself.

Mind control is just so much better, it takes the creature and lets you keep it for the same price as this one. Also, this one requires you to use a two colored deck at least, mind control can be used in a pure blue deck. Overall, Mind control is just better. Also, if you just want something dead, there are much cheaper ways to kill something.

- Mind control doesn't untap the creature, so if you want to use it on something tapped you have to wait until the next turn to start using it. This is probably the most important point; an aggro or mid-range aggro deck doesn't want to wait that long.
- Mind control can be destroyed by things like naturalize/oblivion ring/qasali pridemage/etc.
- Mind control is generally worse on things that have leave battlefield abilities, such as sprouting thrinax (you gain the 3 tokens).

Mind control may still be better, but it's not "so much better". Both have their applications.

188972: Grixis Sojourners.author: tcollins
188972: Grixis Sojourners.text_parsed:
Cycling of any kind is always good, it just makes the card more flexible and make it more useful since the card is less likely to be a dead draw. Add on the fact that you get an extra effect when cycling Grixis Sojourners, and you can end up with some truly awesome plays, such as:

Opponent: I'll cast Dread Return for it's flashback cost, targetting my Kokusho, The Evening Star.
You: In response, I'll cycle Grixis Sojourners for {2}{B} and exile your Kokusho, The Evening Star to net a very handsome 4-for-0 off of a common!
(You opponent loses Dread Return + the 3 creatures he/she sacrificed to cast it, not to mention their Kokusho is now exiled, and the measly common you used to set this all in motion has replaced itself in your hand, at instant speed!

Granted, this is pretty much a best-case scenario, but cycling is pretty awesome, in particular when you get an extra effect as a result.
