188973: Jund Hackblade.author: Donovan_Fabian
188973: Jund Hackblade.text_parsed:
I would say that haste is the least effective of the blades abilities if only because haste is only useful once and after its used its just an obsolete keyword, as in if you don't attack on the turn it comes into play it's the same as it not having haste. On the other hand, there's a really really obvious strategy here.. and that's bloodbraid elf. Bloodbraid elf is also a 3/2 haste that can cascade into anything 3 mana and under, enabling a cascade directly into your jund hackblade for two 3/2 hasters for 4 mana. If you have the mana to attach a runes of the deus, or fists of the demi god, your hackblade can also become a 5/4 first strike wither haste creature. Dropping that much power on the field for 6 mana is pretty epic.

If you compare to watchwolf however, as long as you have something else thats multicolored you have a 2 mana 3/2 haster, where as watch wolf is equivalently 3/3 with no abilities, so it's at least on par.

188974: Firewild Borderpost.author: ErikLauer
188974: Firewild Borderpost.text_parsed:
Erik's Random card 6/25/2011
Alara Reborn was a set with a major "hook" or "gimick": every card was gold.
The basic lands were excluded, but the rest had to be gold.
So there weren't any non-basic lands, because those are not gold cards.

When we (the development team) played a lot of limited with it, we found there just wasn't enough mana fixing. There were cards that helped, but it was still low. If every card is going to be gold, and every color pair is represented, the set needs a lot of fixing. Normally this would mean some common lands, but those would not be gold. So we needed another solution.

Gold mana stones are a solution. The problem is that they aren't a great solution. If you don't have enough mana to cast them, then they don't help. So we tested mana stones that entered the battlefield tapped, but cost you a land drop. However Alara Reborn also has a cycle of "gold loving" two mana creatures, such as the Jund Hackblade. If you could play this on turn 1, then you would be well on your way to casting a turn 2 3/2 haste creature. It made limited a bit too fast.

Requiring that you already have at least one basic land to use this as your land drop meant that super fast start didn't happen. These are still very good with that cycle, but the tempo is a little slower. The text is a little wonky, but we got the play experience right. I think full block Alara is an excellent draft format.

Sometimes when a set has really specific constraints, it is a struggle to accomplish all the other goals. This was one of those, but I think it is a pretty good solution.

Gold mana stones are a solution.  The problem is that they aren't a great solution.  If you don't have enough mana to cast them, then they don't help.  So we tested mana stones that entered the battlefield tapped, but cost you a land drop.  However Alara Reborn also has a cycle of "gold loving" two mana creatures, such as the Jund Hackblade.  If you could play this on turn 1, then you would be well on your way to casting a turn 2 3/2 haste creature.  It made limited a bit too fast.

Requiring that you already have at least one basic land to use this as your land drop meant that super fast start didn't happen.  These are still very good with that cycle, but the tempo is a little slower.  The text is a little wonky, but we got the play experience right.  I think full block Alara is an excellent draft format.

Sometimes when a set has really specific constraints, it is a struggle to accomplish all the other goals.  This was one of those, but I think it is a pretty good solution.

188975: Bant Sureblade.author: GrimjawxRULES
188975: Bant Sureblade.text_parsed:
@darkfury: I disagree. The unblockability provided by Steel puts your opponent on a 4 turn clock, and you're creating a 10 point difference in you and your opponent's life totals every turn with the lifelink ability. First Strike is still viable if you don't get the combo up and running before the late game and you're in need of a blocker: No one would want to run their creatures against a 5/4 first striker that gains you 5 life each time it blocks unless they have a Titan or equivalent on the field.

In terms of Pauper, the blade cycle combined with the "color matters"-auras of Shadowmoor and Eventide are boss.

The borderposts cover a small niche with the gold-bordered blades. The Veinfine is easily the most useful as its corresponding blade, the Hackblade, is a very early, very scary threat. The accompanying Grimblade isn't a bad t2 either.

It's really a hit or miss with these things. Prophetic Prisms are better in almost every other way these days, but for pauper goldblade decks, borderposts are a necessity.

189640: Veinfire Borderpost.author: Ligerman30
189640: Veinfire Borderpost.text_parsed:
@Evermint Prophetic Prisms and borderposts cover two completely different fields. With a borderpost you tap a land, put the tapped land in your hand, then put the borderpost on the field tapped. From then on it is used as a dual land, but, it's an artifact. With prophetic prism, you tap two land and, draw a card. From then on, it's used as a mana converter; in order to add mana of any color you need to tap a land.

Read the cards more closely.

189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.author: Donovan_Fabian
189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.text_parsed:
Probably one of the best cards there is, but by the time you can play it will be almost pointless. An ultimatum at 7 mana is more likely to win you the game than the sphinx can at 8. Also, despite the sphinx's protection and being splash black, there are still several removals that can take her out, including a righteousness on a flyer, divine verdict, path to exile, oblivion ring, unmake, profane command, consume spirit, etc. Blue color players can also just opt to mind control it. Master transmuter can help with the high cost, but then having to be reliant on one card just to get out another is not always the best option, because neither one will function their best without the other. The issue with all cards of this nature is it has to have some sort of great protection like shroud or indestructibility, or it's a win more card. Played to late in the game when you have the disadvantage the build up or momentum that the opponent has reached is better stunted by playing multiple low cost cards, like removals and efficient creatures.

Oh and in case anyone hasn't noticed.. elvish piper is better than master transmuter, as it doesn't have to be artifact, and it doesn't have to bounce another artifact. Also, being in green, could potentially play elvish piper turn 2 -3, where as master transmuter will never be available until turn 5.

189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.author: Kurhan
189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.text_parsed:
For all you "special" ones out there claiming this card isn't good because it can be taken out with path to exile, mind control, oblivion ring, unmake, deathmark, etc, etc...

Name a single card that is immune to all forms of removal. Oh wait, that's right. There isn't one.

At least this has pro green and red so that shatter and naturalize won't take it out.

Every single card has some way it can be taken out. If you think a card is bad because it is capable of not staying in play, then you had better fill your entire deck with lands because they can't be countered, have a limited number of ways of being destroyed, and they have mana abilities that can't be responded to.

Enjoy your Island, Mountain, Forest, Plains, and Swamp.

For the rest of us, there are good cards out there. They may be a bit pricey, but they have their strengths, and just like any other card, they have their weaknesses.

189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.author: FouCapitan
189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.text_parsed:
For anyone thinking Progenitus is a good creature to trump this with, think a bit harder on it.

Progenitus is all colors, so Sphinx of the Steel Wind would have protection from it. With that, neither creature could block each other.

However, with lifelink the Sphinx is healing it's controller 6 life each unblocked attack. So with Progenitus and Spinx of the Steel Wind both out and trading unblocked blows, you'll have the Sphinx side doing 6 total damage each set of turns, but the Progenitus side only doing 4 total.

Now assuming that you aren't completely limited to just your respective bruisers in this match, Progenitus does have the advantage of not being able to be blocked by any cheap, damage mitigating fodder, so he has the advantage as long as he has a valid flying or reaching blocker to help limit the damage/lifelink. But toe to toe, I'd have to award victory to the Sphinx.

189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.author: ilovealara
189641: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.text_parsed:
You can't double Lightning Bolt it.
You can't Doom Blade it.
You can't Terror it.
You can't Go for the Throat it.
You can't Naturalize it.
You usually can't Royal Assassin or Assassinate it.
You can't Beast Within it.
You can't Crushing Vines or Plummet it.
You can't Pyrohemia it.
You can't hit it with a Shivan Meteor, Meteor Storm, or Meteor Shower.
You can't send it Into the Maw of Hell
You can't Shatter it.
You can't Dismember it (Well you can, but not to death)

BUT:

You can Wrath of God or Day of Judgement it
You can Path to Exile it, Exile it, or Swords to Plowshares it.
You can Resounding Silence it.
You can Disenchant it.
You can Solemn Offering it.
You can Tragic Slip it.

189642: Knight of New Alara.author: GrimjawxRULES
189642: Knight of New Alara.text_parsed:
@HairlessThoctar: I know what you mean, but try to think of it this way; people are willing to pay 5 mana for an Overrun that *only* gives all of your creatures +3/+3 and trample for a single turn. In the right deck Knight of New Alara should give all of your creatures at least +2/+2 while also giving you a nice 2/2 creature, all for 4 mana.
Lords being expensive can be justified because they're more or less permanent buffs to the rest of your creatures while at the same time being creatures themselves. And the bigger the buff, the more people are willing to pay for it.
189642: Knight of New Alara.text_posted:
@HairlessThoctar: I know what you mean, but try to think of it this way; people are willing to pay 5 mana for an [autocard]Overrun[/autocard] that *only* gives all of your creatures +3/+3 and trample for a single turn. In the right deck Knight of New Alara should give all of your creatures at least +2/+2 while also giving you a nice 2/2 creature, all for 4 mana.
Lords being expensive can be justified because they're more or less permanent buffs to the rest of your creatures while at the same time being creatures themselves. And the bigger the buff, the more people are willing to pay for it.

189644: Messenger Falcons.author: JaxsonBateman
189644: Messenger Falcons.text_parsed: Works very well with a Knight of New Alara out - instead of getting a 2/2 and 1 card for 4, you get a 5/5 which is decent by anyone's standards. Having said that, on its own it leaves quite a bit to be desired - you can get superior card draw for 1 (Ponder), and a superior creature for 3 (a 3/3 with flying like Jenara), so the fact that you're combining two lesser versions into one card to save space isn't really a good enough reason to cut so much potential.

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.author: Draist
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
I use him for only his first abilty and he still is the card that i would pick over any other 5 drop in my 5 or greater naya deck.

I usually try and play him with Vigor(which prevents all combat damage done to creatures you control and gives them +1+1 counters for each damamge prevented) or Spearbreaker behemoth(which makes creatures with power 5 or greater indestructible for 1 mana), Then he is just broken, becuase he can only be killed by combat damage of which is all prevented, then i put trample on him and its just all over.

His ONLY downfall is that he is legendary so you can only have 1 out :(

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.author: blimmi
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
play this card along with Mayaels Aria and its a game winning combo.

common ways i have had mine killed is by "target player sacrifices attacking creature"

Mayaels Aria says that if you control a creature with a power of 5 or greater each creature you control gains +1/+1 at the beginning of your upkeep. If you control a creature with a power of 10 or greater you gain 10 life on top of +1/+1 counters on each creature. If you control a creature with a power of 20 or greater you win the game. I run 2 Mayaels Aria because they stack. beast

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.author: MisterAction
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
My friend has an EDH deck around this guy. This is, without fail, every single three-player game:

1. We gang up on him, because he's Uril. We know what he does.
2. When he's effectively crippled and either can't play Uril or needs him to block, we turn our guns on each other because whoever finishes him off will be killed by the other guy.
3. Once one of us has eliminated the other, he plays four enchantments and swings in with a 25/25 flying hexproof indestructible double strike vigilance trample.

Normally that kind of comeback is the stuff of legends, but since it happens every game and we all expect it, it's not very entertaining.

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.author: ninjabear
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
I'm curious that people rate him as "one of the most fun EDH commanders" because I feel it's just the opposite. He invites you to build a very simple deck, where you rush to assemble him as a killing machine, slapping him some auras, and then wiping everybody's asses, specially with the "21 damage from your general is enough to kill you" rule.
Most decks I've seen with this general are normally streamlined and with little "tricks" or "resources"; they only want to assemble their Giant Killing Machine (Voltron style, get the pieces together and BAM!!). Feels rather uninteractive to me. Guess it's fun if you love melting faces with giant creatures with super powers.

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
@surewhynot: Uril and Zur are not the only aura-themed legends, even at the time of your comment. Bruna, Light of Alabaster and Krond the Dawn-Clad also exist. And Zur is an enchantment-themed legend, not aura; he's not more aura-themed than Hanna, Ship's Navigator. I'm glad that many of these legends have different color identities so their decks are forced to be built differently.

I used to think Uril didn't deserve the hexproof, but it's there to stop the downside of running auras. So it's a valid addition, unlike just throwing trample on every big creature out there.

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.author: Brawler_1337
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
I'm a little biased towards this guy, given he was my first ever Mythic Rare, but Uril's probably my favorite card in the game. He's a good 5 mana 5/5 beater, and he has hexproof. He has since been outclassed somewhat by Sigarda, Host of Herons, but his ability to become really big really fast never fails to impress me.

Naturally, I've proxied an EDH deck around him (granted, I didn't really know what other General I'd want to make a deck for). I decided not to go the 40 Aura completely Voltron route, as that would be excluding a lot of other cards like Sun Titan, Worldspine Wurm and Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre which I also thought would be good in the deck. So I run a more creature and tech-heavy build. It seems to work well.

My friend also helped me build a Modern deck that's basically a Zoo variant with Aura support like Aura Gnarlid and Kor Spiritdancer, and with Uril teched in as my ace in the hole. From how it has played out so far, it seems pretty consistent. Uril isn't my only win-con, but if he hits the board, it's pretty much game over. It definitely helps that Rancor is now in Modern.

I wouldn't say Uril is very playable outside of EDH, but he does generally make an impact on the game when he comes out. 5/5 hexproof is definitely not easy to deal with. Love him or hate him, I'd say he's a good card. I wouldn't give him a 5 star rating, given his lack of playability outside of EDH, but he's probably good enough to warrant a 4.
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_posted:
I'm a little biased towards this guy, given he was my first ever Mythic Rare, but Uril's probably my favorite card in the game. He's a good 5 mana 5/5 beater, and he has hexproof. He has since been outclassed somewhat by [autocard]Sigarda, Host of Herons[/autocard], but his ability to become really big really fast never fails to impress me.

Naturally, I've proxied an EDH deck around him (granted, I didn't really know what other General I'd want to make a deck for). I decided not to go the 40 Aura completely Voltron route, as that would be excluding a lot of other cards like [autocard]Sun Titan[/autocard], [autocard]Worldspine Wurm[/autocard] and [autocard]Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre[/autocard] which I also thought would be good in the deck. So I run a more creature and tech-heavy build. It seems to work well.

My friend also helped me build a Modern deck that's basically a Zoo variant with Aura support like [autocard]Aura Gnarlid[/autocard] and [autocard]Kor Spiritdancer[/autocard], and with Uril teched in as my ace in the hole. From how it has played out so far, it seems pretty consistent. Uril isn't my only win-con, but if he hits the board, it's pretty much game over. It definitely helps that [autocard]Rancor[/autocard] is now in Modern.

I wouldn't say Uril is very playable outside of EDH, but he does generally make an impact on the game when he comes out. 5/5 hexproof is definitely not easy to deal with. Love him or hate him, I'd say he's a good card. I wouldn't give him a 5 star rating, given his lack of playability outside of EDH, but he's probably good enough to warrant a 4.

189645: Uril, the Miststalker.author: Salient
189645: Uril, the Miststalker.text_parsed:
Awesomely inspiring art, a cool aggrocombo hybrid ability, and aggressively costed -- it's kind of impressive how well this card speaks to Timmy and Spike as well as (obviously) Johnny. I like cards that invite creativity.

earlier, wholelottalove said: "I block people playing this Commander on MTGO."

Hurts my heart. It's kind of unfortunate that Uril is known as the commander played by people who attempt to goldfish their way into third-or-fourth-turn wins without any protection for their combo. So, umm, hey, listen. If you play Uril EDH because you can mulligan into a turn 3 win condition, and you threaten to scoop whenever you don't draw enough for a fast alpha strike or when someone interacts with you, look, you're part of the problem. On the other hand, if you play Uril in EDH because he lets you do cool and interesting things and combine normally marginal/unplayable cards in new and fun ways for unexpected and exciting effects, you're a wonderful human being and you don't deserve the crap people probably give you every single time you announce you're playing Uril.

189646: Defiler of Souls.author: OmegaSerris
189646: Defiler of Souls.text_parsed:
It's amazing how some one could own and/or play against so many cards from a block and still find cards they've never seen thanks to Gatherer's "Random Card". I really thought I've seen everything the Alara and Lorwyn blocks had offer, yet here I am surprised by yet another sweet card I didn't know existed.

I agree that a Flying 5/5 for is definitely on par, especially for . Then his ability is pretty exploitable using his home block. I don't think he would be too amazing in limited though, seeing how Alara Reborn was 100% gold. But outside, yeah...

His ability and his creature type do have an unnoticeable clash. Most demons (outside Alara) are Mono- so while a effects like Reaper from the Abyss won't hurt him, he will most definitely hurt Reaper. I guess you could think of him as a cheaper Lord of the Pit.

Painter's Servant does NOT break this card (Wow, never thought I'd say that). Actually, it neuters it in most cases. Painter's has the clause "addition to their other colors" so all of the cards this would normally hit, actually become multicolored. The exception is colorless, which now are monocolored because of the combo-crow.

I'll also confirm something that deserves repeating: He does not touch Eldrazi or Artifact creatures (well, colorless ones that is). 'Monocolored' is defined the same way as 'Multicolored' in MTG, just used much less.

Multicolored: Colors > 1
Monocolored: Colors = 1
Colored: Colors >= 1 (Thanks to Eldrazi spells)
Colorless: Colors < 1

Monocolored has actually been around since Ravnica while multicolored appeared back in Invasion.

189647: Grizzled Leotau.author: Minus_Prime
189647: Grizzled Leotau.text_parsed:
Consider how many 2 CMC creatures are able to break through that 5 toughness. Technically there were five ever printed, but in any real turn 2-4 situation it's more like zero. Only Dimir Infiltrator's unblockable attribute or various flying creatures can get by Grizzled Leotau in the early game. This guy hoses ground-bound aggro decks all by himself.

Consider also how many 2-drop walls are saddled with less than 5 toughness, less than 1 power, and defender.

Withstands Bloodbraid Elf, Sprouting Thrinax, and even Leatherback Baloth and Vengevine. Takes a hit from Ball Lightning with minimal trample overflow. Takes two Lightning Bolts to kill. Stop me when I mention something that hasn't shown up en-masse in every tournament held in the last two years. He also qualifies for Flying and Indestructibility at your leisure with Shield of the Oversoul.
189647: Grizzled Leotau.text_posted:

189647: Grizzled Leotau.author: jilting_joker
189647: Grizzled Leotau.text_parsed:
Could work neatly in a tri-color, deck, by using Twisted Image and/or Inside Out to switch the power and toughness. With a drawn card as an extra bonus, this could be a clutch play with something like Double Cleave. If Grizzled Leotau is given protection, first strike, or double strike - throw in the switch, and this makes a cheap offensive play.

Grizzled Leotau can be a double-edged sword so to speak. I like the flavor text and the art too.

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: SoulReaverDan
189648: Dragon Broodmother.text_parsed: This card is just amazingly kickass.  Between the various dragon buff cards out there, this shouldn't be a problem.  Combo it with any number of Jund cards that give a bonus when you sac a creature, and you're golden.  Crucible of Fire?  Even if it's not devouring anything, you've got a 4/4 flier.  Doubling Season?  Pop out two, devour one, and it becomes a 5/5.  Lots of options here, and at the end of it, you've just got at on of fliers going around.  Great card, great card.

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: Cigarette
189648: Dragon Broodmother.text_parsed:
Run three of them in my Devour deck. The token production is nuts in a large multiplayer game, since you get one at each player's upkeep. At the end of 5 players turns you can get 9/9 flier without Doubling Season.
Also a great combo with cards like Kresh the Bloodbraided or Rockslide Elemental
My only real gripe is the lack of Black in the mana cost, making it vulnerable to cheap removal. (Maybe take out one of those three Red?)
4.5/5

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: mdakw576
189648: Dragon Broodmother.text_parsed: This is a pretty good card. The problem, however, is that it's competing with dragon broodmate in jund's 6-drop, and no other deck really wants to run this (if you want tokens, run something like wolfbriar). It's basically the same as anowon; anowon is a good card, but it's competing with malakir bloodwitch for vampire's 5-drop, and malakir is better, so anowon never sees play.

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: Xzarfna
189648: Dragon Broodmother.text_parsed:
Ok, i have a brilliant strategy for this card.
I have a Monogreen deck with a large amount of mana output through lands and tappable creatures. I also have 4 Tinder Wall. Now, What i do is, once i have a substantial amount of Forests (8-12) i pop a Howl of the Night Pack, maybe another the next turn if im lucky enough to have two in the same hand. That alone gives me a fair few sacrificial lambs (or wolves hehe). However, if im also lucky enough to have 2 tinder walls, i can play them, sacrifice them and play this card, and the turn after, i can sacrifice all the wolves to get that many dragons which have +1/+1 more than the wolves each. Combine this with Overrun and not many people will survive XD

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: dragonhat

Sweet Avacyn, I love this card. It gives me an unlimited supply of 1/1 missiles to throw at my opponent, and I get the satisfaction of having so many creatures on the table I start to run out of room.
After playing this card:
Me: Okay, I'll start my turn - DRAGON! (puts out a token) - play some spell, and throw a 1/1 flier your way.
Opponent: Okay, it's my turn-
Me: DRAGON! (puts out another token)
Opponent: (glares) Are you going to do that every time you get one of those things?
Me: Yep. Oh, look, it's my turn again. DRAGON!

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: TheGigiBeast
189648: Dragon Broodmother.text_parsed: Another epic card for my Riku Endless Copies EDH deck (creatures that do copies of themselves). A lot of great tokens, and they can even devour themselves when you have enough of them in play.

189648: Dragon Broodmother.author: TheWallinator74
189648: Dragon Broodmother.text_parsed:
Traditionally, Red/Green has had some difficulty dealing with an abundance of fliers... this card solves all of those problems and then some. Even if you just produce a bunch of 1/1's, you've still got a ton of chump blockers, and with enough turns, their numbers can get truly ridiculous. If all else fails, have the children eat each other to become as strong as you need.

Also, the Broodmother herself is amazing when enchanted with Runes of the Deus.

189649: Time Sieve.author: JaxsonBateman
189649: Time Sieve.text_parsed:
Combos insanely well with Sharding Sphinx. When you're at a point where you know you're going to start creating 5 thopters every attacking phase on the next turn (or sooner), activate Time Sieve (after your combat phase, of course - why waste perfectly good thopters that can produce more ^^) and start the never-give-up-your-turn loop. Even if they still have an instant with which to destroy the Sieve, all it takes is a Sanctum Gargoyle or Sharuum to get it straight back out.

Essentially, if they don't have some sort of instant (and enough mana) to destroy the sieve. it's game over.

189649: Time Sieve.author: turtleknite
189649: Time Sieve.text_parsed:
@sir doom

You sacrifice the Sword of the meek to the Thopter foundry. get a 1/1 and gain a life, the the sword comes back attached to the new 1/1 artifact. 5 mana makes 5 thopters and gains you 5 life, then you tap this to sac the five thopters and take an extra turn. repeat. if you have any extra mana, that's more thopters and life to swing with on your subsequent turns. really, i think that this card is just the icing on the cake of the Foundry/Sword combo

189649: Time Sieve.author: FirstPrime
189649: Time Sieve.text_parsed:
@SirDoom

If you sac the Sword of the Meek to the Thopter Foundry it will go to the graveyard, the foundry will put a 1/1 token into play, and the sword will come back into play attached to that token and be free to sac as many times as you want. Therefor for 5 mana you get 5 life + an extra turn with these three cards. Unless the oponent has an answer then and there it's pretty much game over. Broken card?

The power is just sick if you ask me, now toss in some Glassdust Hulk and Salvage Titan or Soul Warden, anything with sac or come into play affects and you have yourself a deck. Throw in some Fabricates to tie it all together. I'm going to build this deck, play it once, have all my friends curse at me like they usually do, and then put it away.

Edit. Ya this card loves thopters, it's like a big bug zapper.

If you sac the [autocard]Sword of the Meek[/autocard] to the [autocard]Thopter Foundry[/autocard] it will go to the graveyard, the foundry will put a 1/1 token into play, and the sword will come back into play attached to that token and be free to sac as many times as you want. Therefor for 5 mana you get 5 life +  an extra turn with these three cards. Unless the oponent has an answer then and there it's pretty much game over. Broken card?

The power is just sick if you ask me, now toss in some [autocard]Glassdust Hulk[/autocard] and [autocard]Salvage Titan[/autocard] or [autocard]Soul Warden[/autocard], anything with sac or come into play affects and you have yourself a deck. Throw in some [autocard]Fabricate[/autocard]s to tie it all together. I'm going to build this deck, play it once, have all my friends curse at me like they usually do, and then put it away. 

Edit. Ya this card loves thopters, it's like a big bug zapper.

189649: Time Sieve.author: BongRipper420
189649: Time Sieve.text_parsed:
In the right deck, this card will easily win you the game every time you cast it. Anyone who doubts this card obviously hasn't seen it used properly. And that's without infinite combos.

While I don't own a deck with this card, I've had the privilege of playing a deck that runs quite a few of these along with cards like Chromatic Star and many other 1 drop artifacts. I've never lost with that deck, mostly because of how abusable this card can be. The cost is mostly negligible in that kind of deck. In fact, it can even be an advantage with 1 or more Disciple of the Vault's and the like.

In conclusion, this card is absurd and will win games when used properly. An easy 5/5.

189649: Time Sieve.author: strider24seven
189649: Time Sieve.text_parsed:
@deadeye1387
Five artifacts is nothing. Not counting the Thopter Assembly and Thopter Foundry/Sword of the Meek infinite combos, simply look for 0-drops like Memnite or Ornithopter or things that get value from sacrifice engines like Ichor Wellspring, Mycosynth Wellspring, Solemn Simulacrum, and Disciple of the Vault. Believe it or not, a card does not have to be stupidly powerful on its own (looking at you, Wurmcoil Engine and Blightsteel Colossus) to be a good card.

In other words:
Time Warp: 3UU, target player takes an extra turn
Time Sieve: UB, you from one to infinite extra turns.

189651: Unscythe, Killer of Kings.author: Bobth
189651: Unscythe, Killer of Kings.text_parsed: I don't think Deathbringer Thoctar is a very good card to go with Unscythe. The beauty of Unscythe is that even a 1/1 token is turned into something that will destroy anything less than an X/5, and when their huge thing dies and your tiny thing dies, you can just re-equip. You don't need to spend 6 mana to bring out a huge creature for this to work with. Tidehollow Strix is actually a much better choice. And of course, anything plus Quietus Spike makes the power and toughness of the creature irrelevant.
189651: Unscythe, Killer of Kings.text_posted: I don't think [autocard]Deathbringer Thoctar[/autocard] is a very good card to go with Unscythe. 189653: Cloven Casting.author: DacenOctavio
189653: Cloven Casting.text_parsed:
Cloven Casting makes Breath of Malfegor hit everybody for 10 damage at instant speed.

Djinn Illuminatus makes Lightning Bolt go on the stack for as many red mana as you can spend. Let's see... pay 6 mana to do 10 to everyone, or pay 6 mana to do 18 to a single player. It's a conundrum. Of course, Illuminatus isn't even in standard, and Cloven Casting is. Paying 8 mana for a double Cruel Ultimatum is also a lovely way to hit and hit hard, but it's not the same as the total direct damage you could do in a duel with DJ and LB, or the damage you could rack up with a cloven Breath in a multiplayer game.
189653: Cloven Casting.text_posted:
Cloven Casting makes [autocard]Breath of Malfegor[/autocard] hit everybody for 10 damage at instant speed.

Djinn Illuminatus makes [autocard]Lightning Bolt[/autocard] go on the stack for as many red mana as you can spend. Let's see... pay 6 mana to do 10 to everyone, or pay 6 mana to do 18 to a single player. It's a conundrum. Of course, Illuminatus isn't even in standard, and Cloven Casting is. Paying 8 mana for a double [autocard]Cruel Ultimatum[/autocard] is also a lovely way to hit and hit hard, but it's not the same as the total direct damage you could do in a duel with DJ and LB, or the damage you could rack up with a cloven Breath in a multiplayer game.

189653: Cloven Casting.author: Enchantment_Removal
189653: Cloven Casting.text_parsed:
Don't build your deck around it. Put one (1) in a deck built around something else (and has many multicolored instants and sorceries and is able to reach 7 mana reasonably).

If you say a card is great, then treat it with respect. If you're planning on pinning down your opponent until you can play this Cloven Casting, then this card is not an important card in your deck (compared to the cards you used to survive to the point of playing this card) and you condescend upon Cloven Casting. The majority of you deck would be shutting down your opponent and/or surviving. All that's left is to do is to kill your opponent/win the game. At that point, Cloven Casting is just as good as Air Elemental.

It is when you have a deck that (coincidentally) runs the appropriate cards that can benefit from Cloven Casting (or any expensive, over-the-top late game card for that matter) that, perhaps, you see it fitting to make room for a copy or two. Then your deck becomes more versatile. You'll be so cool when you impress spectators with your super-secret, late game emergency plan. I know the feeling all to well. hehe
189653: Cloven Casting.text_posted:
Don't build your deck [i]around[/i] it. Put [b]one (1)[/b] in a deck built around something else (and has many multicolored instants and sorceries and is able to reach 7 mana reasonably).

If you say a card is great, then treat it with respect. If you're planning on pinning down your opponent until you can play this Cloven Casting, then this card is not an important card in your deck (compared to the cards you used to survive to the point of playing this card) and you condescend upon Cloven Casting. The majority of you deck would be shutting down your opponent and/or surviving. All that's left is to do is to kill your opponent/win the game. At that point, Cloven Casting is just as good as [autocard multiverseid="189884"]Air Elemental[/autocard].

It is when you have a deck that (coincidentally) runs the appropriate cards that can benefit from Cloven Casting (or any expensive, over-the-top late game card for that matter) that, perhaps, you see it fitting to make room for a copy or two. Then your deck becomes more versatile. You'll be so cool when you impress spectators with your super-secret, late game emergency plan. I know the feeling all to well. hehe

189653: Cloven Casting.author: ratrase

Cast through time seems like a far better choice (even though I think both are too expensive to be worth it). You get the copy one turn later, but you do not have to play red, or play a multicolored spell, or pay 1 extra.

Of course if you are feeling particulary evil and have a shitload of mana, you could alway play both, allowing you to play each spell you cast 4 times.

189653: Cloven Casting.author: Ferlord
189653: Cloven Casting.text_parsed:
The biggest problem I see is the Multi-coloured aspect.

I did some research, and there are "only" 253 multi-coloured instant's and sorcery's out of 3,020 total.

Out of that, 197 have at least one or symbol in their cost.

In different terms, you can somewhat easily use 6.5% of instant's and sorcery's in the game. For a costly Enchantment. That requires two colours.

What I am saying is Mirari is almost always the better choice here.

189654: Gloryscale Viashino.author: OlvynChuru
189654: Gloryscale Viashino.text_parsed:
Don't compare this to Kiln Fiend. This goes in a completely different deck, as it works better with creatures and auras than Kiln Fiend does, while that card works better with instants and sorceries than this card does.

Gloryscale Viashino may not be the best card ever, but what matters is that it has its own niche in the game. I think that people should rate it based on how it performs in that niche.

4/5
